City limits. The words "city limits" or "corporate limits" shall mean the legal boundary of the City of Burlington, North Carolina. 
Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day is Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded. 
Council. The words "the council" or "city council" shall mean the City Council of the City of Burlington, North Carolina, constituting the governing body of the city. 
County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Alamance and the County of Guilford, as applicable, in the State of North Carolina. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision of this Code requires or authorizes an officer or employee of the city to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the act or duty unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
Gender. Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such other as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the words "swear" and "sworn." 
Officials, boards, commissions, etc. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, committees and the like, by title only, they shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Burlington, North Carolina." 
Or, and. "Or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
Owner. The word "owner," when applied to buildings or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or part of such building or land. 
Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit, as well as an individual. 
Personal property. The words "personal property" shall include every species of property, except real property as herein defined. 
Plural, singular. Words importing the singular shall include the plural, and words importing the plural shall include the singular. 
Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after respectively. 
Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
Real property. "Real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
Signature or subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of North Carolina. 
Statutes references. Whenever reference is made for example, to G.S. Section 160A-200, it shall be construed to refer to General Statutes of North Carolina, Section 160A-200, as amended, or to whatever section is cited. 
Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, lane, path, viaduct, bridge or other public place and the approaches thereto within the town when any part thereof is open to the use of the public and established for purposes of vehicular traffic. 
Tenant, occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land shall include any person who occupies the whole or part of such building or land, whether along or with others. 
Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and the present. 
Writing or written. The word "writing" or "written" shall include printing and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code of 1959, § 1-2; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code of 1959, § 1-3)  
Sec. 1-4. - General penalty, continuing violations. 
Wherever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, any person, upon conviction of the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not exceeding twenty (20) days for each separate violation. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. Violators shall be further subject to the provisions of North Carolina General Statutes, Section 160A-175. 
(Code of 1959, § 1-4; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference G.S.14.4; G.S.15A-1340.23.  
Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of code. 
It is hereby declared to be the intention of the council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the council without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code of 1959, § 1-5)  
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal or expiration of ordinance. 
The repeal of an ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued, any offense committed, any penalty or punishment incurred or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. 
When an ordinance which repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(Code of 1959, § 1-6) 
State Law reference Repeal of statute, G.S. 12-2.  
Sec. 1-7. - Liability of corporate officers, agents and employees for violation of code. 
In the event of a violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city by a corporation, the officer, agent or employee thereof who performs the act constituting the violation or procures, aids or abets the performance of such act shall be subject to the same penalties as if he himself had committed such violation.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Elections. 
Pursuant to G.S. 163-290, the city council does hereby exercise its option and select the nonpartisan primary and election method of determining the results of municipal elections as set out in General Statutes Section 163-294. 
(Res. No. 72-6, 1-18-72)  
Sec. 2-2. - Authorized countersignature. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by law, the city manager is hereby designated and authorized as the official of the city to countersign all checks or drafts on an official depository, and all other instruments or documents converting demand deposits, time deposits, investment securities, or other assets into cash, negotiable instruments, or any other form of deposit or investment. 
(b)  The city manager and finance director are hereby authorized to use facsimile signature stamps in signing the instruments as hereinabove set forth. 
(c)  The finance director is hereby charged with the custody of said stamps. 
(Res. No. 73-51, 8-21-73; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Secs. 2-32-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 
 
Sec. 2-16. - Organizational meeting. 
The organizational meeting of city council shall be the first regular meeting in December after the results of the municipal election have been certified pursuant to Article 23, Chapter 163 of the General Statutes. At the date and time of meeting, the members of the city council whose terms of office then begin shall severally make oaths to perform faithfully the duties of their respective offices. 
(Code 1959, § 2-1; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-17. - Resignation of members. 
The resignation of any member of the council shall be tendered in writing and shall not be acted upon until the next regular meeting of the council unless by unanimous consent of those present. 
(Code 1959, § 2-2)  
Sec. 2-18. - Regular and special meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the city council shall be held in the city council chamber in the municipal building at 7:00 p.m. on the first and third Tuesdays of each month; the work session of the city council will ordinarily be held on the Monday prior to the first regular meeting of the city council each month at a location and time determined by the council for which due notice has been given. The mayor, mayor pro tem, or any two (2) members of council thereof may at any time call a special meeting by causing a written notice stating the time of holding such meeting and signed by a person calling the same, to be delivered in hand to each member or left at his usual dwelling place at least forty-eight (48) hours before the time of such meeting. Furthermore, as provided by G.S. 143-318.12 as currently written or hereafter amended, at least forty-eight (48) hours before the time of such meeting, this written notice shall be posted on the door of the usual meeting room, posted on the city's website, and mailed, electronically conveyed, or delivered to each newspaper, wire service, radio station and television station which has filed a written request for notice of special meetings with the clerk. All such notices of said special meetings shall state therein the purpose for which such meeting was called. 
(b)  The mayor, mayor pro tem of the city council, or any two (2) members thereof may at any time call an emergency meeting of the city council by causing a written notice stating the time and purpose of holding such meeting and signed by a person calling the same, to be delivered in hand to each member or left at his usual dwelling place at least six (6) hours before the meeting. Furthermore, said notice of such emergency meeting shall be given by telephone or electronically conveyed to each local newspaper, wire service, radio station and television station which has filed with the city clerk a written request to be notified of emergency meetings. (If there is any cost involved in providing these said emergency notices to said media, the cost shall be charged to the media so notified.) 
(c)  Only business connected with the emergency may be considered at such an emergency meeting. ("Emergency meeting," as used in this section, shall be defined as a meeting called due to generally unexpected circumstances that require immediate consideration or attention by the city council.) 
(Code 1959, § 2-3; Ord. No. 78-58, § 1, 10-3-78; Ord. No. 82-1, § 1, 1-19-82; Ord. No. 08-07, § 1, 2-19-08; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-19. - Quorum. 
For a quorum, the mayor shall be counted and included in obtaining a majority of the members to constitute a quorum of the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-4; Ord. No. 80-54, § 1, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-20. - Order of business. 
At all regular meetings of the city council the mayor and the members of the city council shall determine under the circumstances the appropriate order of business to be transacted and the use of a consent agenda is hereby expressly authorized. 
If the council directs any matter to be the special business of a future meeting, the same shall have precedence over all other business arising at such meeting. Any question discussed at a previous meeting and left open may be taken up at any time at any regular meeting at the request of a majority of the members present. 
No proposition shall be entertained by the mayor until it has been seconded, and every proposition shall, when required by the mayor or a member, be reduced to writing. When a question is under consideration, no motion shall be received except as follows: To lay on the table; to postpone to a time certain; to postpone indefinitely; to refer to a committee; to amend; to divide and to strike out or insert. Motions for any of these purposes shall have precedence in order named. 
(Code 1959, § 2-5; Ord. No. 89-9, § 1, 2-7-89)  
Sec. 2-21. - Voting. 
All final votes of the city council involving the expenditure of fifty dollars ($50.00) or over shall be by yeas and nays and shall be entered on the records. Three (3) affirmative votes shall be necessary for the passage of any order, ordinance, resolution or vote. 
(Code 1959, § 2-7)  
Sec. 2-22. - Rules of order. 
Unless otherwise provided herein, the deliberations of the council shall be governed by the most recent Robert's Rules of Order, revised. 
(Code 1959, § 2-8)  
Secs. 2-232-33. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LEGISLATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-34. - Enactment of ordinances. 
An ordinance may be finally passed on the date on which it was introduced by a majority of the members of the council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-6; 8-21-18 recodification) 
Charter reference Sec. 3.62. 
State Law reference G.S. 160A-75 Voting; G.S. 160A-76 Franchises, technical ordinances.  
Sec. 2-35. - Effective date. 
Every ordinance passed by the city council shall be in force from its passage unless otherwise provided therein. 
(Code 1959, § 2-6)  
Sec. 2-36. - Official copy. 
The city clerk shall keep a bound copy of all ordinances of the city which shall be the official copy. 
(Code 1959, § 2-6)  
Secs. 2-372-42. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AMENDMENTS TO THE CODE 
 
Sec. 2-43. - Manner. 
All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code by the city council.  
Sec. 2-44. - Language. 
Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of the City of Burlington, North Carolina, is hereby amended to read as follows: " The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired.  
Sec. 2-45. - New material. 
(a)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added thereto, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of the City of Burlington, North Carolina, is hereby amended by adding a section (or division, article or chapter), to be numbered ____________, which section (or division, article or chapter reads as follows:" The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(b)  In lieu of subsection (a) hereof, when the city council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the Code, which the council desires to incorporate into the Code, a provision in substantially the following language may be made a part of the ordinance: "It is the intention of the city council, and it is hereby ordained, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Code of the City of Burlington, North Carolina, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention."  
Sec. 2-46. - Effect. 
Any and all additions and amendments to this Code of Ordinances when duly adopted by the city council shall indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part thereof and shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the "Code of the City of Burlington, North Carolina," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-47. - Repeal. 
All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions of this Code of Ordinances desired to be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be.  
Sec. 2-48. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing sections or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code; and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code.  
Secs. 2-492-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 2-60. - Persons eligible for office. 
No person shall be eligible to be appointed or to continue serving on any board or commission of the city unless he or she is a resident of the city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to membership on boards or commissions which, in the resolution or ordinance creating the commission, residence within the city is specifically not required. 
(Code 1959, § 2-12; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-61. - City manager. 
The city manager shall be appointed by and hold office during at the pleasure of the city council. 
The city manager shall be the administrative head of the city government and shall be responsible for the administration of all departments. 
(Code 1959, § 2-11; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-62. - Manager's authority to settle claims. 
Pursuant to section 7.01 of the City Charter, the city manager may compromise and settle all claims and lawsuits of any kind or nature involving the city including but not limited to tort claims, land condemnation, contract disputes and civil penalties and execute any and all documents, including releases necessary for the settlement of such claims or lawsuits. Provided however, the manager's authority under this section shall be limited to settlements not exceeding fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). Agreements, releases or other final documentation require the approval of the city attorney as to form and sufficiency. 
(8-21-18 recodification) 
Charter reference Manager's authority to settle claims provided by ordinance, § 7.01.  
Sec. 2-63. - City attorneyAppointment. 
The city attorney shall be appointed by the city council and may be removed by the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-18; Ord. No. 85-30, § 1, 4-2-85)  
Sec. 2-64. - SameDuties and compensation. 
It shall be the duty of the city attorney to give to the mayor, the council, the city manager and other officers of the city all necessary legal advice connected with their duties and to render to the city such other legal services as may be required. Compensation for the city attorney shall be fixed by the council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-19; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-65. - Finance directorGenerally. 
As required by G.S. 159-24 as currently written or hereafter amended, there is hereby established the office of director of finance appointed by the city manager. The duties of finance director shall be as set forth in G.S. 159-25 together with any additional duties assigned by the city manager. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-66. - Deputy finance officer. 
(a)  A deputy finance officer shall be designated by the manager. 
(b)  In the absence of the finance officer the deputy finance officer shall perform any duties as authorized for the office of director of finance. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 2-672-79. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
 
DIVISION 1. - PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
 
Sec. 2-80. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to each board and commission created and appointed by the city council. Provisions unique to a specific board or commission shall be provided for in the ordinance applicable to said board or commission. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-81. - Nominations to office; term. 
Except where specific provision is made for the creation or term of office of a board or commission by ordinance requiring an exception to this section or by laws of the state or the United States: 
(a)  The city council shall appoint all members and alternates of boards and commissions; 
(b)  The term of office of such members and alternates shall be three (3) years with original appointments so as to provide for the expiration of one-third of the members each year; 
(c)  Members shall be eligible to serve for not more than three (3) consecutive full terms. For purposes of this limitation, initial terms of whatever duration set out above shall be deemed full terms. Thereafter, anyone appointed to complete a vacancy on a board or commission of greater than eighteen (18) months duration shall be deemed to have served a full term. 
(d)  If a sufficient number of qualified applicants are not available to fill the vacant seats, then the city council in its discretion may extend the term of a current member for a term of one (1) year and such other one-year terms until a sufficient number of qualified candidates are available for service and are duly appointed by the city council. 
The time herein fixed for nomination, election or appointment is directory and not mandatory. Members of boards and commissions and alternates shall hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1959, § 2-53; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-82. - Expiration of terms of office of members appointed by council. 
The date of the expiration of the term of office of the members and alternates of all boards and commissions appointed by the city council shall be June thirtieth. Terms of new members, other than those appointed to fill a vacancy, shall begin July 1. 
(Code 1959, § 2-53; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-83. - Removal of members; absenteeism. 
A member of any board or commission of the city may be removed by the council for cause. 
If a member shall miss all of the meetings held during any period of ninety (90) days without excuse granted by the board or commission, this may be considered cause for removal. The position may be declared vacant and a successor appointed. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-84. - Vacancies in membership. 
The council shall fill any vacancy in the membership of any board or commission resulting from any cause other than the expiration of a term for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1959, § 2-60; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-85. - Concurrent service prohibited. 
An individual shall be eligible to serve on only one (1) city board or commission at any one time; it is therefore expressly provided that concurrent membership on city boards and commissions shall not be permitted. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-86. - Compensation. 
Members of boards and commissions shall serve without pay but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incidental to the performance of their duties in accordance with existing City of Burlington policies. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-87. - Officers. 
Each city board and commission shall elect a chair, vice chair and secretary to serve for such time as may be fixed by such board or commission. 
(Code 1959, § 2-57; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-88. - Committees. 
Boards and commissions may, from their own membership or membership otherwise appointed by city council, establish any temporary or permanent committees needed to assist in the study of specific questions and problems. In addition, commissions may seek advice and assistance from citizens and from professional sources, pending authorization by the city council if funding is required. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-89. - Rules and quorum. 
Roberts Rules of Order, the most recent edition, shall be followed to the extent possible in the conduct of meetings. Every board and commission shall notify the city clerk of any rules adopted contrary to the provisions of Roberts Rules of Order. 
A quorum shall consist of a majority of the regularly appointed commission members, along with any alternates participating at that particular meeting. A quorum shall be required for the commission to take action. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-90. - Voting, advocacy, monetary interest. 
No member of a board of commission may discuss, advocate or vote on any matter in which he or she has a separate, private or monetary interest, either direct or indirect, and no member may discuss before the city council or its committees any matter which has been, is or will be considered by the board or commission on which he or she serves, and in which he or she has a separate, private or monetary interest either direct or indirect. Any member who violates this provision may be subject to removal from the board or commission. 
(8-21-18 recodification) 
Cross reference Conflict of interest, Ch. 2, Art. VII.  
Sec. 2-91. - Place of meetings; meetings public. 
All regular and special meetings of boards and commissions shall be held at a location approved by the city council. Public notice shall be given as to time and location within Alamance County unless otherwise approved by city council. All such meetings shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1959, § 2-54; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-92. - Time of regular meetings. 
Regular meetings shall be held on such days and at such hours as may be fixed by rule of the particular board or commission. 
(Code 1959, § 2-55; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-93. - Special meetings. 
All special meetings of any city board or commission may be called by the chairman by notice given in writing and delivered personally to each member or left at his place of residence not less than forty-eight (48) hours before the time fixed for such meeting, which notice shall state the day, hour and purpose fixed for the meeting. Furthermore, as provided by G.S. 143-318.12 as written or hereafter amended, at least forty-eight (48) hours before the time of such meeting, the written notice shall be posted on the door of the usual meeting room, posted on the city's website; and mailed or electronically or physically conveyed to each newspaper, wire service, radio station and television station which has filed a written request with the clerk for notice of special meetings. All such notices of said special meetings shall state therein the purpose for which such meeting was called. 
(Code 1959, § 2-56; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-94. - Staff and technical services. 
Boards and commissions may request from the city council necessary staff or technical services. 
(Ord. No. 90-51, § 8, 11-6-90)  
Sec. 2-95. - Records and reports. 
Each city board and commission shall keep a complete and accurate record of all its proceedings, which record shall be public. Boards and commissions shall make such reports as shall be required by the city council from time to time. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-96. - Fiscal restraint. 
Each city board or commission shall make no expenditure or contract any indebtedness for which the city shall be liable without the approval of the council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-77)  
Secs. 2-972-99. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HOUSING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference Housing, Ch. 14. 
 
Sec. 2-100. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a commission to be known as the city housing commission. 
(Code 1959, § 2-72)  
Sec. 2-101. - Appointment, terms, rules. etc. 
Administrative provisions including but not limited to appointment, terms, removal, vacancies, compensation, officers, rules and quorum, place and time of meetings, special meetings, records and reports and fiscal restraint contained in Article V, Division 1. "Provisions Applicable to All Boards and Commissions" shall apply to the Housing Commission. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-102. - Composition. 
The housing commission shall be composed of five (5) regular members and two (2) alternate members. Alternate members shall be appointed for the same term, at the same time, and in the same manner as regular members. Each alternate member, while attending any regular or special meeting of the commission and serving in the absence of any regular member, shall exercise all the powers and duties of a regular member. 
(Code 1959, § 2-73; Ord. No. 88-32, § 1, 7-19-88; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-103. - Duties generally. 
The duties of the housing commission shall be as follows: 
(a)  To study the need for reconditioning or condemnation, affordability, quality supply and other housing challenges within the city, and to make recommendations to the council concerning such matters. 
(b)  To perform such other duties as may be assigned it from time to time by the council. 
(c)  The commission may inspect houses and living quarters in the city and shall have the right to enter with the building inspector for that purpose. 
(d)  To hear and determine appeals from decisions of the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement upon any provision of the housing code or unsafe nonresidential building ordinances. 
(e)  To serve as a housing appeals board as provided by G.S. 160A-439 and G.S. 160A-446. 
(Code 1959, § 2-72; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-104. - Appeals from building inspectorProcedure; effect. 
(a)  An appeal to the housing commission may be taken from any decision or order of the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement by any person aggrieved thereby or by any officer, board or commission of the city. Any appeal from the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement to the commission shall be taken within a reasonable time as prescribed by the rules of the commission and shall be taken by filing with the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement and with the secretary of the commission a notice of appeal which shall specify the grounds upon which the appeal is based. Upon the filing of notice of appeal, the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement inspector shall forthwith transmit to the commission all the papers constituting the record upon which the decision appealed from was made. 
(b)  When an appeal is from a decision refusing to allow the person aggrieved thereby to do any act, the decision of the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement shall remain in force until modified or reversed by the commission. 
(c)  When an appeal is from a decision requiring the person aggrieved to do any act, the appeal shall have the effect of suspending the requirement of the chief inspector or administrator of code enforcement until the hearing thereon by the commission; unless the building inspector certifies to the commission, after the notice of appeal is filed with him, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate (a copy of which shall be furnished the appellant), a suspension of his requirement would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property, in which case the requirement shall not be suspended except by a restraining order, which may be granted, for due cause shown and upon not less than one day's written notice to the building inspector, by the commission or by any judge of the superior court authorized by law to grant restraining orders. 
(d)  The commission shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of all appeals and shall render its decisions within a reasonable time. 
(e)  Upon the hearing of any appeal any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
(Code 1959, § 2-81; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-105. - SameVote necessary to reverse inspector. 
The concurring vote of four (4) members of the commission shall be necessary to reverse or modify any decision of the building inspector. See G.S. 160A-446(d) 
(Code 1959, § 2-82; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-106. - SameScope of decisions. 
The commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the decision appealed from, and may make such decision and order as in its opinion ought to be made in the matter. 
(Code 1959, § 2-84)  
Sec. 2-107. - Appeals from commission. 
Every decision of the commission shall be subject to review by the superior court of Alamance County by proceedings in the nature of certiorari. 
(Code 1959, § 2-85; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 2-1082-114. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - COMMUNITY APPEARANCE ADVISORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-115. - Established. 
There is hereby created and established "The Burlington Community Appearance Advisory Commission" hereinafter referred to as the "commission" composed of nine (9) members appointed by the City Council of Burlington, North Carolina. All members shall be residents of the planning and zoning jurisdiction of the City of Burlington. 
(Ord. No. 90-51, § 1, 11-6-90; Ord. No. 04-50, § 1, 8-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-116. - Purpose. 
The commission is established as an advisory body to the city council for the purpose of promoting the enhancement of the visual quality of the city especially as to public places and, to the extent feasible by voluntary means, to private development. 
(Ord. No. 90-51, § 2, 11-6-90)  
Sec. 2-117. - Appointment, terms, rules, etc. 
Administrative provisions including but not limited to appointment, terms, removal, vacancies, compensation, officers, rules and quorum, place and time of meetings, special meetings, records and reports and fiscal restraint contained in Article V, Division 1. "Provisions Applicable to All Boards and Commissions" shall apply to the community appearance advisory commission. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-118. - Membership qualifications. 
Where possible, appointments shall be made in such a manner as to maintain on the commission members who have had special training, or experience or interest in landscape architecture, horticulture and city planning or a closely related field. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-119. - Powers and duties. 
The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To initiate, promote and assist in the implementation of programs of general community beautification in the city. 
(2)  To offer advice and assistance to individuals, agencies, and organizations, public and private, whose plans, activities and programs bear upon the appearance of the city and to provide such advice and assistance upon request of such entities. 
(3)  To offer leadership and guidance in matters of area or community design and appearance to individuals, and to public and private organizations and agencies, and to provide such guidance upon request of such entities. 
(4)  To make studies of the visual characteristics and problems of the city, including surveys and inventories of an appropriate nature and to recommend to the city council standards and policies of visual appearance for the entire area, any portion or neighborhood thereof, or any project to be undertaken. 
(5)  To prepare and recommend to the city council both general and specific plans for the improved appearance of the city. These plans may include the entire area or any part thereof. The plans shall set forth desirable standards and goals for the visual enhancement of the city. 
(6)  To review, upon request from the proper officials of any public agency or body, including agencies of the state and its political subdivisions, proposals of those agencies for landscape and visual treatment of proposed buildings and facilities and to make recommendations concerning such proposals to the requesting agency and/or to any duly established department, board or commission or the governing body of the city. All such reviews shall be done within the existing regulatory review time framework of such duly established department, board, commission, and/or the city council. Such recommendations as are made shall be in writing. 
(7)  To review proposals upon request of city departments and boards or commissions for the adoption of ordinances affecting the visual appearance of the city. 
(8)  To formulate and recommend to the city for adoption such policies as will, in the opinion of the commission, enhance the appearance of the city. 
(9)  To advise Burlington officials of needed enforcement of any ordinance that may in any way affect the appearance of the city. 
(10)  To seek voluntary adherence to the standards and policies of its plans; as recommended to and adopted by the city council. 
(11)  To promote public interest in and an understanding of its recommendations, studies and plans, and to that end to prepare, publish and distribute to the public after adoption by the city council, such studies and reports as will, in the opinion of the commission and the city council, advance the cause of improved appearance in the city and its planning jurisdiction. 
(12)  To facilitate the planting, growth and protection of trees within the city, and more particularly: 
a.  To foster the communication among the citizens of Burlington that would provide the needed protection of trees and to coordinate active measures to support their health and growth within the city. 
b.  To investigate available grants, loans or contributions from other governmental agencies, public or private corporations or individuals and to recommend the expenditure of any proceeds toward the accomplishment of the tree advisory committee's purpose. 
c.  To conduct continuing research, planning and feasibility studies required to support the purpose stated herein. 
d.  To formulate and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and landscaping in city parks, along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented to the Burlington Community Appearance Advisory Commission and the city council, and upon its acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive tree plan for the City of Burlington, North Carolina. 
e.  To prepare and administer an official street tree species list comprised of three (3) groups of trees: small trees, medium trees and large trees. 
f.  To develop and administer guidelines for the spacing of city-owned trees in accordance with the three (3) groups of trees in the official street tree species list. These guidelines will cover spacing between street trees, the distance street trees may be planted from curbs, curb lines and sidewalks, the distance street trees may be planted from any street corner, the location of street trees relative to overhead and underground water and sewer lines, transmission lines, telephone poles or other utilities and any other areas involving the spacing of street trees, park trees or other city-owned trees. 
g.  To educate the public as to the economic, aesthetic and environmental benefits of trees and shrubs to the City of Burlington and the need to follow proper planting and tree care requirements. 
h.  To determine tree planting priorities for the city. 
(i)  To perform such other functions provided by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 90-51, § 5, 11-6-90; Ord. No. 4-50, § 2, 3, 8-3-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-120. - Administration. 
All accounts and funds made available to the commission shall be administered as an element of the public works department budget.  
Sec. 2-121. - Funds. 
The commission may receive contributions from private agencies, foundations, organizations, individuals and the state or federal government, or any other source, in addition to any sums appropriated for its use by the city council, such contributions to be administered as set forth above for other accounts and funds. 
(Ord. No. 90-51, § 9, 11-6-90)  
Secs. 2-1222-129. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC TRANSIT ADVISORY COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 2-130. - Creation. 
There is hereby created a commission to be known as the Public Transit Advisory Commission, (hereinafter, "PTAC" or "commission"). 
(Ord. No. 2014-31, 10-7-14; Ord. No. 2015-22, 12-1-15)  
Sec. 2-131. - Membership, qualifications. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of seven (7) members, five (5) from the City of Burlington, one (1) from the Town of Gibsonville, and one (1) from Alamance County. Said members shall be appointed by the governing body of the participating elected governmental entity. Should additional governmental entities elect to join the system (the City of Graham, the City of Mebane, etc.) the commission shall be expanded by one (1) member for each elected governmental entity joining the system. 
(b)  The governing body of each participating governmental entity shall also each appoint one alternate to the commission, with such alternate participating in the commission meeting when the regularly appointed commission member from that governmental entity is not present. When participating in the place of an absent member, alternates shall be counted for the purpose of establishing a quorum and shall have the same powers and authority as a regular commission member. 
(c)  All members of the commission must reside within the jurisdiction of the participating governmental entity by which they were appointed. 
(d)  The Burlington City Council shall make a good faith effort to include membership from diverse elements of its community on the commission. 
(e)  Should any participating governmental entity, other than the City of Burlington, elect to withdraw from the system, the commission membership shall be retracted by one (1) position and that governmental entity's position on the commission, along with the corresponding alternate position, shall cease upon the effective date of the withdrawal. 
(f)  Should the participating governmental entity's representative to the commission also be an elected official of the appointing governmental body, said commission member's appointment to this commission shall be deemed vacated by resignation upon his or her termination in the elected office. In turn, the governmental entity's governing body shall appoint an individual to complete said vacant term. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-132. - Terms, rules, etc. 
Administrative provisions including but not limited to terms, removal, vacancies, compensation, officers, rules and quorum, place and time of meetings, special meetings, records and reports and fiscal restraint contained in Article V, Division 1. "Provisions Applicable to All Boards and Commissions" shall apply to the public transit advisory commission. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-133. - Duties. 
The commission shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Advise the city council and the city staff with regard to transit system policies and safety matters including routes, ridership policies, transit fares, accessibility modes, customer amenities and operating policies. 
(2)  Receive input from the citizenry and the ridership of the system involving public transit issues and make appropriate recommendations to the city council. 
(3)  Recommend to the city council rules and procedures governing public transit programs, equipment and facilities, regulatory guidelines, service improvements, hours of operation, and security. 
(4)  Recommend marketing strategies for the promotion of public utilization of the transit system. 
(5)  It is the intent of this division that all matters affecting the governance and operation of the public transit system, including the annual budget thereof, shall first be considered by the commission and recommendations thereon made to the city council. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the council from acting without the commission's recommendation when the council deems it necessary.  
Secs. 2-1342-149. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PERSONNEL SYSTEM  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-150. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to establish normal procedures which will serve as a guide to administrative action concerning the various personnel activities and transactions. They are intended to indicate customary and the most reasonable method whereby the aims of the city's personnel program can be accomplished. 
(Code 1959, § 2-23)  
Sec. 2-151. - Organization generally. 
The city manager shall be responsible for personnel administration within the city government. A human resources director will be responsible to the manager for the administrative and technical direction of the personnel program. 
(Code 1959, § 2-25; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-152. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this article shall be applicable to all city employees except as provided below: 
(a)  Elected officials shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Employees not covered by the classification plan of this article shall be exempt from sections 2-170 through 2-219. 
(c)  Part-time officials appointed by the city council and employees of advisory or special boards and commission who work on irregular schedules. 
(d)  Temporary or emergency appointments. (Code 1959, § 2-27) 
(e)  Part-time employees with scheduled hours of twenty-nine (29) or less per week. 
(Code 1959, § 2-27; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-153. - Powers and duties of human resources directorGenerally. 
The human resources director shall be responsible for all phases of personnel administration not specifically reserved for the city council or the city manager and shall perform all duties essential to effective personnel administration. The human resources director shall administer all personnel programs which may be activated, such as classification and compensation plans, retirement and insurance programs, testing and training programs, grievance procedures, service rating systems, and various fringe benefit programs, such personnel rules, plans and procedures as may be necessary or desirable to implement the provisions of this article and carry out the intent of the city council. All such personnel rules, plans and procedures shall be established only upon approval of the city manager and shall be made available for review by the city council and inspection by city employees. 
(Code 1959, § 2-29; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-154. - Records. 
(a)  The human resources director shall retain records necessary to the proper administration of the personnel system. 
(b)  Personnel records maintained by the city are subject to inspection in accordance with state law applicable to municipal personnel records, as provided in G.S. 160A-168 "Privacy of employee personnel records" as currently written or hereafter amended. 
(c)  All information contained in a city employee's personnel file, other than the information made public under G.S. 160A-168 is confidential and shall be open to inspection only in the following instances: 
(1)  The employee or his duly authorized agent may examine all portions of his personnel file except: (i) letters of reference solicited prior to employment, and (ii) information concerning a medical disability, mental or physical, that a prudent physician would not divulge to his patient. 
(2)  A licensed physician designated in writing by the employee may examine the employee's medical record. 
(3)  A city employee having supervisory authority over the employee may examine all material in the employee's personnel file. 
(4)  By order of a court of competent jurisdiction, any person may examine such portion of an employee's personnel file as may be ordered by the court. 
(5)  An official of an agency of the state or federal government, or any political subdivision of the state, may inspect any portion of a personnel file when such inspection is deemed by the official having custody of such records to be inspected to be necessary and essential to the pursuance of a proper function of the inspection agency, but no information shall be divulged for the purpose of assisting in a criminal prosecution (of the employee), or for the purpose of assisting in an investigation of (the employee's) tax liability. However, the official having custody of such records may release the name, address, and telephone number from a personnel file for the purpose of assisting in a criminal investigation. 
(6)  An employee may sign a written release, to be placed with his personnel file, that permits the person with custody of the file to provide, either in person with custody of the file to provide, either in person, by telephone, or by mail, information specified in the release to prospective employers, educational institutions, or other persons specified in the release. 
(7)  The city manager, with concurrence of the council, may inform any person of the employment or nonemployment, promotion, demotion, suspension or other disciplinary action, reinstatement, transfer, or termination of a city employee and the reasons for that personnel action. Before releasing the information, the manager or council shall determine in writing that the release is essential to maintaining public confidence in the administration of city services or to maintaining the level and quality of city services. This written determination shall be retained in the office of the manager or the city clerk and is a record available for public inspection and shall become part of the employee's personnel file. 
(8)  Even if considered part of an employee's personnel file, the following information need not be disclosed to an employee or to any other person: 
a.  Testing or examination material used solely to determine individual ualifications for appointment, employment, or promotion in the city's service, when disclosure would compromise the objectivity or the fairness of the testing or examination process. 
b.  Investigative reports or memoranda and other information concerning the investigation of possible criminal actions of an employee, until the investigation is completed and no criminal action taken, or until the criminal action is concluded. 
c.  Information that might identify an undercover law enforcement officer or a law enforcement informer. 
d.  Notes, preliminary drafts and internal communications concerning an employee. In the event such materials are used for any official personnel decision, then the employee or his duly authorized agent shall have a right to inspect such materials. 
(9)  The city council may permit access, subject to limitations they may impose, to selected personnel files by a professional representative of a training, research, or academic institution if that person certifies that he will not release information identifying the employees whose files are opened and that the information will be used solely for statistical, research, or teaching purposes. This certification shall be retained by the city as long as each personnel file examined is retained. 
(d)  The city council of a city that maintains personnel files containing information other than the information mentioned in subsection (b) of this section shall establish procedures whereby an employee who objects to material in his file on grounds that it is inaccurate or misleading may seek to have the material removed from the file or may place in the file a statement relating to the material. 
(e)  A public official or employee who knowingly, willfully, and with malice permits any person to have access to information contained in a personnel file, except as is permitted by this section, is guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor and upon conviction shall only be fined in the discretion of the court but not in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(f)  Any person not specifically authorized by this section to have access to a personnel file designated as confidential, who shall knowingly and willfully examine in its official filing place, remove or copy any portion of a confidential personnel file shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor and upon conviction shall only be fined in the discretion of the court but not in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 04-40, § 1, 6-3-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-155. - Merit principle. 
All appointments and promotions of employees shall be made solely on the basis of merit and fitness. All positions requiring the performance of the same duties and fulfillment of the same responsibilities shall be assigned to the same class and to the same salary range.  
Sec. 2-156. - Violations. 
Any employee violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to suspension and/or dismissal in addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this article.  
Secs. 2-1572-169. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CLASSIFICATION PLAN 
 
Sec. 2-170. - Adoption. 
The position classification plan, as prepared by the human resources director, will be the official classification plan for the city. 
(Code 1959, § 2-26; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-171. - Coverage. 
The classification plan shall include all full-time classes of positions in the service of the city. The human resources director shall allocate each position covered by the classification plan to its appropriate class. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-172. - Purpose. 
The classification plan provides the complete inventory of all full-time positions in the service of the city and an accurate description and specification for each class of employment. The plan standardizes titles, each of which is indicative of a definite range of duties and responsibilities of the same meaning throughout the classified service. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-173. - Composition. 
The classification plan shall consist of the following: 
(a)  Grouping of positions in classes which are approximately equal in difficulty and responsibility which call for the same general qualifications, and which can be equitably compensated within the same range of pay under similar working conditions. 
(b)  Class titles descriptive of the work of the class which identify the class. 
(c)  Written specifications for each class of positions.  
Sec. 2-174. - Use of class titles. 
Class titles are to be used in all personnel, accounting, budget appropriation, and financial records. No person shall be appointed to or employed in a position in the classified service under a title not included in the classification plan. Other job titles may be used in the course of departmental routine to indicate authority, status in the organization, or administrative work. 
(Code 1959, § 2-28)  
Sec. 2-175. - Use of class specifications. 
Specifications are to be interpreted in their entirety in relationship to others in the classification plan. Particular phrases or examples are not to be isolated and treated as a full definition of a class. Specifications are deemed to be descriptive and explanatory of the kind of work performed and not necessarily inclusive of all duties performed.  
Sec. 2-176. - Use of plan. 
The classification plan shall be used as follows: 
(a)  As a guide in recruiting and examining applicants for employment; 
(b)  In determining salary to be paid for various types of work; 
(c)  In determining personal service items in departmental budgets; 
(d)  In determining lines of promotion and in development of employee training programs; and 
(e)  In providing uniform job terminology understandable by all officials and employees and by the general public.  
Sec. 2-177. - Administration of the plan. 
The human resources director is charged with administration and maintenance of the classification plan so that it will accurately reflect the duties performed by employees in the classes to which their positions are allocated. It will be the human resources director's duty to examine the nature of the positions as they are created and to allocate them to existing classes or to create new classes as deemed appropriate; to recommend such changes in the classification plan as are made necessary by changes in the duties and responsibilities of existing positions; and periodically to review the entire classification plan so that the city manager may recommend appropriate changes in individual position allocations or in the classification plan to the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 2-30; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-178. - Allocation of position. 
When a new position is established or the duties of an existing position change, department heads shall submit in writing a comprehensive job description describing in detail the duties of such a position. The human resources director shall thereupon investigate the actual or suggested duties and recommend to the city manager the appropriate class allocation or the establishment of a new class. The city council shall then act upon such recommendations. 
(Code 1959, § 2-32; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-179. - Request for reclassification. 
Employees who consider their position improperly classified should first submit their request to their supervisor who shall review such request as to its justification and shall transmit a recommendation to the human resources director. The human resources director shall render a decision, advise the employee and make a recommendation to the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Secs. 2-1802-199. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PAY PLAN 
 
Sec. 2-200. - General. 
The pay plan includes the basic salary schedule as adopted by the city council and subsequent amendments thereto and a schedule of salary ranges consisting of minimum and maximum rates of pay for all classes of positions included in the classification plan. 
(Code 1959, § 2-38; Ord. No. 97-27, § 3, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-201. - Maintenance of plan. 
The human resource director shall be responsible for the administration and maintenance of the pay plan. The pay plan is intended to provide equitable compensation for all classes in the classification plan with regard to range of pay or other classes, general rates of pay for similar employment in private establishments and other public jurisdictions in the area and being based on cost-of-living data, financial condition of the city and other factors. To this end, the human resources director, with authorization from the city manager, will periodically make comparative studies of all factors affecting the level of the salary ranges and will recommend to the city manager for council consideration such changes in salary ranges as appear to be pertinent. Such adjustments will be made by increasing or decreasing the assigned salary level for the class and adjusting the rate of pay for employees in the class when action is approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 04-40, § 2, 6-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-202. - Use of salary ranges. 
Salary ranges are intended to furnish administrative flexibility in recognizing individual differences among positions allocated to the same class, in providing employee incentive and in rewarding employees for meritorious service. The following general provisions shall govern the granting of within-the-range increases: 
(a)  Department heads have authority to establish the starting pay for new hires up to ten (10) percent above minimum pay without obtaining city manager approval pending budget availability. Starting pay in excess of ten per cent (10%) above minimum pay shall be approved by the city manager pending budget availability. 
(b)  New employees will receive a two and one-half (2½) percent pay increase after twenty-six (26) weeks after which they will enter the merit pool and be evaluated with other employees in their department/division for future salary increases. 
(c)  Further advancements in pay are reserved to reward employees for meritorious service. Annually, pending budget availability, department heads shall consider the eligibility of the employees to receive an increase in pay and recommend such advancement or retention at the same rate. Department heads are to consider all relevant factors affecting employee performance and recommend whether to advance or retain the employee at the same rate. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 3-4-50; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27, §§ 2, 46, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 1, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 04-40, § 3, 6-3-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-203. - Salary of trainee. 
Applicants hired or employees promoted to positions in higher classifications who do not meet all of the established requirements of the position may be appointed or reassigned upon recommendations of the department head and human resources director with approval by the city manager at a wage below the minimum established for the position. An employee shall remain on the trainee step until the department head and the human resources director shall certify that the trainee is qualified to assume the full responsibility of the position. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27, §§ 2, 7, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-204. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-205. - Pay for part-time or temporary work. 
The pay plan established for this article is for full-time service. Employees appointed for less than full-time service shall be paid at a rate consistent with a comparable job classification and level.  
Sec. 2-206. - OvertimeGenerally. 
Employees of the city shall be required to work overtime hours if determined necessary by a department head or in cases of emergency. Supervisors shall arrange the work schedules of their sections so as to accomplish the required work within the standard work day. If it is necessary for an employee to work beyond the hours established for the standard work day, the department head may authorize overtime work. Compensation for overtime worked by non-exempt employees may, per department policy, be in the form of granting compensatory time or monetary compensation as determined by methods established by the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(Ord. No. 77-6, § 1, 3-15-77; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-207. - Payment of overtime (exempt employees). 
Exempt employees required to work overtime because of emergency conditions may be compensated for their overtime work with the approval of the city manager. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-208. - Call-back pay. 
Employees, subject to overtime provisions, called out on emergency work after hours will be guaranteed a minimum of two (2) hours pay as a reporting fee.  
Sec. 2-209. - Payroll deductionsGenerally. 
Withholding taxes, employee's retirement contributions and social security shall be deducted at each pay period as required by law from each employee's pay. Other deductions may be authorized for group insurance, savings accounts, uniforms, etc.; however, no deductions shall be authorized for individuals or groups that are not available to all employees.  
Sec. 2-210. - SameCharitable purposes. 
No payroll deductions from employee's pay for contributions to charitable organizations or otherwise shall be made without prior request of the employee and approval of the city manager.  
Sec. 2-211. - Withholding from final paycheck for unreturned city property or money owed. 
(a)  The city will withhold from an employee's final paycheck an appropriate amount for the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to return city-issued equipment or uniforms; or 
(2)  Accepting a bad check or credit card, if such acceptance was in violation of procedures previously made known to the employee; or 
(3)  Any cash shortage from a cash register, drawer or depository provided for that purpose, if the employee had sole access to the cash and participated in the cash accounting at the beginning of the employee's shift and the end of said shift; or 
(4)  Any cash shortage, walkout (failure of customer to pay), breakage, or loss of equipment if the shortage, walkout, breakage or loss was caused by a dishonest or willful act of the employee; or 
(5)  Theft of city property. 
(b)  The city may not withhold earnings from the final paycheck for any of the above incidents that occurred in previous pay periods. In no case shall the city reduce an employee's final gross earnings below the federal minimum wage in effect at the time the work is performed. 
(c)  Should an employee's final earnings be insufficient to pay the amount due, the city may institute civil action against the employee for the outstanding amount. 
(8-21-18 recodification) 
Cross reference Withholding of wages, G.S. 95-25.8.  
Secs. 2-2122-219. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT 
 
Sec. 2-220. - WorkweekGenerally. 
The standard or basic workweek of employees of the city shall be forty (40) hours per week and eight (8) hours per day.  
Sec. 2-221. - SamePolice, fire and shift personnel. 
The basic workweek for police, fire and shift personnel will be without reference to the number of hours per day or days of the week as set forth in section 2-220 but shall be the number of hours established by the council and as scheduled by the city manager in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-222. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-223. - Outside employment. 
The work of the city shall have precedence over all occupational interests of employees. All outside employment for salary, wages, or commissions, and all self-employment must be reported to the employee's department head. Conflicting outside employment shall be grounds for disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal.  
Sec. 2-224. - Political activity restricted. 
Every employee has a civic responsibility to support good government by every available means and every appropriate manner. Each employee may join or affiliate with civic organizations of a partisan or political nature, may attend political meetings, may advocate and support the principles or the policies of civic or political organizations in accordance with the constitution and laws of the United States of America. However, no employee shall: 
(a)  Engage in any political activity while on duty; 
(b)  Be required as a duty of his office or employment, or as a condition for employment, promotion, or tenure of office, to contribute funds for political or partisan purposes; 
(c)  Solicit, or act as custodian of, funds for political or partisan purposes; 
(d)  Coerce or compel contributions for political or partisan purposes by any other employee; 
(e)  Use any supplies or equipment of the city for political purposes; or 
(f)  Become a candidate by whatever means for nomination, election, appointment or service to elected statutory office. 
(Code 1959, § 2-38; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 2000-1, § 1, 1-4-2000)  
Secs. 2-2252-230. - Reserved.  
Sec. 2-231. - Employee organizations. 
North Carolina law provides that the right of persons to work shall not be denied on account of membership in any labor union, labor organization or association. By virtue of a federal court decision, this law applies to cities, counties, and other units of government. In accordance with this law, employees of the city have the right to belong to labor unions. However, the city recognizes the right of any employee to refrain from membership and participation in a union or employee organization. The city will not permit coercion or discrimination against any employee in the exercise of their right not to join a union or other employee organization. Such coercion or discrimination will constitute cause for dismissal. Activities associated with unions or union membership will not be permitted during any employee's work hours. Union meetings, solicitations, collections of dues, passing out of handbills and literature are prohibited on the job. Any employee who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. Strikes and work stoppages by city employees will not be permitted. Instigation of, participation in, or giving leadership to a strike, work stoppage or disruption of the normal work process shall constitute grounds for disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. Infractions of work rules including unauthorized absences from work shall be grounds for disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84)  
Secs. 2-2322-239. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 
 
Sec. 2-240. - Purpose. 
The city recognizes the need to provide certain fringe benefits to the city employees in order to recruit qualified personnel and as an incentive for seeking employment with the city.  
Sec. 2-241. - Insurance benefits. 
(a)  The city will provide at no cost to its employees the opportunity to enroll in the city's group health, dental, group hospitalization, accident and life insurance programs. The costs, if any, for the employee to cover themselves will be determined each year based on recommendations from the third-party administrator, city manager or the city's insurance committee. Also, this group insurance shall be made available to the employees' dependents on a participating cost basis. 
The city may, in its discretion, offer other insurance programs to its full-time employees, including but not limited to long-term care insurance. 
(b)  Other insurance programs, such as accident, disability, cancer, etc., which will serve the needs of the employees of the city, may be offered through payroll deduction. 
(c)  Information concerning the cost and benefits of the insurance program shall be available to all employees through the finance office. or through the supervisors. Booklets explaining the program will be available to all employees. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 03-40, § 1, 11-18-2003; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-242. - North Carolina Local Governmental Employee's Retirement System. 
Each full-time employee and part-time employees in positions requiring them to work more than 1,000 hours per year shall be required to join the Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System as a condition of employment. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 97-27, § 10, 6-17-97; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-243. - Death benefit. 
The city has elected to provide a death benefit at no cost to the employee under the provisions of the North Carolina Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System. This benefit constitutes upon death, a payment to the employee's beneficiary an amount equal to the highest twelve (12) months of salary in a row during the twenty-four (24) months before the employee's death, but no less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) and no more than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00). Payment of this benefit is subject to laws governing the retirement system. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-244. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Section 2-305 in the prior Code, relative to the North Carolina Law Enforcement Officers' Retirement and Benefit Fund, was repealed by Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, enacted June 2, 1987. Said section bore no history note.  
Sec. 2-245. - Workers' compensation. 
(a)  Employees are fully covered by workers' compensation and are required to report all injuries arising out of and in the course of their employment with the city to their immediate supervisor or, in the event their immediate supervisor is unavailable, to occupational health or their immediate supervisor's superior at the time of the injury in order that appropriate actions may be taken. 
(b)  Such coverage shall not be construed to include accidental injuries sustained while off the job or while performing services for a private employer either on or off city-owned property. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-246. - Longevity pay. 
(a)  On or around the 20th day of each month, annual longevity payments shall be made in accordance with the longevity pay plan to all full-time employees whose date of hire falls within the month and who have completed at least five (5) years of continuous service. Payments shall be based on the basic salary of employees as of the month payment is to be made. The payment schedule applicable to each employee shall be based on the year in which the employee was hired. 
For employees hired prior to July 1, 1995, the following payment schedule will apply: 
(1)  One (1) percent of basic annual salary after two (2) years of continuous service. 
(2)  Two and one-half (2½) percent of basic annual salary after five (5) years of continuous service. 
(3)  Four (4) percent of basic annual salary after ten (10) years of continuous service. 
(4)  Five (5) percent of basic annual salary after fifteen (15) years of continuous service. 
(5)  Six (6) percent of basic annual salary after twenty (20) years of continuous service. 
For employees hired after July 1, 1995, the following payment schedule will apply: 
(1)  One (1) percent of basic annual salary after five (5) years of continuous service. 
(2)  Two (2) percent of basic annual salary after ten (10) years of continuous service. 
(3)  Three (3) percent of basic annual salary after fifteen (15) years of continuous service. 
(4)  Four (4) percent of basic annual salary after twenty (20) years of continuous service. 
(5)  Five (5) percent of basic annual salary after twenty-five (25) years of continuous service. 
The maximum longevity payment under this schedule shall not exceed three thousand five hundred dollars ($3,500.00). 
(b)  Social security, retirement, federal and state withholding and other required deductions will be made. 
(c)  Leave without pay for a duration of one (1) month or more during the fiscal year in which an employee qualified for longevity payments shall be considered in computing the amount of longevity payment. Deductions at the rate of one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the annual gross longevity payment will be made for each month of continuous leave without pay. 
(d)  Employees who retire under normal or disability retirement programs of the city or who expire during any year in which longevity payments shall be made under this section shall receive a pro rata longevity payment for that year based on the number of full months of employment. 
(Code 1959, § 2-51.1; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 95-34, 6-6-95; Ord. No. 97-27, § 11, 6-17-97; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-247. - Repayment of travel advance. 
No later than ten (10) working days after returning from an authorized trip for which a travel advance was issued, employees are required to complete and submit to the finance department a travel reimbursement form and reimburse the city in full any unused portion of the travel advance. Failure to do so may result in the total amount owed the city being deducted from the employee's next scheduled paycheck and/or disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. In the event of dismissal, the amount owed the city will be deducted from the employee's terminal pay. 
(Ord. No. 04-62, § 1, 11-16-2004; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Secs. 2-2482-259. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - LEAVE PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 2-260. - General policy. 
It is the policy of the city to provide proportionally equivalent amounts of vacation leave, sick leave and holiday leave to employees having workweeks of different length. Consistent with this policy, employees having workweeks of different lengths shall earn different amounts of leave on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 1, 7-18-72)  
Sec. 2-261. - Basic calculations of sick and vacation leave. 
For the purpose of calculating earned vacation and/or sick leave, the basic workweek shall be forty (40) hours per week and eight (8) hours per day. An employee working the basic workweek shall earn vacation and sick leave at the rate of 3.70 hours per pay period. Vacation based on years of service is as follows: 
Years of Service 	Bi-Weekly 
Hours Earned 	Maximum Annual Accrual 
(Based on 26 pay periods) 
Less than 10 years 	3.70 	 96 hours 
10 or more years 	4.62 	120 hours 
14 or more years 	5.54 	144 hours 
18 or more years 	6.47 	168 hours 
22 or more years 	7.39 	192 hours 
 
  
Fire fighters with a basic work week of fifty-six (56) hours a week will accrue sick leave at the rate of 5.54 hours per pay period. Vacation based on years of service is as follows: 
Years of Service 	Bi-Weekly 
Hours Earned 	Maximum Annual Accrual
