(Based on 26 pay periods) 
Less than 10 years 	5.54 	144 hours 
10 or more years 	6.46 	168 hours 
14 or more years 	7.39 	192 hours 
18 or more years 	9.23 	240 hours 
22 or more years 	10.15 	264 hours 
 
  
(Ord. No. 72-59, §§ 1, 2, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-63, § 1, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 96-6, § 1, 3-5-96; Ord. No. 03-40, § 2, 11-18-2003; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-262. - Calculation for employees on other than basic workweek. 
Vacation and/or sick leave earned by employees having a workweek with greater or fewer hours than the basic workweek shall be determined in accordance with the following formula: 
(1)  The average number of hours worked per week by such employee shall be divided by the number of hours in the basic workweek. 
(2)  The proportion obtained in step (1) shall be multiplied by the number of hours of leave earned annually by employees working the basic workweek. 
(3)  The number of hours obtained in step (2) shall be divided by the workdays and, after rounding to the nearest day, shall be the amount of leave earned annually by the employees concerned. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, §§ 1, 2, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-63, § 2, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 96-6, § 2, 3-5-96; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-263. - Basic accrual. 
Employees shall earn one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of the annual vacation leave to which they are entitled for each month worked. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 1, 7-18-72)  
Sec. 2-264. - Vacation leaveAccumulation. 
(a)  All employees shall be permitted to accrue vacation leave in excess of their established maximum accrual limit during the fiscal year as provided for in section 2-261. 
(b)  In the event that an employee's unused vacation balance exceeds said employee's maximum accrual limit as of July 1, all hours in excess of this amount will be added to the employee's sick leave balance. 
(c)  In the event that an employee submits a notice of retirement or is terminated from employment for any reason and such employee's vacation balance exceeds his/her maximum accrual limit, said employee shall only be paid for the number of hours equal to the employee's maximum accrual limit based on years of service. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 1, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 03-40, § 3, 11-18-2003; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-265. - Vacation leaveManner of taking. 
Employees shall be granted the use of earned vacation leave upon request and at those times designated by their supervisor which will least obstruct normal operations of the department except in extenuating circumstances or where the employee has a commitment arranged prior to his or her acceptance of employment of which the hiring supervisor has been notified. Final scheduling of vacation for all employees shall be at the discretion of the department head. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 1, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-266. - Vacation leaveTerminal pay. 
(a)  An employee leaving the city service voluntarily or involuntarily shall receive compensation for accumulated vacation and holiday leave in accordance with subsection 2-264(c) Vacation leaveAccumulation. In the event of voluntarily termination of service, the employee may work a notice provided it is in the best interest of the city for the employee to do so. The city manager may make the resignation effective immediately without further compensation except for payment of accrued vacation and holiday leave. 
(b)  An employee who is involuntarily separated or dismissed shall be paid for vacation and holiday leave accumulated to the date of separation in accordance with subsection 2-325(c) Vacation leaveAccumulation. Payment shall be made to the employee no later than the next scheduled payday. 
(Code 1959, § 2-46; Ord. No. 756, § 1, 1-21-75; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 03-40, § 4, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-267. - Vacation leaveDeath payment. 
Upon the death of an employee, compensation for accumulated vacation leave, if any, shall be paid to his estate in accordance with subsection 2-325(c) Vacation leaveAccumulation. 
(Code 1959, § 2-46; Ord. No. 75-6, § 1, 1-21-75; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-268. - Sick, medical leaveGenerally. 
(a)  Sick leave is a benefit granted to an employee on account of personal sickness, bodily injury, quarantine, and exposure to a contagious disease when continuing to work might jeopardize the health of others. 
(b)  Sick leave may be granted to an employee on account of illness for the employee's immediate family which requires the care for or by the employee, or the funeral of a member of the employee's immediate family. "Immediate family" for the purpose of this section is defined as wife, husband, mother, father, brother, sister, son, daughter, mother-in-law, father-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law, grandmother, grandfather, granddaughter, grandson, stepmother, stepfather. 
(c)  Sick leave shall be limited to five (5) workdays (fire personnel, three (3) duty days) for funeral. 
(d)  Sick leave shall not be used when absent from work for intemperance, immorality or willful misconduct of the employee. 
(e)  Notification of the necessity to take sick leave should be submitted to the employee's supervisor (prior) to the leave or at the beginning of the scheduled reporting time. 
(f)  Claiming sick leave under false pretense shall be cause for disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. Sick leave benefits are not a right which city employees may demand but are a privilege granted by the city council to full-time employees. 
(g)  Sick leave benefits shall be at a rate equivalent to that payable if the employee were present at work. 
(h)  Medical or dental appointment. With prior approval of the department head, an employee may have up to two (2) hours off for a medical or dental appointment for the employee without charge against leave time, if it is not possible to make the appointment during regular time off. Employees shall work part of the scheduled workday to be eligible to take medical leave. Supervisors and department heads may request that an employee present a doctor certificate upon returning to work. Doctor certificates must be submitted to the occupational health nurse who will communicate to the supervisor or department head the authenticity of the certificate. Supervisors are prohibited from asking employees or requiring them to divulge the condition for which they sought medical treatment. 
(Code 1959, § 2-46; Ord. No. 756, § 1, 1-21-75; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 03-40, § 4, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-269. - Sick, medical leaveMaximum accumulation, use. 
Sick leave shall be cumulative with no limit on the maximum accumulation. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 2, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-63, § 4, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 96-6, § 4, 3-5-96)  
Sec. 2-270. - Sick, medical leaveDoctor's certificate. 
The employee's supervisor or department head may require the employee to present a certificate from the employee's treating physician to the occupational health nurse to verify the employee was under a doctor's care during the period sick leave is requested to ensure there is no abuse of sick leave privileges. The occupational health nurse will communicate the authenticity of the certificate to the employee's supervisor or department head. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 2, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-63, § 5, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-271. - Sick, medical leaveOn-job injuries. 
Employees injured on the job while employed by the city shall be compensated according to provisions set forth in the North Carolina Workers' Compensation Act. Employees retain the right to augment their workers' compensation benefit with sick, vacation, or holiday leave to that amount that, combined with their workers' compensation benefit, will equal a full sick leave benefit. 
In the event an employee is unable to perform his job and other suitable employment is available, the department head and/or human resource director may reassign such employee to another position in lieu of sick leave or receiving workers' compensation except under those circumstances where the employee's physician certifies that such employee is not capable of performing the work of such other position. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 2, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-63, § 6, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 89-6, § 1, 1-3-89; Ord. No. 96-6, § 5, 3-5-96; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 4, 12-18-2001)  
Sec. 2-272. - Sick, medical leaveCreditable service, retirement system. 
For the purposes of retirement eligibility compensation under the North Carolina Local Governmental Employee's Retirement System, an employee shall be allowed one (1) month credit for each twenty (20) days or any portion thereof for any unused sick leave. 
(Code 1959, § 2-48; Ord. No. 78-63, § 7, 10-17-78)  
Sec. 2-273. - Sick, medical leaveTermination of employment. 
All sick leave accumulated by an employee shall end and terminate when the employee resigns or is dismissed by the city. 
Upon retirement (as defined by the North Carolina Local Governmental Employee's Retirement System or North Carolina Law Enforcement Officer's Retirement and Benefit Fund) or death of any regular full-time employee who has served the city for ten (10) years or more, payment will be made to that employee or estate for accrued sick leave at the rate of one (1) month for each ten (10) years of continuous employment. Payment for fractions of a ten-year period will be based on one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of a month for each additional year of service. 
In case of voluntary or involuntary separation from city service, other than for retirement or death after ten (10) years of service, no payment will be made for accumulated sick leave. 
(Ord. No. 78-63, § 8, 10-17-78; Ord. No. 96-6, § 7, 3-5-96)  
Sec. 2-274. - Holiday leaveDesignated. 
(a)  All city employees shall receive paid holidays as established by the state personnel committee with the exception of Veterans Day which shall not be a paid holiday. 
(b)  For the purpose of calculating holiday leave, the basic workweek shall be forty (40) hours per week and eight (8) hours per day. Leave earned by employees having a workweek with greater or fewer hours than the basic workweek shall be determined based on their scheduled hours of work. 
(c)  Employees required to work on an observed holiday shall receive compensatory time off. If a holiday falls on an employee's regular day off, he will receive equal time off. All employees, with the exception of firefighters, may accrue up to 88 hours of holiday leave; firefighters may accrue up to 132 hours. 
(Ord. No. 72-59, § 3, 7-18-72; Ord. No. 78-22, § 1, 5-16-78; Ord. No. 87-49, § 1, 12-1-87; Ord. No. 88-38, § 1, 7-19-88; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-275. - Holiday leaveEffect on other leave. 
Regular holidays, scheduled days off, Saturdays or Sundays which may fall or occur during a vacation, sick or other leave period of any employee of the city shall not be considered as a day's vacation, sick or other leave. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 2-276. - Appointed employees. 
After completion of twenty-five (25) years of continuous service with the city, appointed employees, in lieu of accrual and accumulation of holiday, vacation and/or sick leave, may elect to receive periodic compensation. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, § 5, 12-18-2001)  
Sec. 2-277. - Appointed employeesLeave. 
After completion of twenty-six (26) years of continuous service with the city, appointed employees shall earn sick leave at the rate of 7.39 hours per pay period and vacation leave at the rate of 11.08 hours per pay period. 
(Ord. No. 03-40, § 6, 11-18-2003)  
Sec. 2-278. - Military leave. 
Leave for required annual training as a member of the organized military reserves shall be granted not to exceed two (2) calendar weeks in a calendar year. This period may, at the employee's option, be charged to accrued vacation leave, overtime, etc., or be taken as a leave of absence without pay. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, § 6, 12-18-2001)  
Sec. 2-279. - Military leave policy for call-up to active duty. 
(a)  General. The Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA) governs the rights of employees who temporarily leave their jobs as a result of their voluntary or involuntary service in the United States uniformed services. 
(1)  Reemployment eligibility and duration of service. Under USERRA, all employees are eligible for a military leave of absence of up to five (5) years as specified below, provided that the employee gives advance verbal or written notice of the leave except when such notice is precluded by military necessity, impossibility, or unreasonableness. This five-year period is cumulative over the course of employment and may be extended in certain situations, such as war or national emergency declared by the President or Congress. USERRA protects only employees who are honorably discharged and who return to their jobs following periods of uniformed services of no longer than five (5) years. 
(2)  Types of military leave. Uniformed services consist of the following: Army, Navy, Marine Corps, Air Force, or Coast Guard, Army Reserve, Naval Reserve, Marine Corps Reserve, Air Force Reserve, or Coast Guard Reserve, Army National Guard or Air National Guard, Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service or any other category of persons designated by the President in time of war or emergency. 
(3)  Types of service covered. Active duty, active duty in training, initial active duty for training, inactive duty training, full-time National Guard duty, absence from work for an examination to determine a person's fitness for any of the above types of duty and funeral honors duty performed by National Guard or reserve members. 
(b)  Employee's obligation to employer. The law requires all employees to provide their employer with advance notice (either written or oral) of military service unless prevented by military necessity. It may be provided by the employee or by an appropriate officer of the branch of the military in which the employee will be serving. 
(c)  Employer's obligation and effect on employee benefits. Employees who take a military leave of absence also are entitled to: 
(1)  Retain and accrue benefits based on the number of years including time spent in active military service such as longevity pay, market adjustments, and vacation/sick leave; 
(2)  Elect and pay for continued health care coverage during their absence as outlined below; and 
(3)  Participate during the leave in benefits provided through the North Carolina Local Government Retirement System. 
(d)  Employees may continue health and dental coverage for themselves and/or their families with their civilian employer while on military leave. While dependents do not have an independent right to continue coverage under USERRA, the employee has the right to continue coverage for him/herself and covered dependents. Health coverage is available through the military to all active military personnel and their families, which begins immediately upon activation. A city employee granted military leave may elect to receive insurance coverage as outlined below: 
(1)  Option one: The employee may elect to continue health and/or dental coverage through the city. The city will continue to pay the employer portion of medical and dental premiums until their return from active military leave. The employee is obligated to pay the employee portion on a monthly basis; payments are due on the first of each month. There is a thirty-day grace period for payment of premiums. Failure to remit payment in a timely manner will result in termination of coverage. The coverage provided by the military will also be in effect as of the activation date (into military service) for the employee and dependents (unless coverage is declined for dependents). 
(2)  Option two: The employee may elect to cancel health and/or dental coverage through the city as coverage is provided to all active military personnel and their families. Employees may re-enroll in the city's plans when they return to active employment status. Employees and their dependents will be reinstated with health and dental benefits immediately with no pre-existing conditions or waiting periods (waiting periods and pre-existing conditions will apply if incurred as a result of military service). 
(e)  Retirement contributions by the employer. Employees who return following a period of military service are entitled to any pension benefits that accrued prior to departure, and any additional benefits that would have accrued with reasonable certainty during the employee's absence (i.e. retirement and 401(k) employer portions). Employees cannot be treated as inactive participants and cannot be treated as having incurred a break in service as a result of their absence from employment. 
For employees who are scheduled to be absent for military service ninety (90) or fewer days, the city will make "employer" contributions to 401(k) upon their return. 
For employees who are scheduled to be absent for military service ninety-one (91) or more days, the city will postpone making retroactive 401(k) contributions until the person submits satisfactory documentation. 
Presentation of the DD-214, Report of Separation, identifying the veteran's condition of discharge will enable their months of military service to be counted toward their retirement by the North Carolina Local Government Retirement System. 
(f)  401(k) contributions by the employee. Upon return to work, the employee may make contributions to the plan in the amount equal to the contributions that would have been made if the employee has been actively employed during the period of military service. The employee may make up missed contributions over three (3) times the period of time away (i.e. if an employee is out for twelve (12) months, he would have thirty-six (36) months to pay their missed employee contributions). 
(g)  Flex plan contributions by the employee. Contributions to the city's flexible spending plan (Beneflex) may be continued during military leave if a participating employee wishes to do so, provided that the pay differential (see below) is adequate to allow such participation. Otherwise, military leave would meet the requirements of a qualifying event to allow the participant to cease contributions until return from military service. 
(h)  Pay for leave. An employee granted temporary military leave for active-duty training, inactive-duty training, or extended military leave is granted a military pay differential. 
The pay differential is the amount, if any, by which the employee's normal base pay exceeds any pay received for such military training duty for the same period, including all military pay except subsistence allowance (including "quarters allowance") and travel allowance. 
Upon return from military duty, employees submit to the human resources director a copy of their original duty orders and a certified statement of their military pay and allowances for the appropriate period. Any adjustments in salary will be reflected in a subsequent paycheck. 
(i)  Reinstatement. The city will reinstate the veteran to the position he would have held if employment had not been interrupted by military service. 
In order to be eligible for reinstatement, the returning veteran must notify the city that he intends to return to employment once military service is completed. The length of time that the veteran has to contact the employer regarding reemployment depends on the length of the service as follows: 
(1)  Service of one (1) to thirty (30) days. The employee must report back to work by the beginning of the first regularly scheduled work day that would fall eight (8) hours after the end of the last calendar day of active military service. If, due to no fault of the employee, timely reporting back to work would be impossible or unreasonable, the employee must report back to work as soon as possible. 
(2)  Service of thirty-one (31) to one hundred eighty (180) days. A request for reinstatement must be submitted no later than fourteen (14) days after completion of an employee's service. If submission of a timely request is impossible or unreasonable through no fault of the employee the request must be submitted as soon as possible. If the fourteenth day falls on a day when offices are not open, the time extends to the next business day. 
(3)  Service of one hundred eighty-one (181) or more days. A request for reinstatement must be submitted no later than ninety (90) days after completion of an employee's military service. If the ninetieth day falls on a day when the offices are not open, the time extends to the next business day. 
(4)  Disability incurred or aggravated. The "reporting back to work" deadlines are extended for up to two (2) years for employees who are hospitalized or convalescing because of a disability incurred or aggravated during the period of military service. The two-year period will be extended by the minimum time required to accommodate a circumstance beyond an employee's control that would make reporting within the two-year period impossible or unreasonable. The employee is required to notify the city within the time limits set forth above even if extensions are necessary. 
(5)  Unexcused delay. An employee's reinstatement rights are not forfeited if the employee fails to report to work or to apply for reinstatement within the required time limits, but the employee will then be subject to the employer's rules governing unexcused absences. 
(j)  Documentation upon return. The city has the right to request that an employee who is absent for a period of military service of thirty-one (31) days or more provide documentation showing that: 
(1)  The employee's application for reinstatement is timely; 
(2)  The employee has not exceeded the five-year service limitation (some exceptions apply); and/or 
(3)  The employee's separation from service was not less than "honorable". 
Presentation of the DD-214, Report of Separation, identifying the veteran's condition of discharge will be considered as proof upon return. 
(k)  Protection against discharge without cause upon return. USERRA also protects returning veterans from discharge without cause for a period of time after reemployment. For example, if the returning veteran's military service lasted between thirty-one (31) and one hundred eighty (180) days, the veteran may not be terminated without cause for one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of reemployment. If the veteran's service was more than one hundred eighty (180) days, this protection applies for one (1) year after reemployment. Employees with less than thirty-one (31) days of service do not have protection against discharge without cause, but like other returning veterans, they are protected from discrimination based on military service or a continuing service obligation. 
(l)  Accumulation of vacation/sick leave while on active duty. Employees called to active military duty will continue to accumulate vacation and sick leave while in active military service. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, § 7, 12-18-2001; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-280. - Jury duty leave. 
An employee serving on jury duty shall be entitled to leave with pay for such duty and shall be entitled to retain fees received for such duty. Law enforcement officers may not receive or keep any witness fees for appearing in a criminal court in connection with their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, § 8, 12-18-2001)  
Sec. 2-281. - Leave without pay. 
Upon the recommendation of the supervising department head and with the approval of the city manager, an employee in good standing may be granted a leave of absence without pay for a period not to exceed one (1) year for reasons of personal or family illness, completion of education, or special work which will permit the city to profit from the experience gained or the work performed. 
(Ord. No. 93-26, § 1, 8-3-93; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 9, 12-18-2001; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 2-2822-289. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - RECRUITMENT AND EMPLOYMENT 
 
Sec. 2-290. - Eligibility; residency policy. 
Individuals shall be recruited from the geographic area as wide as is necessary to assure obtaining well-qualified candidates for the various types of positions. Employment, therefore, shall not necessarily be limited to residents of the city. In cases where residents and nonresidents are equally qualified for particular vacant positions, the resident shall receive first consideration in filling such vacancies.  
Sec. 2-291. - Discrimination prohibited. 
No person in the service of the city or seeking admission thereto shall in any way be discriminated against or favored because of age, sex, race, color, national origin, religion, or disability. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 04-40, § 5, 6-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-292. - Qualification standards. 
Employees shall meet the employment standards established by the position classification plan and such other reasonable minimum standards as to character, aptitude, ability to meet the public and physical condition as may be established by the city with the advice and recommendations of the department heads.  
Sec. 2-293. - Appointments. 
(a)  It is the policy of the city to employ according to merit and fitness. To that end, it will be the policy of the city to use all available means to attract qualified candidates for employment, and to make such investigations and examinations as are deemed appropriate to assess fairly the aptitude; education and experience; knowledge and skills; character; physical fitness; and other qualities required for positions in the service of the city. 
(b)  When positions are to be filled by original appointment, department heads will notify the human resource department as to the number and class of positions which are to be filled. The human resource director shall publicize opportunities for employment with the city including the salary ranges and employment qualifications for positions to be filled. 
(c)  The human resources director will make available to the department heads for consideration applications from those applying who meet the minimum qualification on file for those positions. If selections cannot be made from the available lists of qualified applicants, the human resources director will assist department heads with recruitment of qualified applicants for appointment. 
(Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-294. - Probationary period of employment. 
(a)  All employees appointed to or promoted to full-time positions shall serve a probationary period of twenty-six (26) weeks. Law enforcement officers subject to the provisions of the regulations of the North Carolina Criminal Justice Standards Council shall serve a probationary period of fifty-two (52) weeks; however, this would not affect the city's twenty-six (26) weeks' probationary pay and benefit policy. Employees serving a probationary period following initial employment in a full-time position shall receive all benefits provided in accordance with this article, with the following exceptions or as otherwise provided: 
(1)  Employees accumulate vacation leave but shall not be permitted to take vacation leave during the initial twenty-six (26) weeks of employment. (See section 2-265) 
(2)  The employee, if dismissed during the probationary period, shall not be entitled to exercise the right to appeal the dismissal. 
(b)  Employees serving a probationary period following a promotion shall continue to receive all benefits provided in accordance with this article and under supplementary rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84)  
Sec. 2-295. - Evaluation. 
(a)  Before the end of the initial probationary period, the appointing department head shall indicate: 
(1)  That the employee has successfully completed the probationary period, is capable of performing the duties of the job satisfactorily, and is to be considered a full-time employee; or 
(2)  That the employee has not demonstrated ability to perform satisfactorily the duties of the position and is to be separated from the city service, or, if promoted from another position, the employee may be returned to the previous or a similar classification, if available, if such demotion would be in the best interest of the city service; or 
(3)  That upon recommendation of the department head and approval of the appointing authority, the probationary period may be extended for a period not to exceed twenty-six (26) weeks. 
(b)  A new appointee may be dismissed by the department head at any time during the initial probationary period, if the appointing department head determines that the employee is incapable of satisfactorily performing assigned duties or for any other reason stated in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-296. - Temporary or part-time employees. 
Temporary or part-time employees shall not be included in the provisions of this article, and each will be set up on an individual basis as to the salary, working hours, work to be performed, etc., by the human resources director. Temporary employees are not eligible for vacation, sick or holiday leave, retirement pay, etc. 
(Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-297. - Limitation of employment of relatives. 
(a)  No member of an immediate family shall be an immediate supervisor of another member of the same immediate family and no two (2) members of the same immediate family shall be hired and employed by the city or transferred within the same department where there is the possibility of a conflict of interest. Examples of the possibility of a conflict of interest shall include, but not be limited to, the indirect supervision by one such person of the other family member, or the ability of one family member to directly or indirectly influence the other family member's salary, employment or termination, promotion or demotion, and other similar terms and conditions of employment. In no event shall one member of a family either directly or indirectly attempt to influence and/or become involved in influencing another family member's salary, employment or termination, promotion or demotion and other terms and conditions of employment; and if an employee violates this provision, it shall be grounds for disciplinary action including dismissal. 
(b)  Where two (2) persons previously employed by the city become members of the same immediate family by virtue of marriage after the employment of each of them, this shall not be grounds for termination of either or both of them. Provided however, the department head of such employees shall make every reasonable effort to transfer one (1) of the persons to a similar job classification within another department. If this cannot be done, the department shall make every effort to insure that said persons work as separately as possible within said department and shall attempt to place them on different shifts if said department works on different shifts, provided however, in no event shall either of any such employees directly supervise the other member of the same immediate family. 
(c)  "Immediate family" is defined for the purpose of this section as wife, husband, mother, father, brother, sister, son, daughter, mother-in-law, father-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandmother, grandfather, granddaughter, grandson, stepmother, and stepfather. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 89-32, § 1, 6-6-89)  
Secs. 2-2982-309. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - PROMOTIONS, DEMOTIONS, TRANSFERS 
 
Sec. 2-310. - Promotion. 
All vacancies shall be filled as far as practicable by the promotion of employees in the service of the city. When a vacancy occurs, the department head or his designee will examine the qualifications of all employees who apply for the position. If there are not qualified employees, the position will be filled by systematic recruitment. 
(Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-311. - Demotion. 
Any employee whose work performance is unsatisfactory may be demoted by the department head, provided the employee shows promise of becoming a satisfactory employee in another position. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 2-312. - Transfer. 
Any employee in the service of the city who has successfully completed the required probationary period, may be transferred to the same or similar position in a different department without being subject to a probationary period. An employee desiring to be transferred should make the request known to the human resources director. As vacancies occur in other departments to which an employee would be eligible for transfer, the employee's name will be submitted to the department head for consideration. The transferring department head and the receiving department head must approve the employee's request for transfer as well as the human resources director. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 97-27, § 2, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 2-313. - Right of appeal. 
Any employee demoted or transferred for cause may appeal the disciplinary action in accordance with the grievance procedure outlined in Division 10 of this chapter.  
Secs. 2-3142-319. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - SEPARATION, DISCIPLINARY ACTION AND REINSTATEMENT 
 
Sec. 2-320. - Types of separation. 
All separations of employees from positions in the service of the city shall be designated as one of the following types and shall be accomplished in the manner indicated: resignation, layoff, disability, death, retirement, and dismissal.  
Sec. 2-321. - Resignation. 
An employee may resign by submitting in writing the reasons for the resignation and the effective date to the department head as far in advance as possible, but a minimum of seven (7) calendar days is required. Failure to comply with this requirement may be cause for denying future employment with the city.  
Sec. 2-322. - Reinstatement with full benefits. 
An employee who leaves his employment in good standing and who is reemployed within thirty (30) calendar days may be reinstated with full benefits at the discretion of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 79-61, § 1, 12-4-79; Ord. No. 79-62, § 1, 12-4-79)  
Sec. 2-323. - Reduction in force. 
(a)  Purpose. A reduction in force may become necessary due to economic circumstances, program elimination or alternation, shortage of work or funds, or privatization of existing programs. 
(b)  ProceduresDetermination of reductions. The city manager shall specify that there is a need to reduce the workforce and will determine if there is a need to reduce overall city positions or if the reduction will be limited to specific positions. If only specific positions are involved, the city manager, after consultation with department heads, shall determine the class/classes or functional area(s) and number of positions involved. The identification of employees subjected to the workforce reduction will be based (in priority of order) on: 
(1)  Possession of appropriate or applicable certifications; 
(2)  The organization's need for the employee's services and skills; 
(3)  The quality of the employee's past performance and past conduct; and 
(4)  Seniority in the position. 
Based on the above criteria, the department head shall develop a written rationale for the proposed reductions and changes in positions and personnel and present it to the human resource director and city manager. 
(c)  Notice of requirements. Employees who are subject to the reduction in force shall be given at least thirty (30) days' written notice prior to termination. 
(d)  Privatization efforts. The city will use its best efforts to encourage the private contractor, in the event city positions are eliminated due to privatization, to hire qualified city employees whose positions have been eliminated. 
(e)  Reduction in force assistance and outplacement services. The city will take the following steps to assist employees who are subjected to the reduction in force to locate other employment within the city: 
(1)  The city will attempt to locate alternate city employment for affected employees whose past performance has met minimum performance requirements. Where possible employees whose performance is in good standing and who occupy positions that have been identified for elimination will be given preference in consideration for existing city vacancies. This will take the form of having an opportunity to interview for such vacancies, if basic qualifications are met, without competition from other potential applicants, except other employees affected by the reduction in force. Affected employees must cooperate fully with human resources and the hiring department in the placement process to continue to be considered. Pay decisions regarding transfer, demotion, and promotion will be in accordance with the city's pay plan. 
(2)  The city may provide appropriate outplacement services either internally or through an outside agency. Services could include: 
a.  Career counseling; 
b.  Resume and application preparation; 
c.  Allowances for reasonable time off for interviews and employment follow-up; 
d.  Reasonable office support and telephone access to use for the job search; and 
e.  Access to listing or referrals of other employment opportunities. 
(f)  Severance pay. Employees whose position are being eliminated under a reduction in force will be eligible for seniority-based payment if all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The employee has not refused reasonable alternative employment with the city. 
(2)  The employee has not refused reasonable employment offers with a contractor (in the event of privatization). A reasonable employment offer shall be defined as one in which the employment offer does not result in a permanent reduction in the rate of pay of more than twenty (20) percent. 
(3)  The employee has not or is ineligible to submit notice of retirement to the North Carolina Local Government Retirement System. 
(4)  All financial obligations to the city must be current or satisfied in accordance with all applicable terms. 
Severance pay will be paid in the last check of employment and will not be subject to employee or employer retirement contributions. As a result, severance pay will not be included in computing the average final compensation for retirement purposes. Any period covered by severance pay will not be counted as an active employment period for the purposes of earning retirement service credit or for qualifying for employer-paid insurance coverage. Severance pay is based on total years of service with the City of Burlington; however, affected employees will not receive credit for any evaluation period that their performance was rated at "needs improvement." 
Less than 1 year 	2 weeks base pay equivalent 
1 but less than 5 years 	4 weeks base pay equivalent 
5 but less than 10 years 	6 weeks base pay equivalent 
10 but less than 15 years 	8 weeks base pay equivalent 
15 but less than 20 years 	10 weeks base pay equivalent 
20 years or more 	12 weeks base pay equivalent 
 
  
(g)  Benefits. Employees who receive severance pay shall be eligible for continuation of insurance coverage under the Consolidated Omnibus Reconciliation Act of 1985 (COBRA) as amended, at the employee's expense. The city's portion of employee health insurance shall be paid for the corresponding number of weeks for which the employee received severance pay. Employees who retire with full or early retirement may be eligible for retiree health benefits as provided by the City of Burlington. Tuition reimbursement for courses previously submitted and approved will be honored by the city upon submission of proper documentation required by the tuition reimbursement policy. Affected employees may continue to use access services offered through the Employee Assistance and Counseling Program for up to one (1) year after termination. No other benefits will apply after termination of employment. 
(h)  Reinstatement. An employee who has been subjected to a reduction of force may be considered for internal job listings for a period of two (2) years. However, an employee who has elected to receive severance pay will not be eligible for re-employment with the City of Burlington for the number of weeks calculated in the severance payout unless repayment is made in advance of re-employment for any severance payout received in excess of the period of actual separation from the city. Employees who apply and are rehired within two (2) years shall have their sick accrual balance reinstated. 
(i)  Supplemental measures and changes to policy. This policy can be amended or revoked without notice to employees. Also, in order to possibly prevent or minimize the impact of a reduction in force, the city manager, at his/her discretion, may implement creative measures such as reducing work schedules, temporary reassignment of employees, or other such measures as deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 03-40, § 7, 11-18-2003)  
Sec. 2-324. - Disability. 
An employee may be separated for disability when the required duties cannot be performed because of a physical or mental impairment. Action may be initiated by the employee or the city, but in all cases, it must be approved by medical evidence acceptable to the city manager. The city may require an examination at its expense and performed by a physician of its choice.  
Sec. 2-325. - Death. 
Separation shall be effective as of the date of death. All compensation due in accordance with this article shall be paid to the estate of the employee.  
Sec. 2-326. - RetirementGenerally. 
(a)  Whenever any employee meets the conditions set forth under the provisions of the North Carolina Local Government Employees' Retirement System, the employee may elect to retire and receive all benefits earned under the retirement plan and all compensation due under this article. 
(b)  Any employee may qualify for retirement credits as provided by the North Carolina Local Government Employees' Retirement System for withdrawn service, out-of-state service, educational leave, temporary local and state service, workers' compensation leave, part-time local and state service, other service with a local government employer, service with the federal government, public community service, omitted service, service as a member of the general assembly and local probationary or waiting period service. It is provided, however, that an appointed employee who has thirty (30) years of actual service with the city and in the North Carolina Local Government Retirement System who was not eligible when initially employed to join the Local Governmental Employees' Retirement System because of a mandatory waiting period and thereby not eligible except upon completion of six (6) months of employment is hereby granted leave not to exceed any such outstanding waiting period using a multiplier of .015625 times annual hours for each year of actual service with the city which may be designated and used by said appointed employee may determine and/or otherwise permit such appointed employee to qualify for retirement credits that may have been earned had the appointed employee been eligible to participate in the North Carolina Local Government Employees' Retirement System when initially employed. 
(Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 04-40, § 6, 6-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-327. - Mandatory retirement. 
Employees may be eligible to continue employment with the city as long as they maintain acceptable job performance and can satisfactorily perform all the requirements of their position. 
(Ord. No. 78-90, § 1, 12-5-78; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-328. - Disciplinary actionsGenerally. 
(a)  An employee may be warned, placed on probation, demoted, transferred, suspended, placed on leave without pay, or dismissed. The degree and kind of action to be taken will be based upon the sound and considered judgment of the appropriate authority in accordance with the provisions of this policy. 
(b)  The causes for suspension or dismissal fall into two (2) categories: (1) causes relating to performance of duties; (2) causes relating to personal conduct detrimental to city service. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-329. - Disciplinary actionsPerformance of duties. 
(1)  Unsatisfactory performance of duties. The following are examples of unsatisfactory performance of duties but are in no way intended to be all inclusive: 
(a)  Inefficiency or incompetency in the performance of duties. 
(b)  Negligence in the performance of duties. 
(c)  Physical or mental incapability for performing duties. 
(d)  Careless, negligent, or improper use of city property or equipment. 
(e)  Failure to maintain satisfactory and harmonious working relationships with the public and employees. 
(f)  Absence without approved leave. 
(g)  Improper use of sick leave privileges. 
(h)  Failure to report for duty at the assigned time and place. 
(i)  Violation of departmental regulations regarding performance of duties. 
(j)  Failure to obtain or maintain a valid license or certificate required by law as a condition for performing the job. 
(k)  Failure to comply with established city occupational safety policies and guidelines. 
(2)  Warnings prior to dismissal. Employees who are dismissed for unsatisfactory performance of duties should normally receive at least two (2) warnings as follows: 
(a)  One (1) or more oral warnings with documentation which set forth the points covered in the discussion; 
(b)  A written warning which will serve notice upon the employee that continuation of the unacceptable practices may result in disciplinary action or dismissal. 
(The two (2) warnings may relate to the same cause or to separate and different causes.) 
(3)  Oral warning with documentation. The supervisor is responsible for maintaining the proper conduct and discipline of employees under his supervision. When some action is necessary, the supervisor will talk privately with the employee and perform the following: 
(a)  Review with the employee exactly what is expected of him and why. 
(b)  Explain to the employee that this is the oral warning, that he has not met the requirements, and why his conduct has been unacceptable. 
(c)  Will allow the employee to give the reasons for his actions or failure orally or in writing. 
(d)  Make suggestions for corrections. 
(e)  Record the date of the interview and other necessary information for any future use. 
(f)  Review with the division or department head the contents of the information prior to delivery to the employee and human resources department. 
(4)  Written warning. Before issuing the final written warning, the division or department head and the supervisor must review the contents of the letter with the human resources director which will include a notice to the employee that a continuation of the practice may result in dismissal. 
(5)  Dismissal. Before an employee is dismissed because of unsatisfactory performance of duties, the following shall occur: 
(a)  A written summary of the case will be prepared by the supervisor and reviewed by the division or department head and personnel. A copy of the notice will be placed in the employee's file. 
(b)  Incidents involving gross negligence or carelessness will constitute grounds for immediate severe disciplinary action up to and including dismissal without warning. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27. § 2, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 03-40, § 8, 11-18-2003; Ord. No. 05-30, 6-21-2005)  
Sec. 2-330. - Disciplinary actionsFailure in personal conduct. 
The following are examples of unsatisfactory personal conduct but are in no way intended to be all inclusive: 
(a)  Conviction or commission of a crime involving moral turpitude, or a crime which adversely reflects upon ability to perform assigned duties. 
(b)  Willful misuse of city funds. 
(c)  Willfully falsifying job information to secure position. 
(d)  Participation in any action that would in any way seriously disrupt or disturb the normal operation of the division, department or any other segment of municipal government. 
(e)  Willful damage or destruction of city property. 
(f)  Willful acts that would endanger the lives or property of others. 
(g)  Possession of unauthorized firearms or dangerous weapons on the job. 
(h)  Brutality in the performance of duties. 
(i)  Refusal to accept a reasonable and proper assignment from an authorized supervisor ("insubordination"). 
(j)  Reporting to work under the influence of alcohol or illegal use of drugs, or with the odor of alcohol, where such would adversely reflect upon ability to perform assigned duties, or possession of or partaking of such things on the job. 
(k)  Betrayal of information from official records that are allowed by law to be confidential. 
(l)  Misconduct on or off the job which adversely reflects on the city and the employee's ability to perform his job. 
(m)  Three (3) consecutive unexcused absences from work. 
An employee may be dismissed or suspended without warning for causes relating to personal conduct detrimental to city service in order to avoid undue disruption of work or to protect the safety of persons or property or for other serious reasons. In less serious or disruptive situations, steps similar to those listed under section 2-329, Performance of duties, may be in order. When an employee is suspended or dismissed immediately, the following steps will be taken by the supervisor. 
The employee shall be requested to leave city property at once and either report back to the supervisor or human resources department the following day or remain away until further notice. If an immediate dismissal is made, all facts leading to the dismissal must be clearly understood by the supervisor and the division or department head and a written summary shall be prepared giving the circumstances and facts which led to the decision for dismissal and copy filed in the employee's personnel folder. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 97-27 § 2, 6-17-97; Ord. No. 2001-38, § 12, 12-18-2001)  
Sec. 2-331. - Disciplinary probation. 
(a)  An employee may be placed on probation for failure in performance of duties or personal conduct not to exceed twelve (12) months. An employee placed on probation shall be told in writing why he is on probation, the length of time, and corrective action to be taken. An employee on probation may not be considered for promotion or merit increase. 
(b)  An employee on probation may be dismissed without recourse for further violation. At the end of the probationary period the supervisor shall indicate that corrective action has taken place. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84)  
Sec. 2-332. - Suspension. 
(a)  An employee may be suspended because of problems arising as a result of performance of duties or personal conduct. Suspension may be used as a form of discipline or as an alternative to dismissal. An employee who is suspended shall be relieved of all duties and responsibilities and shall leave city property at once. 
(b)  An employee who fails to report back at the expiration of his suspension will be considered to have quit his employment. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84)  
Sec. 2-333. - Employee appeal. 
A full-time employee wishing appeal concerning a suspension or dismissal may present the matter to the city manager in accordance with provisions of the grievance procedure that is prescribed in sections 2-411 through 2-430. 
(Ord. No. 84-73, § 1, 9-18-84)  
Secs. 2-3342-339. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 2-340. - Purpose. 
The provisions of this division are enacted for the following purposes: 
(a)  To provide employees a procedure by which their complaints can be considered rapidly, fairly, and without reprisal. 
(b)  To encourage employees to express themselves about the conditions of work which affect them as employees. 
(c)  To promote better understanding of policies, practices, and procedures that affect employees. 
(d)  To instill in employees confidence that personnel actions are taken in accordance with established, fair, and uniform policies and procedures. 
(e)  To develop in supervisors a greater sense of responsibility in dealings with employees.  
Sec. 2-341. - Definition. 
A grievance is a claim or complaint based upon an event or condition which affects the circumstances under which an employee works allegedly caused by misinterpretation, unfair application, or lack of established policy pertaining to employment conditions. A grievance might involve alleged safety or health hazards, unsatisfactory physical facilities, surroundings, materials or equipment, unfair or discriminatory supervisory or disciplinary practice, unjust treatment by fellow workers, unreasonable work quotas, or any other grievance relating to conditions of employment.  
Sec. 2-342. - Policy. 
It is the policy of the city to provide a means whereby employees may freely discuss problems with supervisors and to provide a procedure for the presentation and mutual adjustment of points of disagreement that arise between employees and their supervisors. 
Employees terminated for unsatisfactory performance during their probationary period are ineligible to use this grievance policy. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-343. - Procedure. 
An employee who believes inequitable treatment has occurred because of some condition of employment may personally request relief from that condition. The following successive steps are to be taken unless otherwise provided. The number of days indicated for each step should be considered the maximum, unless otherwise provided. Every effort should be made to expedite the process. The time limits at any step may be extended by mutual consent or due to unusual circumstances beyond the reasonable control of either party. All employees consulted during a grievance procedure are required to cooperate to the fullest extent possible. The city manager shall be the final authority in all grievance matters. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-344. - Informal grievance procedure. 
Employees are encouraged to resolve a grievance in an informal manner by discussing the concern with their immediate supervisor. Either the employee or supervisor may involve the respective department head and human resources director if desired. Use of the informal grievance process does not preclude an employee from enacting the formal grievance process. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-345. - Formal grievance procedure. 
To be considered a formal grievance, the issue must be filed in writing within the time frame outlined as set out in subsection (a) of this section and must include a full explanation of the basis on which the complaint is based. Included in this statement should be all information upon which the grievance is based and an explanation of the result(s) the employee is seeking by filing a grievance. 
(a)  Step 1. An employee wishing to initiate the formal grievance process shall present the grievance in writing to the appropriate supervisor within twelve (12) working days of the event or learning of the event or condition. Upon receiving the written grievance, the supervisor will meet with the employee to discuss the grievance and shall respond to the employee, in writing, within twelve (12) days after receipt of the grievance. The response shall be signed by the supervisor and employee. Copies of the grievance and supervisor's response shall be forwarded to the human resources director. 
(b)  Step 2. If the grievance is not resolved to the satisfaction of the employee by the supervisor, the employee may appeal, in writing, to the appropriate department head within twelve (12) working days after receipt of the supervisor response in Step 1 or (a) above. The department head shall meet with the employee and immediate supervisor and respond to the employee grievance, in writing, within twelve (12) days of receiving the written employee appeal. Such response shall be signed by the employee and the department head to acknowledge receipt. The department head shall send copies of the grievance and response to the human resources director. 
(c)  Step 3. If the grievance is not resolved to the satisfaction of the employee at the end of Step 2 or (b) above, the employee may appeal, in writing, to the city manager within twelve (12) days after receiving the written response from the department head in Step 2 or (b) above. 
(d)  The city manager will acknowledge receipt of the employee's appeal within twelve (12) days of receiving the appeal. In making a final decision, the city manager may conduct any investigation deemed necessary, or, appoint a grievance board to consider the grievance and suggest action, and may also request that the city council establish or revise city policy so that an equitable adjustment of the grievance can be made. The city manager shall make a decision in writing and such decision shall be final with no appeal therefrom. The city manager shall notify the department head of the final decision prior to submitting it to the employee. A copy of the city manager's written response shall be given to the employee and sent to the human resources director for placement in the employee's personnel file. 
(e)  Should the grievance be the result of an adverse disciplinary action taken against an employee, the employee is required to adhere to procedures outlined in Steps 1 or (a) above and 2 above or (b) above. If an employee desires to appeal the personnel action to the city manager and request a grievance hearing, an employee's request to appeal must be received, in writing, by the department head within 48 hours of delivering the written ruling to the employee. The notice shall be promptly transmitted to the office of the city manager by the department head along with the complete record of the proceedings involved, including any written documents, investigative reports, recommendations and prior conduct considered by the department head in his/her action. 
(f)  The city manager, or his/her designee, will have twelve (12) days from receiving written notification from an employee requesting a hearing to schedule a time and place to hear the appeal and shall notify the department head of such. The hearing shall be scheduled as expeditiously as possible. Prior to the hearing, the affected employee shall be provided with a copy or summary of the complaints against him/her and with documentation and supporting investigative conclusions reached. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-346. - Grievance hearing. 
(a)  The grievance hearing shall be conducted by the city attorney. The city manager shall act as the decision-making authority. The city manager may conduct any such investigations deemed necessary or desirable. Procedurally, the city attorney shall present a summary of the proceedings, the contents of any investigative reports, and the disciplinary action imposed by the department head. This information may be presented by submission of documentation and/or direct testimony of the department head or other parties, including the human resources director. The employee, or his/her representative, will be allowed to make a final statement to the city manager. 
(b)  After hearing all parties, the city manager may elect to further investigate the incident or may conclude the hearing based on the record established. If further investigation is ordered, the hearing will be reconvened at the direction of the city manager to consider any additional facts prior to making a final decision. 
(c)  Upon closing the hearing, the city manager shall, within 48 hours, render a decision in the matter which shall be final and not subject to appeal and shall immediately communicate the decision to the employee and/or his/her representative. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 2-3472-354. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 11. - EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY AND AFFIRMATIVE ACTION 
 
Sec. 2-355. - Statement of policy. 
The purpose of this division shall be to establish the city's policy regarding equal employment opportunity and shall apply to all segments of the city government. 
It shall be the continuing policy of the city that there shall be no discrimination in the treatment of minority group job applicants or employees in the application of any city policy, practice, rule or regulation. Efforts to achieve and maintain a city work force that is appropriately balanced by race and sex shall be limited only by the vacancies that occur as a result of turnover and expansion, and by the availability of minorities and women with required skills. All applicants and employees, regardless of race, creed, national origin, sex, age, religion, or handicap, shall be treated on the same basis with respect to employment, performance evaluation, merit consideration, promotion, training opportunities and all other city activities. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-356. - Implementation of policy. 
(a)  All personnel responsible for recruiting and employment will continue to review regularly, the implementation of this personnel policy and relevant practices to assure that equal employment opportunity is being actively observed to the end that no employee or applicant for employment shall suffer discrimination because of age, sex, race, color, national origin, religion, or disability. 
(b)  The human resources director shall prepare and maintain a personnel policy manual which shall supplement and set forth guidelines for the implementation of the personnel code and other personnel policies. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 04-40, § 7, 6-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-357. - Affirmative actionDefined. 
For the purpose of this division, affirmative action shall be defined as a set of program objectives designed to increase the utilization of minorities and women at all levels and all segments of the city's work force. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-358. - Affirmative actionEqual employment opportunity coordinatorDesignated; general duties. 
The coordinator for the city in matters pertaining to equal employment opportunity shall be the city manager or the human resources director. His or her duties will be to coordinate the efforts of all segments of the city government. He or she shall provide reports concerning the state of progress, with recommendations where appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 04-40, § 8, 6-3-2004)  
Sec. 2-359. - Affirmative actionAdministration of program. 
Administration of this program shall be the responsibility of the city manager, or a designate, as the city's equal employment opportunity coordinator. He or she and the staff are responsible for: 
(a)  Implementing policy, affirmative action programs and internal and external communication techniques. 
(b)  Assisting department heads in arriving at solutions to problems. 
(c)  Periodically auditing hiring and promotion patterns to insure that goals and objectives are being diligently pursued. 
(d)  Assisting in the identification of problem areas. 
(e)  Conducting regular discussions with department heads, supervisors, and employees to insure that city policy is being followed and to monitor effectiveness of city programs, to indicate the need for remedial action and to determine the degree to which goals and objectives have been attained. 
(f)  Keeping management informed of the latest developments in the entire equal employment opportunity area. 
(g)  Serving as liaison between the city and enforcement agencies, minority organizations and community action groups. 
(h)  Making layoffs, terminations, downgradings, recalls from layoffs, training, promotions, upgrading, paying, classifying, and transferring employees without regard to race, creed, national origin, sex, age, religion, or handicap; providing equal opportunity for overtime compensation or other increased earnings; and continuing to insure that there is no disparity in the compensation received by minorities and women for performing equivalent work. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-360. - Recruitment. 
The city shall seek qualified minority group applicants and females for all job categories and shall make particular efforts to increase minority group representation in occupations at the higher levels of skill and responsibility. Decisions on employment shall be based solely upon an individual's qualifications for the position being filled. 
To increase the flow of minority and female applicants, the following policy shall be pursued: 
(a)  Contacts with organizations representing minority and female applicants. 
(b)  Schools attended by substantial numbers of minority and female group members will be contacted for job referral. 
(c)  Minority employees shall be actively encouraged to refer applicants. 
(d)  A copy of the city's policy shall be available to each employee. Communication media, including bulletin boards and orientation of new employees shall emphasize this subject. All management personnel and any others involved in administering this policy including those engaged in recruitment, employment, training, and other personnel activities, shall be aware of the policy and of their responsibility with respect to it. 
(e)  All external recruitment sources shall be informed of the city's policy, stipulating that such sources actively recruit and refer minorities for positions listed. The city will include equal opportunity clauses in all appropriate external documents. The city will endeavor to publicize its program in various news media and will include the phrase "Equal Opportunity Employer" on application forms and in advertisements for employment. 
(f)  Supervisors shall be directed to contact the equal employment opportunity coordinator for advice and counsel to ensure that all employees are given proper consideration for promotions, upgradings, transfers and other personnel actions. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-361. - Applications for employment. 
All persons expressing interest in employment with the city shall be given the opportunity to file an application for employment. 
Applicants shall be appropriately informed of job openings. Applications of all job applicants shall be kept in a reserve file for a period of three (3) years in accordance with equal employment commission guidelines. To the extent that it is practical, reference to these files shall be made periodically in connection with the city employment requirements. This program is designed to insure that equal consideration is given to all applicants. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-362. - Qualifications and testing. 
(a)  The city's policy includes the responsibility for ensuring that hiring qualifications for both entry level and promotional level jobs are fair and shall continue to be fairly administered. Qualifications shall be reviewed periodically to assure that requirements conform to the actual job performance requirements and to changing situations. The city reserves the right to be responsible to perform its services and functions effectively and efficiently. 
(b)  In keeping with both these responsibilities, the city will make every effort to hire minority and female group applicants who may not be fully qualified for a particular job, provided that the deficiency is such that it can be eliminated through orientation and on-the-job training. 
(c)  Tests administered by the city or by the state employment security commission for the city shall be only those that will measure the skills actually required for the job. Tests shall conform to applicable legal regulations and shall be appropriately validated. 
(d)  All tests given to applicants shall be administered and evaluated by qualified employees, or by employment security commission personnel, who shall be fully acquainted with the city's policy as to equal employment opportunity. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80)  
Sec. 2-363. - Compensation. 
The policy of the city is to pay compensation which is competitive with local rates for the work performed so that compensation does not create a barrier to recruitment. Opportunities for performing overtime work or otherwise increasing compensation will be afforded to all qualified employees without discrimination based on age, sex, race, color, national origin, religion or disability. It is the policy of the city to pay all employees in accordance with job classification, experience and ability. 
(Ord. No. 80-53, § 2, 9-2-80; Ord. No. 04-40, § 9, 6-3-2004)  
Secs. 2-3642-400. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - ETHICS AND CONFLICTS OF INTEREST, CITY OFFICIALS, EMPLOYEES AND BOARD/COMMISSION MEMBERS 
 
Sec. 2-401. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and phrases are defined as hereinafter set forth. 
Conflict of interest. A situation in which the concerns, aims, or goals of an individual or a member of his family are incompatible with those of the city or a situation in which an individual or a family member is in a position to possibly derive a personal financial benefit from actions or decisions made in their capacity as an official, employee, or member of a board or commission. The following situations are deemed to be included within the term "conflict of interest": 
(1)  An appointed official, employee, or member of a board or commission of the city or a family member of any of the foregoing is a party to a contract or involved in a transaction with the City of Burlington for goods or services. 
(2)  An appointed official, employee, member of a board or commission of the city, or a family member of any of the foregoing has a material financial interest in a transaction between the City of Burlington and an entity in which the appointed official, employee, member of board or commission or a family member of any of the foregoing is an officer, agent, partner, member, associate, employee, trustee, personal representative, receiver, guardian, custodian, significant shareholder or other legal representative. 
(3)  An appointed official, employee, member of a board or commission of the city, or a family member of any of the foregoing is engaged in some capacity or has a material financial interest in a business or enterprise, public or private, that competes with the City of Burlington or which may have a material interests which conflict the interests of the city. 
(4)  An appointed official, employee, member of a board or commission of the city, or a family member of any of the foregoing, discusses possible future employment with a person, firm, or any other business entity that is dealing with, or may be reasonably expected to deal with the city concerning matters within the individual's official duties or areas of responsibility. 
(5)  Any other factual situation which may be reasonably perceived to fall within the definition of "conflict of interest" as set forth above. 
A Contract or transaction is any agreement or relationship involving the sale or purchase of goods or services, the providing or receipt of a loan or grant, the establishment of any other type of financial relationship, or the exercise of control over another organization. The making of a gift to the City of Burlington is not a contract or transaction. 
Family member as used herein is a spouse, parent, child, brother, sister, or the spouse of one of the foregoing. 
An interested person is any person serving as an appointed official of the City of Burlington, an employee of the City of Burlington, or a member of a board or commission of the City of Burlington and who has a personal interest in a transaction which creates a conflict of interest as defined in this article. 
Material financial interest in an entity is a financial interest of any kind, which in view of all the circumstances, is substantial enough that it would, or reasonably could, affect an interested person's or family member's judgment with respect to transactions to which the entity is a party. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-402. - Disclosure of conflict of interest. 
(a)  Appointed officials of the city shall disclose any conflicts of interest that they or a family member may have and which do not involve council action to the mayor who shall cause a record of such report to be filed with the city clerk. If the conflict of interest involves a matter before the city council, such conflict shall be reported to the city council at the council meeting in which such matter is being considered or acted upon and shall be recorded the minutes of the meeting. 
(b)  Employees of the city shall disclose any conflict of interest that they or a family member may have to their department head who shall transmit such information to the city manager. In the case of a department head, he or she shall report a conflict of interest to the city manager directly. 
(c)  Members of boards and commissions shall report in open meeting conflicts of interest that they or a family member may have to the board or commission at the meeting in which said matter is being considered or acted upon. The secretary to the board or commission shall record such conflict in the minutes of the meeting and shall provide the same to the city manager. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-403. - Failure to disclose; violations. 
It shall be a violation of this articlefor any covered individual to fail to make a disclosure of a conflict of interest when such disclosure is required or could be reasonably deemed to be required. It shall also be a violation of this article to take action in contradiction of instructions given by the city council, the city manager, or a department head with respect to such conflict. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-404. - Remedies. 
In the event that reports of possible violations of this ordinance are made, such reports of violation shall be investigated as follows: 
(1)  If the allegation is against an appointed official of the city or a member of a board or commission, the inquiry shall be made by the council with the assistance of the city attorney or city manager as appropriate. The council may take such action as it deems necessary upon a finding that a violation has occurred, up to and including dismissal or removal from office. 
(2)  Allegations against employees of the city shall be treated as grievances and shall be heard before the city manager in accordance with the city grievance process. If a violation of this article is established, the city manager shall take such action as deemed appropriate, up to and including dismissal. 
(3)  Reports of possible violation may be made to the mayor, a member of council, the city manager, the city attorney, or to a department head of the city. The individual receiving said report shall have the duty to forward the report to the appropriate investigatory office as established above. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-405. - Advisory opinion; defense. 
An appointed official, member of a board or commission, or employee of the city who has a doubt as to whether he or she or a covered family member has a conflict of interest may apply in writing to the city attorney for an advisory opinion as to the existence of a conflict of interest under this article or the applicability of this article to a particular factual situation. Such request must disclose all relevant facts and relationships. The city attorney shall render his or her opinion in writing and shall provide a copy to the requesting party and a copy to the city manager. The existence of the written opinion shall not relieve any party of their duty to disclose conflicts of interest as provided in section 2-402 above. Should the opinion be that no conflict exists that would rise to a violation of this chapter, the requesting individual shall have no affirmative duty to further disclose as to the facts set forth in the request for opinion. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 2-406. - Limitations on gifts to public officials and employees. 
No official or employee of the city shall accept any valuable gift of fifty dollars ($50.00) or more, whether in the form of service, loan, thing or promise, from any person who, to their knowledge, is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the city which may tend to influence the discharge of duties, or grant any improper favor, service or thing of value in the discharge of their duties. 
(Ord No. 87-25. §1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 3 - ALARM CONTROL 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
Alarm permit . A permit issued by the police or fire department allowing the operation of an alarm system. 
Alarm signal. A detectable signal, either audible or visual, generated by an alarm system being monitored or designed to exteriorly annunciate, requiring the police or fire department to respond. 
Alarm system. Any single device or assembly of equipment designed to monitor and/or exteriorly annunciate the occurrence of an illegal entry, criminal activity or other activity requiring police response or designed to signal the detection of fire, or products of combustion, in a building, structure, or premises, or to signal an actual fire or initiate a response for medical assistance regardless of whether the call for response comes from a monitoring service, the alarm user, a neighbor, or results from a police officer or firefighter hearing the alarm system. 
Alarm systems coordinators. An employee of the police department and an employee of the fire department, each designated to administer the respective department's responsibilities under this chapter. 
Alarm user. A person, corporation, partnership, proprietorship, association, governmental or educational entity or any other entity owning or leasing an alarm system or on whose premises an alarm system is maintained for the protection of such premises. 
Automatic dial protection device. An automatic dialing device, automatic telephone dialing alarm system or any system which, upon being activated, automatically initiates, a recorded message or code signal indicating a need for police response. 
Burglar alarm. An alarm activated upon an intrusion during a break-in. 
False alarm. 
(1)  Any signal communicated by any means that solicits a response from the police or fire department to which the responding units find no evidence of fire or products of combustion or medical emergency or no evidence of unauthorized intrusion, criminal activity, or other such crime in or on premises. False alarms include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Error or mistake: Any action by any person, firm or corporation, association, or other entity or agency thereof, owning or operating any dwelling, building or place, which results in the activation of any alarm system when no emergency exists. 
b.  Malfunction: Any activation of any alarm system caused by a flaw in the normal operation, design, installation, or maintenance of the system, by faulty equipment, or by a change in the environment or premises upon, or within which, the alarm system is operating.
