c.  Intentional misuse: Any activation of an alarm system when one knows, has reason to know, or should have known no fire or other emergency is in progress. 
d.  Failure to notify alarm-monitoring service of testing: Any alarm transmitted to the police or fire department while alarm is being tested by personnel without notifying the alarm service of test results. 
(2)  An alarm will not be considered to be a false alarm if it is determined by the officer in charge that the alarm was caused by: 
a.  Natural or manmade catastrophe, or an act of God. Such events include, but are not limited to tornadoes, floods, earthquakes, or other similarly violent conditions or adverse weather conditions. 
b.  The testing of a local/audible alarm system by a licensed alarm business, agent, or employee who is present at the premises servicing, repairing or installing the alarm when the agent or user has contacted the alarm company and informed them of the test. 
c.  Activation by other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm user. 
Hold-up alarm. A manually activated alarm in response to a robbery of a business. 
Panic alarm. A manually activated alarm in response to an immediate threat such as a breaking in progress or an assault. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 1, 3-16-04; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-2. - Required for alarm users. 
(a)  An alarm user must obtain an alarm permit from the alarm systems coordinator in the police department if intended for burglary or illegal entry purposes, or the fire department if intended for fire purposes. Except as exempted herein, it shall be unlawful for any alarm user to operate an alarm system, as described in the definitions section of this article, within the corporate limits of the City of Burlington, without obtaining a permit within ten (10) business days of initial operation or within ten (10) business days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, whichever comes last. No person shall use an alarm system when the alarm permit for that system has been revoked by the alarm systems coordinator. 
(b)  The alarm user must provide complete, accurate information on the alarm permit application, including his name, the address of the premises upon which the system has been or will be installed, the mailing address, the telephone number, the type of alarm system and the business(es) selling, monitoring, inspecting, responding to, and maintaining the alarm system. The alarm user must also provide at least two (2) persons as means of contact who can respond to the location of the alarm. 
(c)  The alarm user must provide any changes from the information provided on the alarm permit application to the alarm systems coordinator within ten (10) business days of the change. 
(d)  When possession of the alarm system protected premises changes, the person obtaining possession of the property shall file an application for an alarm user permit to the alarm systems coordinator within ten (10) business days of obtaining possession of the property. Alarm permits are not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 03-12, § 2, 3-16-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-3. - Exemption. 
Single family residences are not required to be registered under the alarm permit requirements of section 3-12. 
This exemption is not applicable to other residential uses specified in the North Carolina Fire Code and Administrative Code for which fire alarms are required. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-4. - Multiple alarm systems. 
An alarm user, maintaining multiple alarm systems, whether in the same or different locations, shall be required to obtain an alarm permit for each system. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 3, 3-16-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-5. - Alarm reset feature. 
(a)  No alarm user may install, maintain, or use an audible alarm system which can sound for more than fifteen (15) minutes when activated. Burglary, illegal entry alarms must have an automatic reset feature that resets the alarm within fifteen (15) minutes. The reset feature does not apply to fire alarm systems. 
(b)  When an alarm activates continuously for a period of thirty (30) minutes from the time an officer a police officer or fire department representative initially responds to the alarm, due to the failure of the alarm user or the user's representative to reset the alarm, it shall be deemed a false alarm, and each subsequent thirty (30) sixty (60) minute period or portion thereof that the alarm continues to be activated shall be considered a separate false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 4, 3-16-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-6. - False alarms. 
(a)  Response. Whenever an alarm is activated in the city and the police or fire department does respond, an incident commander or officer on the scene of the activated alarm system shall determine whether the alarm was a false alarm as defined in the definitions section of this article. Such notification should be given to the communications center by the commander or officer responding to the alarm. 
(b)  Notification. In the case of false alarms, the incident commander will leave a written notice of the false alarm at, or attached to, the alarm system premises. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 5, 3-16-2004)  
Sec. 3-7. - Appeal of false alarm determination and charges. 
When requested in writing by the alarm user within ten (10) business days of response to a false alarm, the alarm systems coordinator in the department responding to the incident will review the basis of the incident commander's/officer's determination that an alarm was false. The written request for review of a false alarm determination by the alarm systems coordinator shall include the following information: 
(1)  Alarm user name; 
(2)  Address at which the alarm is installed; 
(3)  Date and time of the false alarm that is being contested; 
(4)  Alarm user permit number; and 
(5)  Facts to establish that the alarm was not false. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 6, 3-16-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-8. - Assessed cost recovery for false alarms. 
(a)  After the fourth or subsequent false alarm during a rolling twelve-month period, a fee shall be assessed based on the estimated cost to the city of responding. The cost recovery assessment after the fourth and any subsequent fire department responses shall be three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00). The cost recovery assessment after the fourth and any subsequent police department responses shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(b)  Each assessment must be paid within thirty (30) days of notification. If not paid when due, the city may recover the assessment in a civil action in the nature of a debt. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-9. - Penalty for failure to obtain alarm permit. 
(a)  Failure to obtain applicable alarm permit. Any person or firm who fails to register their alarm system, when registration is required, with the City of Burlington Police or Fire Department alarm systems coordinator shall be subject to a civil penalty in the nature of a debt in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(b)  No automatic dial protection device shall be used to report, or cause to be reported, any recorded message to the Burlington Police or Fire Department. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 3-10. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully cause a false fire alarm. A violation of this provision shall be a misdemeanor punishable as provided in G.S. 14-286. 
(b)  Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and the punished as provided by G.S 14-4 and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than twenty (20) days and shall be further subject to the provisions of G.S. 160A-175. 
(Ord. No. 04-12, § 8, 3-16-04)  
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES  
ARTICLE I. - PUBLIC PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Consumption on public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any malt beverage or unfortified wine in or on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public property within the city. Provided, however, it shall be lawful for any person to purchase and consume malt beverages and unfortified wine at Indian Valley Golf Course, Burlington Athletic Stadium, Paramount Theater, the Historic Depot, Willowbrook Arboretum, and the Downtown Municipal Service District with the exception of the Lexington Avenue Municipal Building and surrounding grounds and parking lot, and the Davis Street Municipal Annex Building and surrounding grounds and parking lot, provided necessary permits and approval have been secured. 
It shall be lawful to purchase and consume malt beverages or unfortified wine at Regional Park (City Park) for city sponsored events at the annual Burlington Carousel Festival and in accordance with all provisions contained in Chapter 18B of the North Carolina General Statutes and any and all regulations which have been or may be promulgated thereunder. 
Section amended by ordinance of April 2016)  
Sec. 4-2. - Sunday sales. 
The sale of malt beverages, unfortified wine, fortified wine and mixed beverages shall be allowed within Burlington-s corporate limits at any premises licensed pursuant to N.C.G.S. 18B-1001 on Sundays beginning at 10:00 a.m. 
Ord. of 9-5-17) 
State Law reference Statutory authority G.S. 160A-205.3, Session Law 2017-87.  
Secs. 4-3, 4-4. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SECURITY REQUIREMENTS FOR DESIGNATED ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 4-5. - Applicability. 
This article applies to any business or individual holding a permit for the sale of alcohol issued by the North Carolina ABC Commission and that has been designated as a high security risk by the chief of police or his designee in the manner hereinafter set forth. This article shall not be construed to affect issuance of an ABC permit. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-6. - Standard for designation. 
Any establishment within the City of Burlington which holds a permit issued by the North Carolina ABC Commission for the sale of alcoholic beverages, beer or wine, which operates after 11:00 p.m. and which has been the locus of three or more calls for police service within a ninety (90) day period with said calls involving a breach of the peace or a threatened breach of the peace, a violent crime involving the use or threatened use of a firearm or other deadly weapon, or an altercation involving physical violence or the threat thereof, or the sale of narcotics or other controlled substances may be designated as a high security risk establishment. For the purposes of this article, conduct enumerated in this section which takes place on adjacent premises or in adjacent streets or sidewalks shall be treated as having taken place within the establishment if there is a nexus between the establishment and the individuals involved in the prohibited conduct. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-7. - Notification of designation. 
At such time as the chief of police determines that the standards set forth in section 4-6 have been met as to any establishment within the city, the chief, or his designee, shall cause a notice of designation, along with a copy of the ordinance from which this article derives, to be served on the establishment and its permittee. Said notice shall list the occurrences giving rise to the designation and the dates, locations, and involved parties (if known) of same. The notice shall further state that the provisions of this part shall take effect thirty (30) days from the date of service of the notice and that the failure to fully comply shall constitute a separate violation for each day that the requirements are not met. Service of the notice may be made by personal service or by registered mail with return receipt and shall be made on the permittee, its owner or its operator. A copy shall also be posted at the affected premises. The designated permittee may appeal this action and the designation to the city council by giving written notice of such appeal to the chief of police within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice of designation. The city council shall hear this appeal de novo and may affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the chief of police. Required action shall be stayed during the pendency of said appeal. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-8. - Permittee. 
Permittee means any business or the owner or operator of such business who holds a valid permit issued by the North Carolina ABC Commission for the sale of alcohol at a business that operates after 11:00 p.m. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-9. - Exterior safety plan. 
(a)  The permittee shall develop and maintain on file for inspection by any Burlington police officer an exterior safety plan for any establishment designated under the standards of section 4-6 by this article. The exterior safety plan shall provide for: 
(1)  On site security personnel. 
(2)  Exterior surveillance/camera system. 
(3)  Exterior lighting. 
(4)  Parking as to allow access for emergency vehicles and personnel. 
(5)  Plan for patrons entering and leaving the establishment and parking lot. 
(b)  The exterior safety plan shall be implemented by the permittee between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and until all patrons have left the property of the closed permitted establishment. 
(c)  The business owner, permittee, or business employee shall promptly notify the police department via the city's 9-1-1 emergency telephone system of any illegal activity or emergency situations that are reported to or observed by the business owner, permittee, or business employee. 
(d)  Between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and until all patrons have left the property of the closed permitted establishment, the permittee shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To maintain an orderly line of persons wishing to enter the establishment; and 
(2)  to instruct persons waiting in line to enter the establishment, exiting the establishment or otherwise located outside the establishment to refrain from making loud or unnecessary noise and from otherwise disturbing the peace, quiet and good order of the community; and 
(3)  To prevent persons from congregating in front of the permitted establishment. Provided, however, that this item shall not apply to persons waiting in an orderly line to enter the establishment; and 
(4)  To pick up garbage in front of and curbside of the permitted establishment; and 
(5)  To notify the police department of any illegal activity reported to or observed by such person(s). 
(e)  If an employee or agent of the business owner or permittee is charged by the business owner or permittee with responsibility for carrying out any of the duties set forth in this article or for implementing or maintaining any part of the permittee's exterior safety plan, and the person charged with such responsibility fails to perform such responsibility, the business owner or permittee shall be deemed to have failed to adequately implement or maintain an adequate exterior safety plan. 
(f)  The permittee (any person holding a permit for sale of alcohol, who has a valid permit issued by the North Carolina ABC Commission) and operating after 11:00 p.m. and the owner of any business with such a permit) shall install security cameras specified in section 4-10 of this article. 
(g)  The permitted establishment shall have in operation between dusk and dawn "adequate exterior lighting." "Adequate exterior lighting" means lighting that: 
(1)  Is sufficient to enable the security cameras required under this article to produce easily discernible images; and 
(2)  Illuminates the front and sides of each entry and exit way used by patrons of the permitted business. 
(h)  When necessary to maintain and implement the exterior safety plan, the permitted business shall use "adequately trained security personnel" or an off-duty sworn law enforcement officer with territorial and subject matter jurisdiction. The term "adequately trained security personnel" means security personnel meeting all of the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  Each person providing security at the permitted establishment has successfully completed the Be A Responsible Seller (BARS) educational program presented by the North Carolina Alcohol Law Enforcement (ALE), and such person has provided proof of compliance with this requirement to the permittee; and 
(2)  Each person providing security at the permitted establishment has been trained by the permittee to report all incidents of illegal activity at the permitted establishment, and such person has certified in writing that such training was received; and 
(3)  Each person providing security at the permitted establishment has been trained by the permittee (i) not to exceed the establishment's legal maximum occupancy; and (ii) in the fundamentals of the permitted establishment's fire safety, emergency preparedness and emergency evacuation procedures, and such person has certified in writing that such training was received. 
(i)  The permitted establishment shall maintain on file, for a period of at least two (2) years, a record of all full-time or part-time security personnel, including documented compliance that each security personnel completed the requirements detailed in section 4-9(h)(13). Such documents shall be made available, upon request, for inspection by the Burlington Police Department. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-10. - Security cameras. 
(a)  As used in this section "permittee" means any person holding a permit for sale of alcohol and operating after 11:00 p.m. 
(b)  Any holder of an Alcoholic Beverage Control license, which permits the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages after 11:00 p.m. and whose establishment has been designated under the standards of section 4-6, shall place and maintain security cameras (technical requirements detailed below) that does monitor and record all entrances and exits of the establishment, as well as the front perimeter of the same extending to the curb line and any parking lot within the permittee's care and control. 
(c)  Technical requirements for video security system. 
(1)  The security camera(s) shall record in a minimum of 1080p high-definition resolution; and 
(2)  The security camera(s) shall be operational twenty-four (24) hours, seven (7) days a week; and 
(3)  Any recording shall be maintained for a minimum of fourteen (14) days 
(d)  All recording equipment and recordings should be stored on the permitted establishment in a locked receptacle located in a controlled access area accessible only to authorized personnel or shall otherwise be secured in a manner accessible only to authorized personnel. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-11. - Change in name or ownership. 
A change in the name or ownership of an establishment that has met the standards for designation under section 4-6 of this article, shall not release the establishment from the security requirements imposed as a result of its high security risk status. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-12. - Termination of high risk status. 
Any establishment which has been previously designated as a high risk security establishment under section 4-6 may apply to the chief of police for a termination of such status by filing with the chief an application for redetermination setting forth good and valid reasons why such status should be terminated. No such application shall be considered without a showing by the applicant that the standards for imposition of high risk status have not been present for a minimum of twelve (12) consecutive months. The chief of police may grant said application, deny the same, or approve it conditioned upon such terms as appear necessary for the preservation of the public peace. 
An applicant who has been denied may not file a subsequent application for twelve (12) months after the date of denial. If, upon filing a second application for redetermination, none of the standards for designation set forth in section 4-6 have been present for twenty-four (24) months, the application must be granted and high risk status terminated. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-13. - Penalties for violation. 
The business owner, permittee, or business employee may be fined five hundred dollars ($500.00) for violation of any section of this article. Each day's continuance of the violation shall constitute a separate violation. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 4-14. - Severability 
Severability is intended throughout and within the provisions of the ordinance. If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this ordinance is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, then the decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 5 - AMUSEMENTS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 5-1. - Bond, insurance required for rides, carnivals, circuses. 
No person shall conduct, operate, manage or sponsor any Ferris wheel, merry-go-round, amusement ride operated for hire, circus, or carnival without first filing with the city clerk a bond or certificate of liability insurance, naming the city as an additional insured, in the amount of at least one million ($1,000,000.00) indemnifying the public against damages sustained by reason of the operation of such ride or commercial amusement. Such bond or certificate of insurance shall be subject to the approval of the finance director. This section shall apply to all persons, whether or not such persons are exempted from any other provision of this Code of Ordinances. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 5-2. - Location. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or take part in any such shows or amusements or commercial attraction commonly known as a carnival within four hundred (400) feet of any residence, school, church or hospital within the corporate limits of the city. No such show, carnival, riding device or amusement shall be permitted in a residential district. 
(Code 1959, § 21-38; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 5-35-9. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - APPLICATION AND PERMIT 
 
Sec. 5-10. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or take part in any show or commercial amusement commonly known as a circus or a carnival, within the corporate limits of the city, without first obtaining a city permit for operation of the amusement, plus any other permits required by fire and or building codes adopted by the city. 
(Code 1959, § 21-32; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 5-11. - Application; fee. 
Each applicant for the permit required by this division shall complete and submit to the city clerk a notarized carnival application permit form. Information provided shall include: 
(a)  The full name and address of the applicant. If the applicant is not the owner or operator of the circus or carnival, then the full name and permanent address of such owner or operator shall also be shown. 
(b)  The location to be used for such show in a district as permitted in the Uniform Development Ordinance. 
(c)  The dates upon which such show will begin and will conclude operations. 
(d)  A description of the type of entertainment, amusements and exhibitions to be offered. 
(e)  List of the past three jurisdictions and dates where the amusement has operated. 
(f)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any city, state or federal laws, the nature of any such offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
The application shall be accompanied by the bond or certificate of liability insurance required by section 5-1. 
At the time of filing the application, a nonrefundable fee set by council shall be paid to the tax department to cover the costs of investigation of the facts stated herein. 
(Code 1959, § 21-33; Ord. No. 81-10, § 1, 2-17-81; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 5-12. - Application, investigation, action by city council and permit. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application, the city's fee, and certificate of insurance or bond, the city clerk shall submit the application to the police, fire, and inspections departments for review. Investigation by city departments shall include but not be limited to: 
(1)  Any record of criminal or civil convictions or violations by the operator, agents or employeesPolice department. 
(2)  Record of past performance in the three most recent jurisdictions where operatedPolice Department. 
(3)  On-site visit to proposed locationFire Department. 
(4)  On-site visit to proposed locationInspections department. 
(5)  Any other investigation necessary for protection of the public good, including any record of reports to the N.C. Department of Insurance. 
(b)  Written approval from the head of each reviewing department and any required permit shall be required before the clerk places the application on the city council agenda for final action. Should investigation of the applicant's record or on-site investigation reveal a problem, the appropriate department representatives shall attempt to resolve the issue with the applicant or require necessary on-site modifications. 
(c)  The clerk shall place an application that has received all department approvals on the city council agenda. 
(d)  When the council approves an application, the clerk shall certify a copy of the application approved by city council, which certified Application shall become the permit. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 5-13. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  In the event that any commercial amusement covered by this chapter shall be found by the police chief, fire chief, or chief building inspector to be conducted in an unlawful manner or in violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the city or in violation of any state or federal law or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of peace or to constitute a menace to health, safety, or general welfare of the public, the permit issued hereunder shall be immediately revoked by any one or more of the aforementioned city officials upon written notice served on the applicant or owner/operator of the amusement. 
(b)  The operator may request a hearing on the revocation to be conducted by the city manager within a reasonable time after said written notice of revocation. The city manager's review of any permits revoked shall be guided by but not limited to: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application. 
(2)  Any violation of this Code or any other ordinance of the city or violation of any state or federal law. 
(3)  Conducting such circus, carnival or in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. The hearing or review hearing for revocation of a permit issued under this division may be held at any time after written notice has been served upon the applicant or the owner or the operator of the circus, carnival. The city manager in a hearing on revocation of a permit, shall limit the scope of the review to the reasons and causes identified by the revoking official or officials. The manager shall reverse a revocation only upon a finding of (a) prejudicial procedural errors; or (b) willful or gross abuse of discretion by the revoking official or officials. 
(c)  It is further provided that the city manager's decision shall be automatically reviewed by the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting after revocation of said permit. Review by the city council shall be conducted in accordance with the guidelines set out above to be followed in a hearing conducted by the Manger. A written notice of this review hearing by the city council shall be served on the applicant or owner/operator of the circus or carnival in a reasonable time before the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. 
(d)  Any owner/operator of a carnival, circus, or other commercial amusement whose permit has been revoked as herein provided shall retain any and all rights of appeal as otherwise provided by law. 
(Code 1959, §§ 21-34, 21-36; Ord. No. 81-10, §§ 2, 4, 2-17-81; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Municipal authority to regulate domestic animals, G.S. 160A-186; municipal authority to regulate the possession or harboring of domestic animals, G.S. 160A-187; animal protection, G.S. 19A-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Purpose. 
It is the purpose of this chapter to: 
(1)  Regulate ownership and possession of animals; 
(2)  Prohibit certain acts, omissions and conditions which interfere with the health, safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the city; 
(3)  Protect the public from unvaccinated, diseased, stray, roaming, dangerous or wild animals; 
(4)  Make unlawful acts of animals that interfere with the enjoyment of property or the peace and safety of the community; 
(5)  Protect animals from abuse or conditions harmful to their well-being; 
(6)  Provide for the peace and dignity of residents; and 
(7)  Perform any other duties authorized by applicable state laws. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively set out opposite them: 
Adequate shelter: Provision of and access to shelter that is suitable for the species, age, condition, size and type of each animal; provides adequate space for each animal; is safe and protects each animal from injury, rain, sleet, snow, hail, direct sunlight, and the adverse effects of heat or cold, physical suffering, and impairment of health; is properly cleaned; enables each animal to be clean and dry, except when detrimental to the species; and for dogs and cats, provides a solid surface, resting platform, pad, floor mat or similar devices that is large enough for the animal to lie on in a normal manner and can be maintained in a sanitary manner. 
Adequate exercise or exercise: The opportunity for the animal to move sufficiently to maintain normal muscle tone and mass for the age, species, size, and condition of the animal. 
Adequate space: Sufficient space to allow each animal to (i) easily stand, sit, lie, turnabout, and make all other normal body movements in a comfortable, normal position for the animal and (ii) interact safely with other animals in the enclosure. When freedom of movement would endanger the animal, temporarily and appropriately restricting movement of the animal according to professionally accepted standards for the species is considered provision of adequate space. Inadequate space may be indicated by evidence of malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, or abnormal behavior patterns. 
Animal appeals board: A three-member board appointed by the city council consisting of at least one veterinarian to fulfill the purposes of G.S. 67-4.1 to hear any appeals from an owner that result from a determination by an animal control officer that a dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous. The appeals process and the timing thereof shall be as provided by G.S. 67-4.1 as currently written or subsequently amended. 
Animal control officer: Those persons designated by the animal services director who are responsible for discharging the duties and functions set forth in this chapter or as may be prescribed by the city council or state law or pursuant to any interlocal agreements. 
Animal Shelter: Any facility designated by the city for the purpose of sheltering any animal lawfully impounded by the animal services department. 
At large: Off the premises of the owner. 
Department.The animal services department. 
Director. Animal services director. 
Dog: Both the male and female of the domesticated canine species of animals. 
Dog, dangerous. As provided by G.S. 67-4.1 and all amendments hereafter enacted, a dangerous dog is a dog that: 
(a)  Without provocation has killed or inflicted severe injury on a person; or 
(b)  Is determined by the animal services director or the director's designee to be potentially dangerous because the dog has engaged in one or more of the behaviors listed below as potentially dangerous; 
(c)  Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting, or any dog trained for dog fighting. 
Dog, potentially dangerous: As provided by G.S. 67-4.1 and all amendments hereafter enacted, a potentially dangerous dog is a dog that the animal services director or director's designee determines to have: 
(a)  Inflicted a bite on a person that resulted in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations or required cosmetic surgery or hospitalization; or 
(b)  Killed or inflicted severe injury upon a domestic animal when not on the owner's real property; or 
(c)  Approached a person when not on the owner's property in a vicious or terrorizing manner in an apparent attitude of attack. 
Exotic or wild animal. An animal that is in one of the following categories: ordinarily confined to a zoo, ordinarily found in the wilderness in the United States or another country, a species not indigenous to the United States or North America, or one that is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm by attack or disease or significant property destruction. Examples from these categories include but are not limited to: all species of primates other than humans; all species of canids including wolf hybrids but excluding domesticated dogs; all species of felids including wild feline hybrids but excluding domesticated cats; mammals and non-venomous reptiles weighing over 50 pounds at maturity; all venomous reptiles. "Exotic or wild animals" specifically does not include: species of animals customarily kept in North Carolina as household pets, livestock, animals classified as service animals under federal regulations, fish confined in an aquarium, and birds. 
Feral means a domesticated animal that exists in an untamed state or that has returned to an untamed state generally not socialized to human contact and is no longer considered domesticated. Feral animals shall include, but not be limited to cats, dogs and hogs. 
Fowl: Birds customarily used for the production of meat or eggs including but not limited to any of the larger domestic birds specifically, chickens, ducks, geese and turkeys, collectively. 
Harboring an animal: An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered fourteen (14) days or more, unless the animal is being boarded for a fee. 
Humanely clean conditions: Minimum standards of sanitation necessary to provide humanely clean conditions for enclosures shall include periodic cleaning to remove excretions and other waste materials, dirt and trash to minimize health hazards. 
Impounded: Any animal that is received into custody by any employee of the department. 
Kennel: A use or structure intended and used for the breeding or storage of animals for sale or for the training or overnight boarding of animals. 
Livestock: All animals of a domesticated, agricultural nature, including, but not limited to, equine animals, bovine animals, porcine animals, camelid animals, caprine animals and cervid animals. 
Owner: Any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog. 
Premises: The principal residence of an owner. The word shall not include a vacant lot upon which no residence is located. 
Provocation: Any act done towards an animal that a reasonable person would expect to irritate or enrage such an animal to the extent that the animal would be likely to bite or attack, including, but not limited to, teasing, harassing, beating, torturing, injuring, or intentionally causing pain to an animal. Provocation does not include any actions on the part of an individual that pertain to reasonable efforts of self-defense or defense of others. 
Rabies suspect: Any animal believed to have rabies or bitten by an animal suspected of having been running at large. 
(Code 1959, § 3-10; Ord. No. 06-24, § 1, 6-6-06; Ord. No. 2014-35, § 1, 10-7-14; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-3. - Creation of animal services department; jurisdiction; director. 
(a)  The animal services department shall be charged with: 
(1)  Enforcing city ordinances and state laws relating to animals and the care, custody and control of animals; 
(2)  Cooperating with and assisting the county health director in enforcing laws of North Carolina with regard to animals; vaccination of dogs and cats against rabies; and to the confinement and leashing of animals; 
(3)  Investigating reported and observed cruelty or animal abuse with regard to all animals pursuant to the pertinent provisions of G.S. 14-360 and reported or observed violations of any section of this chapter. 
(b)  The department shall be supervised by the animal services director, or as this position shall be hereafter designated. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-4. - Jurisdiction; interlocal agreements. 
(a)  This chapter shall be applicable within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  No employee of the animal services department shall have the authority to enforce this chapter within any other corporate limits or jurisdictions, unless an interlocal agreement pursuant to G.S. 160A-460 et seq. is executed by the city and the municipality. Such an interlocal agreement may be entered into at any time, provided the appropriate resolution is adopted by the governing body of any such municipality agreeing that this chapter shall be enforced by the animal control officers, as defined in section 6-2, within the corporate limits of the municipality. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-5. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The director of the department shall designate employees of the department as animal control officers to enforce this chapter, including, but not limited to, apprehension and impoundment of animals found to warrant such action and issuance of civil citations. 
(b)  In the enforcement of this chapter any police officer, animal control officer, or the Director is authorized to enter into the open premises of any person to secure or take possession of an animal which the officer reasonably deems, then and there, to be in violation of this chapter. The officer may issue a notice of violation or citation to the owner or handler of said animal. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-6. - Inspections. 
Whenever it is necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of or perform any duty imposed by this chapter, or other applicable law, or whenever an animal control officer has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any violation of the provisions of this chapter or other applicable law, an animal control officer is hereby empowered to enter such property at any reasonable time and to inspect the same and perform any duty imposed upon animal control officers by this chapter or other applicable law, but only if the consent of the occupant or owner of the property is freely given or a search or inspection warrant is obtained as hereinafter provided: 
(1)  If such property be occupied, the officer shall first present proper credentials to the occupant and request entry, explaining the reasons therefor; and 
(2)  If such property be unoccupied, the officer shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the property, present proper credentials and request entry, explaining his reasons therefor; and 
(3)  If such entry is refused or cannot be obtained because the owner or other person having charge or control of the property cannot be found after due diligence, the animal control officer shall obtain a warrant to conduct a search or inspection of the property. 
(Ord. No. 75-18, § 3, 5-6-75)  
Secs. 6-76-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RESTRICTED OR PROHIBITED ANIMALS 
 
Sec. 6-11 - Keeping of livestock prohibited. 
Keeping of livestock, as defined herein, shall be prohibited within the corporate limits of the city, However, any livestock being maintained as of the date of re-adoption of this chapter shall be permitted to continue until the use is discontinued for thirty (30) days or more. Thereafter, such use shall not be allowed to resume. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-12. - Livestock running at large prohibited. 
No person, whether the owner or user of any livestock shall permit the same to run at large in the city. 
(Code 1959, § 3-2; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference The term "livestock" defined, G.S. 68-15; Allowing livestock to run at large forbidden, G.S. 68-16.  
Sec. 6-13. - Keeping of fowl prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have and keep fowl within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 73-87, § 1, 12-4-73; Ord. No. 06-24, § 2, 6-6-06)  
Sec. 6-14. - Keeping of exotic or wild animals prohibited. 
(a)  Unlawful act. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, possess or have under his or her control within the city any exotic or wild animal as defined in this chapter. 
(b)  Permits not authorized. Permits for the keeping or maintenance of exotic or wild animals are not authorized. 
(c)  Exempt purposes. 
(1)  Application. This section shall not apply to exotic or wild animals kept for the following exempt purposes: lawfully operated and located pet shops, zoological gardens, and scientific research laboratories, veterinarians harboring such animals for purposes of providing professional medical treatment, wildlife rehabilitators with proper permits, religious displays, or exhibitors licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture displaying such animals for educational purposes, provided that the animals are maintained in a manner so as to prevent escape. 
(2)  Confinement. Confinement of exotic or wild animals kept for exempt purposes must meet regulations promulgated by the state wildlife commission, the minimum standards under the Animal Welfare Act and all applicable rules promulgated by the United States Department of Agriculture. 
(3)  Presence on public rights-of-way. Animals kept for exempt purposes shall not be allowed on any public street, sidewalk, or other public way, except in a fully enclosed cage or adequate structural restraint. The use of a leash, with or without a muzzle, shall not be considered adequate restraint. This subsection does not apply to: animals that are part of a featured performance at a special event with a city festival or parade permit where the animal handler is licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-15. - Limit on number of dogs per owner. 
Owners may keep, maintain or harbor no more than three (3) dogs age twelve (12) weeks old or older. 
(Code 1959, § 3-11; Ord. No. 95-17, § 1, 5-16-95; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 6-166-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ANIMAL CARE, CONTROL AND PROHIBITED OR RESTRICTED ACTS 
 
Sec. 6-20. - Dogs running at large prohibited. 
(a)  No person owning or having possession, charge, custody or control of any animal dog shall cause, permit or allow the animal to stray or in any manner to run at large in or upon any public street, sidewalk or park or upon the property of another. 
(b)  Every person owning or having possession, charge, care, custody, or control of any dog shall keep such dog exclusively upon his own premises; provided, however, that such dog may be off such premises if it be under the control of a competent person and restrained by a chain or leash or other means of adequate physical control. Physical restraints and enclosures must be in compliance with section 6-28. 
(c)  An exemption from this section shall be made for service dogs trained to provide assistance to handicapped persons for sight, hearing, mobility, or other similar purposes. Service dogs do not have to be under physical restraint while off the owner's premises if the dog is under the handicapped person's direct control and is obedient to that person's commands. 
(d)  An exemption from this section shall be made for a dog being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall be excluded from the provisions requiring physical restraint while the dogs are engaged in the performance of duties or training. 
(Ord. No. 75-48, § 2, 5-6-75; Ord. No. 95-18, § 1, 5-16-95; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-21. - Vaccinations against rabies. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog, cat, or ferret to keep, maintain or harbor such animal unless it shall have been vaccinated by a licensed veterinarian with anti-rabies vaccination as required by G.S. 130A-185. 
(Code 1959, § 3-20; Ord. No. 85-09, § 1, 2-19-85; Ord. No. 95-19, § 1, 5-16-96)  
Sec. 6-22. - Dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs. 
(a)  Prohibited without permit. Dogs declared "dangerous" or "potentially dangerous," as defined in section 6-2 of this chapter are prohibited in the city without a permit. 
(b)  Determination. The animal services director shall determine whether a dog shall be declared dangerous or potentially dangerous using the definitions of those terms in this chapter. The animal services director shall issue a written declaration that a dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous within ten working days of the incident necessitating a determination of whether the dog is dangerous or potentially dangerous. 
(c)  Appeal of determination to animal appeals board. Owners of dogs declared dangerous or potentially dangerous who wish to appeal the animal services director's determination may do so by making written notification of such to the city's animal appeals board within ten (10) business days of receiving notification of the determination. The appellate board shall schedule a hearing within ten (10) days of the filing of the objections. 
(d)  Permit for confinement of dangerous of potentially dangerous dogs. The animal services department shall issue a permit for a declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dog only upon submission of a complete, verified application, a finding by the director or his/her designee that required arrangements for housing of the dog and other public health and safety provisions are in effect, payment of a permit fee, and that each dog for which a permit is issued does not pose an unreasonable threat to the public health, safety and general welfare if the permittee shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and the conditions of the permit. 
(1)  Each permit shall be conditioned on continued compliance with the provisions of this chapter and other provisions of law, on continued compliance with and maintenance of the arrangements for housing and safety set forth in the permit application, and any special conditions the director may deem reasonably necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare in view of the particular circumstances and history of the dog concerned. 
(2)  Timing and conditions of permit. Within five (5) business days of final determination by the director or the animal appeals board, owners of declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs shall submit an application to the animal services department for a permit to keep the dog within the corporate limits, or the dog must be removed from the city. Applications for new and renewal permits are available from the animal services department and must be submitted with complete documentation and fees. Before a permit is issued the following criteria shall be met: 
a.  The dog shall be currently vaccinated against rabies, in accordance with G.S. 130A-185. 
b.  The dog shall be spayed or neutered. An exception may be made for dogs that are medically unable to be spayed or neutered. In such cases a certification signed by a licensed veterinarian stating that such animal is unfit to be spayed or neutered because such procedure would endanger the life of such animal and the reason is required. 
c.  The dog shall be implanted with a microchip and the microchip shall be registered with the animal services department 
d.  The dog shall be securely confined to the owner's property in accordance with G.S. 67-4.2. and subsection (f) of this section, Confinement of dangerous of potentially dangerous dogs. The animal services department shall inspect the premises where the permit for keeping the declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is desired. In making such inspection, an animal services officer shall ascertain whether or not the keeping of such dog on the premises, including any enclosures are able to be maintained in a manner that does not pose an unreasonable threat to the public health, safety and general welfare. 
e.  The owner shall, along with the application for a new permit, submit the non-refundable fee for a dangerous dog permit. 
f.  An application for renewal of the permit shall be required annually and all requirements pertaining to keeping dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs shall be met. 
g.  The permit fee shall be in an amount set from time to time by the city council and contained in the schedule of fees and charges on file in the city clerk's office. 
(e)  All permit conditions shall be complied with within thirty (30) days of approval of an application. 
(f)  Confinement of dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs. The owner of a declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is required to keep the animal securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure so as to prevent the animal from escaping. This pen or structure shall be suitable to prevent the entry of young children. If it has no bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded into the ground. The enclosure must also provide protection from the elements for the animal and be in compliance with section 6-24 of this chapter (Mistreatment of animals prohibited). The shelter must be inspected and receive written approval from the animal control officer. 
(g)  A dangerous or potentially dangerous dog shall be permitted at the following locations only: 
(1)  On the premises of the owner. 
(2)  On private property, with the authorization of the owner of the property. 
(3)  At a licensed veterinarian for treatment. 
(4)  In a motor vehicle while being transported. 
(h)  When off the property of the owner, the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog must be muzzled and securely restrained under the control of a competent adult by means of a handheld leash or other like device at all times. Voice command is not recognized as adequate restraint. 
The owner shall notify the animal services department immediately if the dog escapes or is otherwise freed from the property of the owner or escapes restraint when off the property of the owner. 
(i)  Impoundment. If a dog which has been declared dangerous or potentially dangerous is found at large off the owners' property, or out of a secure structure and not controlled by means of a chain, leash or other like device, or for being in a location other than described in subsection (f) or is in the city without a permit it shall be seized and impounded. An animal control officer is authorized to go upon private property to seize the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. If attempts to seize the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog are unsuccessful, animal control may tranquilize the animal to facilitate capture of the animal, without prior notice to the owner. 
(j)  Destruction of previously declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. If an owner of a previously declared dangerous or potentially dangerous dog is in violation of this section and the animal services director reasonably believes the dog to be a threat to public health and safety, the animal services director may seek a court order of custody and proper disposition. 
(k)  Transfer of ownership. If the owner of a dog that has been declared dangerous or potentially dangerous wants to transfer ownership of the dog to another person, the owner shall comply with the requirements of G.S. 67-4.2 regarding written notice and transfer of ownership. The owner shall notify the animal services department of the transfer and the transferee shall comply with all requirements for a permit set forth above. 
(l)  Exemption. The provisions of this section do not apply to: 
(1)  A dog being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties; 
(2)  A dog being used in a lawful hunt; 
(3)  A dog where the injury or damage inflicted by the dog was sustained by a domestic animal while the dog was working as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog on the property of, or under the control of, its owner or keeper, and the damage or injury was to a species or type of domestic animal appropriate to the work of the dog; or 
(4)  A dog where the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time of the injury, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog, had tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-23. - Mistreatment of animals prohibited 
It shall be unlawful for any owner and/or custodian to fail to provide animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, and with humane care and treatment. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner and/or custodian to beat, cruelly ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse any animal or cause or permit any dogfight, bullfight, or other combat between animals or between animals and humans. 
(b)  Whenever any animal is kept within any building or on any premises without food, water or proper care and attention, it shall be the duty of any animal control officer to enter said building or premises to take possession of and remove said animal so abandoned or neglected. 
(c)  Whenever any animal is or will be without proper care because of injury, illness, incarceration or other involuntary absence of the person responsible for the care of such animal, the animal control officer may impound such animal until reclaimed by its owner. The owner must pay the applicable fees in the same manner as any other owner would redeem an impounded animal prior to the release of such animal by the animal control officer. 
(d)  Every person maintaining a pet shop shall post a notice clearly visible from the ground level adjacent to the store, containing the names, addresses and telephone numbers of persons to be notified during any hour of the day or night by an animal control officer acting under the authority of this section. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to allow animals to live in crowded or unsanitary conditions. Any dog confined within a fenced yard or enclosure must have adequate shelter, adequate space and exercise. Minimum space requirements for enclosures shall include the following: 
(1)  The enclosure shall be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animal from injury and to contain the animal 
(2)  Enclosures must be kept in humanely clean condition. 
(3)  Enclosures shall be constructed and maintained as to provide adequate space to allow each animal to make normal postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement to maintain physical conditioning. The animal should be able to sit, stand, turn and lie without obstruction. 
(f)  No person shall tether, fasten, chain tie, or restrain an animal, or cause such restraining of an animal to any object during periods of which tethering is unlawful. Periods of lawful tethering shall be temporary in nature and for no longer than seven (7) consecutive days and shall not be misconstrued to permit the practice of continuous tethering of a dog as a method of restraint or confinement. An animal may be tethered, subject to the requirements of section 6-23 in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Tethering for a period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days while actively engaged in: 
a.  Lawful animal event (such as a show or sporting event). 
b.  Lawful hunting activities, if reasonably necessary for the safety of the dog. 
c.  While a dog is actively engaged in shepherding or herding livestock. 
d.  When meeting the requirements of a camping or recreation facility. 
e.  Law enforcement activities. 
f.  After taking possession of a dog that appears to be a stray dog and after having advised animal control of the stray. 
(2)  When the animal's caretaker is outside and within eyesight of the animal. 
(g)  During periods of lawful tethering, the following are stipulations to the types of tethers that may be used: 
(1)  Tethers must be made of rope, twine, cord, or similar material with a swivel on one end or must be made of a chain that is at least ten (10) feet in length with swivels on both ends and which does not exceed ten (10) percent of the dog's body weight. 
(2)  All collars or harnesses used for the purpose of the lawful tethering of a dog must be made of fabric or leather. 
(3)  No person shall tether a dog with a chain or wire or other device to, or cause such attachment to, any collar other than a buckle-type collar or body harness. 
(4)  No person shall tether with a chain or a wire or other device to, or cause such attachment to, a head harness, choke-type collar or pronged collar to a dog. 
(5)  No person shall tether with a chain, wire or other device to a dog where the weight of the tethering device and the collar combined exceeds ten (10) percent of the dog's body weight. 
(6)  No person shall tether with a chain or wire or other device a dog in such a manner that does not allow the dog access to adequate food, water and shelter. 
(7)  Trolley systems: The length of the cable along which the tethering device can move must be at least ten (10) feet, and the tethering device must be of such length that the dog is able to move ten (10) feet away from the cable perpendicularly and attached in such a manner as to prevent strangulation or other injury to the dog and entanglement with objects. 
(8)  No person shall tether a sick, diseased and/or injured dog, or puppy (a dog that is one (1) year of age or younger). 
(Ord. No. 75-48 § 3, 5-6-75; Ord. No. 2014-35, § 3, 10-7-14)  
Secs. 6-246-36. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT 
 
Sec. 6-37. - Authority. 
Any domesticated or exotic animal that is found to be without apparent evidence of ownership or to be in violation of any provision of this chapter is subject to immediate impoundment by animal control officers if the animal's owner is non-existent, unknown, or found to be unavailable after a reasonable attempt to identify, locate, and/or notify the animal's owner has been made. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from seizing and/or forfeiting an impounded animal pursuant to any other provision of this chapter or state law. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-38. - Right of entry. 
Animal control officers are hereby authorized to enter upon any unfenced lot, tract or parcel of land for the purpose of seizing and impounding any animal found thereon in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 79-39, § 4, 7-17-79; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-39. - Impoundment at animal shelter. 
Any animal taken by an animal control officer shall be impounded by the animal services department at the animal shelter, or another location as designated and authorized by the department. 
The animal services department shall comply with G.S. 19A-32.1 which sets out in part minimum requirements for holding periods, public viewing of animals in shelters and disposition of animals. The animal services personnel, upon impounding or receiving any animal under the provisions of this article, shall abide by Article 3, Animal Welfare Act, of G.S. 19A, Article 6, Communicable Diseases, Part 6 Rabies of G.S. 130A, and by provisions of the North Carolina Administrative Code promulgated to carry out such laws in registering and caring for animals in animal shelters and making reasonable efforts to identify and notify the owner of impounded animals when the owner is not known. In compliance with these statutes and regulations, the animal services department shall hold impounded animals for a minimum of seventy-two (72) hours consistent G.S. 19A-32.1, unless otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-40. - Notice. 
Upon impounding an animal, the animal services staff make a reasonable effort to notify the owner and inform such owner of the conditions under which the animal may be reclaimed. Any owner concerned about the loss or possible impoundment of an animal must check the animal services department. The seventy-two (72) hour holding period, unless otherwise provided for, begins when the animal control officer delivers the animal to the animal shelter. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-41. - Right to redeem. 
The owner of any animal which has been impounded under the provisions of this article shall have the right to redeem the animal within the seventy-two (72) day holding period, unless otherwise provided for herein, upon the payment of any and all fees which may be due and payable for the impoundment of such animal as determined by the City of Burlington. 
(Ord. No. 74-5, § 1, 1-18-74; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-42. - Reserved.  
Sec. 6-43. - Fees. 
Fees shall be charged for the impoundment, redemption or adoption and care of any animal under the provisions of this article. These fees shall be set annually by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 74-5, § 1, 1-18-74; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-44. - Redemption or adoption of animal. 
(a)  Redemption; vaccination required. The owner of any impounded domesticated animal, upon satisfactory proof of ownership, and proof of vaccination against rabies if the animal is a dog, cat or ferret, may, unless otherwise provided for herein, recover the animal from the shelter within the seventy-two (72) hour holding period. Absent proof of vaccination, the animal shall at the time of redemption or prior to redemption, be vaccinated by a veterinarian or certified rabies vaccinator (CRV) on duty at the shelter. If no veterinarian or CRV is on duty, the owner shall within three (3) business days have the animal vaccinated by a veterinarian and provide proof of such to the animal services department. 
(b)  Options if owner fails to recover. If the owner of any animal impounded under this article shall fail to recover the animal within the seventy-two (72) hour holding period, the animal may be adopted as a pet to a new owner or humanely euthanized, in accordance with Article 3 Animal Welfare Act of G.S. 19A and provisions of the North Carolina Administrative Code promulgated to carry out said laws. 
(c)  Compliance with rabies law required for adoption. Any person adopting or reclaiming any dog, or cat or ferret from the animal shelter shall ensure compliance with North Carolina Rabies law: Article 6, Communicable Diseases, Part 6 Rabies of G.S. 130A prior to taking possession of the animal. If the dog, cat, or ferret was previously vaccinated, proof of vaccination shall be required. 
(d)  Spaying or neutering required. Dogs and cats released for adoption from the shelter shall be spayed or neutered. Such animal may be adopted by the first such person who meets adoption requirements and pays the adoption fee. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-45. - Suspected rabid animals not to be redeemed or adopted. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, animals impounded which are reasonably suspected to be suffering from rabies shall not be redeemed or adopted shall be dealt with in accordance with this chapter and applicable state laws. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-46. - Destruction of wounded or diseased animals before conclusion of seventy-two-hour hold. 
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, any animal impounded that is badly wounded or diseased may be humanely euthanized in accordance with G.S. 19A-32.1(b)(2). 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 6-476-57. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - RABIES CONTROL 
 
Sec. 6-58. - Rabies control. 
It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any animal owner, keeper or other person to fail to comply with the laws of North Carolina relating to the control of rabies. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-59. - Duty of owner to surrender animal; redemption. 
The owner, upon demand by the animal control officer, shall forthwith surrender any animal which has bitten a human, or which is suspected as having been exposed to rabies, for supervised confinement, the expense of which shall be borne by the owner. Said animal may be reclaimed by the owner if it is adjudged free of rabies, upon payment of fees determined therefor by the council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 73-86, § 1, 12-4-73)  
Sec. 6-60. - SameRedemption of strays restricted. 
No animal which has been impounded by reason of its being a stray, unclaimed by its owner, shall be allowed to be adopted from any animal shelter during the period of rabies emergency quarantine, except by special authorization of the animal control officer.  
Sec. 6-61. - Surrender of carcass. 
The carcass of any dead animal exposed to rabies shall, upon demand, be surrendered to the animal control officer.  
Sec. 6-62. - Failure to obey. 
No person shall fail or refuse to surrender any animal for quarantine or destruction as required herein when demand is made therefor by the animal control officer.  
Secs. 6-636-64. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PENALTIES 
 
Sec. 6-65. - Civil penalty. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided herein, any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a civil penalty for each level of violation in accordance with subsection (C) of this section. Fines shall be established by the city council based on the nature of the violation and number of repeat offences. If the violation is continued, each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. For the purposes of this section, repeat violations occur where the agency has issued a fine for the same offense within a twenty-four-month period. Nothing in this section shall prevent agency representatives from issuing warning violations. 
(b)  The animal owner or keeper shall be issued a written notice of violation and penalty and shall be required to make payment to the tax collector within ten days of receipt of notice. Notice of the civil penalty and violation shall be delivered in person to the violator or mailed by certified mail, return-receipt requested, to the violator's last known address. If the applicable civil penalty is not paid within the period prescribed, a civil action may be commenced to recover the penalty and costs associated with the collection of the penalty. 
(c)  The severity of violations of the provisions of this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  Violation of the following shall constitute a level I violation: 
a.  Section 6-12 "Livestock running at large prohibited." 
b.  Section 6-15 "Limit on number of dogs per owner." 
(2)  Violation of the following shall constitute a level II violation: 
a.  Section 6-11 "Keeping of livestock prohibited". 
b.  Section 6-13 "Keeping of fowl prohibited." 
(3)  Violation of the following shall constitute a level III violation: 
a.  Section 6-14 "Keeping of exotic or wild animals prohibited." 
b.  Section 6-20 "Dogs running at large prohibited." 
c.  Section 6-21 "Vaccination against rabies." 
d.  Section 6-22 "Dangerous, potentially dangerous dogs." 
e.  Section 6-23 "Mistreatment of animals prohibited." 
f.  Section 6-58 "Rabies control." 
g.  Section 6-59 "Duty of owner to surrender animal; redemption." 
h.  Section 6-61 "Surrender of carcass." 
i.  Section 6-62 "Failure to obey." 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-66. - Injunctions. 
Any provision of this chapter which makes a condition existing on or use made of real property unlawful may be enforced by injunction and order of abatement. When a violation of such a provision occurs, the director, through the city attorney, or any resident of the city, may apply to the general court of justice for a mandatory or prohibitory injunction and order of abatement commanding the defendant to correct the unlawful condition upon or cease the unlawful use of the property. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 6-67. - Civil penalty fine schedule. 
Civil Penalty Fine Schedule 
	First Offense 	Second Offense 	Third Offense 	Each Additional Offense 
Level I 	$50.00 	$75.00 	$100.00 	$100.00 
Level II 	$75.00 	$125.00 	$250.00 	$250.00 
Level III 	$100.00 	$250.00 	$500.00 	$500.00 
 
  
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS  
ARTICLE I. - BUILDING CODE 
 
Secs. 7-1, 7-2. - Reserved.  
Sec. 7-3. - Extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
The city, in accordance with Article 19, chapter 160A of the North Carolina General Statutes and as authorized by the Alamance County Commissioners on the second day of October, 1972, shall regulate the construction of buildings by the enforcement of the city building construction and inspection provisions and regulations of this Code, within the boundaries of the extraterritorial jurisdiction as adopted shown on the official zoning map of the city. 
(Ord. No. 72-73, § 1, 10-17-72; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 7-4. - Permit fees. 
Any person making application for a permit for buildings, heating and air conditioning, plumbing and electrical inspections shall pay to the city a fee in such amount as established from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 72-86, § 1, 12-5-72; Ord. No. 79-26, §§ 1, 2, 4-17-79; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 7-5. - Penalty for beginning work without permit. 
Where work for which a permit is required by this Code has started before obtaining the permit, the fees specified for such work shall be doubled but with a minimum fee set forth in the fee schedule adopted by council. The payment of such doubled fee or required minimum fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this Code and the execution of the work nor from any penalties prescribed herein. It is provided further that this section shall cover all work where a permit is required. 
(Ord. No. 81-11, 2-17-81; Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-18-94; Ord. No. 09-04, 4-7-09; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 7-6. - Extra inspections. 
Additional inspections or inspection trips made necessary through the failure of any contractor or builder in charge of work to specify location of work, or by failure of said contractor or builder to install any apparatus in proper manner, or any other extra inspections or trips made necessary by such contractor or builder are hereby designated "extra inspections." For the "first extra inspection," a fee set forth in the fee schedule adopted by council shall be charged against and paid by said contractor or builder to the city. For a "second extra inspection," a fee set forth in the fee schedule shall be charged against and paid by said contractor or builder to the city. For "all inspections after a second extra inspection," a fee set forth in the fee schedule shall be paid by said contractor or builder to the city. Nothing herein shall be construed to require extra fees for the several inspections made necessary in the regular order of construction work. 
(Ord. No. 86-51, § 1, 11-4-86; Ord. No. 94-1, § 1, 1-18-94; Ord. No. 47, § 1, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 09-04, 4-7-09; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 7-77-14. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TECHNICAL CODES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7-15. - Building and technical codes. 
The following codes, with all supplements and amendments thereto, ratified and adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council under the provisions of G.S. 143-138, and with the specified effective date, shall be in effect in the City of Burlington and shall be applicable to all construction activities to which the code applies: 
(1)  Administrative Code and Policies 
(2)  Building Code 
(3)  Electrical Code 
(4)  Energy Code 
(5)  Existing Building Code 
(6)  Fire Prevention Code 
(7)  Fuel and Gas Code 
(8)  Mechanical Code 
(9)  Modular Construction Regulations 
(10)  Plumbing Code 
(11)  Residential Code 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 7-16. - Examinations for journeyman electricians. 
Examinations for journeyman electricians conducted by the Electrical Inspector. 
(1)  Every person desiring to operate as a journeyman electrician under the supervision of a qualified electrical contractor within the city shall make written application with a fee established by the city council to the electrical inspector for an examination. No application shall be accepted for journeyman electrician qualifications unless said person has had four (4) years training under the supervision of a journeyman electrician or equivalent. 
(2)  Examination shall be conducted by the electrical inspector monthly or when deemed advisable by and shall be based on practical experience, the current edition of the National Electrical Code, and the state and local electrical laws and ordinances. Examinations shall be written and shall be kept on file for two (2) years after examination. The electrical inspector shall issue certificates and a copy of the local electrical code as applied for to those applicants who shall show proper qualifications. 
(3)  Any certificate may, after a hearing before the chief inspector, be suspended or revoked for just cause. Any decision of the chief inspector may be appealed to the city manager who shall then render a final decision. 
(4)  An applicant who passes the examination shall receive a permanent journeyman card. An applicant who fails to pass the examination shall not have his fee returned but will be entitled to a reexamination after a period of sixty (60) days, after which time he may again apply to the electrical inspector. After two (2) failures, a new deposit is required. 
(Ord. No. 71-29, 7-20-71; Ord. No. 88-34, § 3, 7-19-88; Ord. No. 2000-2, §§ 1, 2, 1-4-02; Ord. No. 09-04, 4-7-09 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 7-17. - Creation of fire districts. 
(a)  Primary and secondary fire districts are established for the city. The boundaries of each district shall be shown on the official map maintained in the inspections department of the city. 
(b)  The North Carolina Building Code "Appendix D," Fire Districts, including any and all future amendments, shall apply to fire districts. 
(8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Establishment of fire limits, G.S. 160A-435; Restrictions within primary fire limits, G.S. 160A-436; Restrictions within secondary fire limits, G.S. 160A-437.  
Sec. 7-18. - Construction, repair or alteration of buildings. 
Within the secondary fire district: 
(a)  The regulations and requirements covering new construction for commercial, business or industrial uses within the primary fire district are hereby established as the same as the regulations and requirements for new construction within the secondary fire district unless such building or structure is located thirty (30) feet or more from the adjoining property lines. The width of streets, alleys and railroad rights-of-way may be included in the thirty-foot requirement. 
(b)  Residential construction, or the repair, alteration or addition to existing buildings shall be permitted under regular permit issued by the building inspector. 
(c)  Temporary buildings or structures may be permitted provided they are placed on the property expressly as a sales item. The following restrictions will apply: 
(1)  A five-foot unobstructed separation between such structures or buildings or other structures or buildings on the same lot. 
(2)  A minimum of ten (10) feet from all property lines. 
(3)  No electrical current or operational plumbing or heating devices shall be connected to such buildings or structures. 
(4)  No such structure or building shall be used for storage while located on the lot. 
(5)  Placement of such structures or buildings shall not impede flow of traffic or utilize any required off-street parking. 
(Code 1959, § 12-3; Ord. No. 93-37, § 2, 10-5-93; Ord. No. 94-22, § 2, 5-17-94; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference G.S. 160A-435.  
Chapter 9 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Cemeteries generally, G.S. Ch. 65; municipal cemeteries, G.S. § 65-37 et seq., § 160A-341 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 9-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to provide regulations for the management and sale of lots and grave spaces within the city cemeteries. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-2. - Definitions. 
Grave space shall apply to a single space of sufficient size to accommodate one adult interment, also known as a "burial site," "burial space," "grave" or "plot." 
Interment shall mean the permanent disposition of the remains of a deceased person by cremation, entombment or burial. 
Lot shall apply to numbered divisions as shown on the recorded plat, each of which consists of two (2), four (4) or eight (8) grave spaces. 
Marker shall mean a memorial flush with the ground. 
Monument shall include a tombstone or memorial of granite or other materials, which shall extend above the surface of the ground. 
Space number shall mean the grave space number. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-3. - Burials restricted. 
No person shall bury a dead human body within the corporate limits of the city except in the church cemeteries now in use or upon the lots or parcels of land known as the public cemeteries belonging to the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-9; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-4. - Price of lots and grave spaces. 
The price of cemetery lots and grave spaces sold by the city shall be established from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 71-3, § 1, 1-19-71; Ord. No. 76-43, 6-15-76; Ord. No. 80-81, § 1, 11-18-80; Ord. No. 84-87, § 1, 11-6-84; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-5. - Fees for opening, digging graves and other services. 
The fees to be charged by the city for opening and digging graves in the city cemeteries and other services performed by the cemeteries division shall be set by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 71-3, § 2, 1-19-71; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-6. - How many lots one may purchase. 
No person shall be entitled to purchase more than eight (8) grave space lots except where there are unusual and extraordinary circumstances surrounding the individual's particular situation making it necessary that the individual have more than eight (8), and in such latter case only when the individual has applied for and received the specific approval of the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 8-21; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-7. - Speculating in lots. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to buy or otherwise acquire any city cemetery lot for the purpose of sale or exchange, or to sell or exchange the same for speculation or for profit or gain, or to sell or exchange grave space in any such lot for profit or gain. 
(Code 1959, § 8-20 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-8. - Certain cemetery lot sales prohibited.
