Sales of city cemetery lots to any corporation, and to business concerns, partnerships and associations, are hereby expressly forbidden. 
(Code 1959, § 8-19)  
Sec. 9-9. - Required clause in deeds to lots. 
Every deed for a cemetery lot executed by the city, after the date of the passage of this section, shall contain a paragraph reading substantially as follows: 
To have and to hold the said lot for the uses and purposes, and subject to the limitations herein mentioned, unto the said ____________, his heirs and assigns forever. Provided always, and these presents are on the express condition, that the said lot above described shall be used for the burial of dead human bodies or cremated remains only, and in the event the said ____________ or ____________, heirs or assigns, shall use or attempt to use the same for any other purpose whatever, then this deed shall become inoperative, null and void, and all rights and privileges granted hereunder shall immediately cease and terminate; and provided further, that this deed is hereby expressly made subject to and with full notice of the rules and regulations adopted by the City Council of Burlington, at its regular meeting on the ____________ day of ____________/____________/____________, ____________, as later amended, and subject to and with full notice of the ordinances enacted by the City Council pertaining to said cemetery, and all of the provisions, conditions and stipulations of said rules and regulations, and of all the pertinent ordinances now in force, and of such rules and regulations and ordinances as may hereafter be adopted by the City Council, are accepted by the grantee and are recognized as covenants running with the land, are expressly made a part hereof, and are binding upon the grantee and his heirs and assigns. 
(Code 1959, § 8-25; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-10. - Purchase and sale of lots and grave spaces. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or transfer a lot or a grave space in the city cemeteries except as provided herein or as provided in section 9-11 between members of the same family. 
When a purchaser desires to purchase a city cemetery lot or grave space, the purchase shall be initiated through the cemetery division based on the cemetery fee schedule established by the city council. The city clerk shall prepare a cemetery deed drawn on a form prepared by the city attorney that conveys the lot from the city to the purchaser. Payment shall be based on the cemetery fee schedule established by the city council. 
When an owner desires to sell a city cemetery lot or grave space, the transaction shall be by execution of a deed from the owner reconveying the lot to the city. The owner shall initiate the reconveyance through the cemetery division. Upon verification of ownership and other required information by the cemetery division, the city legal staff shall prepare a cemetery deed drawn on a form prepared by the city attorney that conveys the lot from the grantor to the city. 
The cemetery division shall maintain a record of ownership of all city cemetery lots and grave spaces. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-11. - Transfer of lots or grave spaces between family members. 
When the owner or owners of a lot or a grave space in a city cemetery desires to transfer the lot or the grave space to an immediate family member, related by blood or marriage, the cemetery division shall obtain a notarized statement from the owner acknowledging transfer of the city cemetery lot to the designated family member. "Immediate family" shall mean parents, children, grandchildren, brothers or sisters, spouses and nephews or nieces. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-12. - Cemetery fee schedule. 
The city council shall from time to time adopt a cemetery fee schedule which shall be the basis for sale of lots, grave spaces and columbarium niches from the city to a purchaser. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-13. - Digging graves. 
All graves in any city cemetery shall be dug under the supervision of the cemetery superintendent or designee and at the price fixed by the city. No such graves shall be dug until a request to have the grave opened shall have been made to the superintendent or person designated by him the superintendent to receive the request and to see that the work is done. No person other than as herein provided shall be allowed to dig a grave in such cemetery. 
(Code 1959, § 8-13; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-14. - Obstructions in walkways. 
No marker, curbing, border or tree shall be placed in any walkway or path in any city cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 74-70, § 2, 12-17-74; Ord. No. 85-21, § 1, 3-19-85)  
Sec. 9-15. - Monuments, upright for four and eight grave-space lots. 
Upright mount monuments are permitted only for four (4) and eight (8) grave-space lots. They shall be set upon a foundation that is flush with the ground, designed such that it can properly support the structural load of the monument, and placed as nearly as possible in the center of the lot. The installation of the monument and foundation shall be done in accordance with industry standards and practices and shall be approved by the cemetery superintendent or designee. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-16. - Monuments not permitted for single grave spaces or two grave lots. 
No type of monument shall be permitted for a single grave space in any city cemetery except the flush type, without curbstones or extended corners. 
No type of monument shall be permitted for a two (2) grave plot except the flush-type marker which may be double or single. 
(Code 1959, §§ 8-15, 8-15.1; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-17. - Markers installed flush with ground. 
All markers placed in any city cemetery shall be installed flush with the ground; provided this section shall not apply to an upright monument and provided further that this section shall not apply to any grave space or lot on which a marker has been placed aboveground as of the sixteenth day of January 1962. 
(Code 1959, § 8-12.1; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-18. - Removal of cut flowers after funeral. 
The cemetery superintendent or designee shall have the right to remove from any grave space all cut flowers which remain on a grave space five (5) days after the date on which the funeral was held. The cemetery keeper shall also have the right to remove artificial flowers after a reasonable period of time or when they appear to be deteriorated as to color and appearance. 
(Code 1959, § 8-18; Ord. No. 74-70, § 4, 12-17-74 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-19. - Injuring shrubbery. 
No person shall cut, break or injure, or in any manner destroy any tree, shrub or plant, or wantonly destroy any flower, grass or plant in any enclosure of any grave in the cemeteries of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-7)  
Sec. 9-20. - Planting shrubbery. 
From and after the readoption of this Code, planting of shrubbery or plants of any kind on lots and grave sites shall be prohibited and will be removed by the staff. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-21. - Planting trees in cemetery lots prohibited. 
No person shall plant any tree on a city cemetery lot. 
(Code 1959, § 8-13.1)  
Sec. 9-22. - Disturbing the peace. 
Any person disturbing the quiet and good order of the cemeteries by noise of any kind, or other improper conduct, may be ejected by the proper authority from the grounds. No person shall refuse to leave the cemeteries when notified by such authority to do so, for any disturbance, improper conduct or other violations of the regulations. 
(Code 1959, § 8-5)  
Sec. 9-23. - Disturbing funeral gathering. 
No person shall disturb any funeral gathering which may be in any cemetery for the burial of the dead. 
(Code 1959, § 8-6)  
Sec. 9-24. - Deposit, etc., of filth, etc. 
No person shall throw or deposit any filth, offensive or unclean substance or litter in the cemeteries of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-8)  
Sec. 9-25. - Disturbing a grave or defacing gravestone. 
No person shall in any way disturb any stone placed to mark a grave space or any wall or enclosure around a grave space. 
(Code 1959, § 8-10; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Removing or defacing monuments and tombstones, G.S. § 14-148.  
Sec. 9-26. - Entry between sunset and sunrise. 
No person shall enter the limits of the city-operated cemeteries between sunset and sunrise without first obtaining the written permission of the city manager or the cemetery superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 71-36, § 2, 8-17-71)  
Sec. 9-27. - Maintenance provisions and restrictions. 
In order to allow for the safe, efficient and orderly maintenance and visitation of cemeteries, the following items are prohibited from placement on or around all gravesites, and the cemetery superintendent shall have the right to remove them. 
(a)  Fencing. 
(b)  Gravel. 
(c)  Hardscapes (i.e. block, rocks or bricks). 
(d)  Trinkets. 
(e)  Solar lights. 
(f)  Glass objects. 
(g)  Any other items interfering with the safe and efficient maintenance of cemeteries. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-28. - Cremation burials on grave spaces. 
Cremation burials are allowed on graves spaces as follows: 
(a)  One (1) cremation burial and one casket/vault burial per grave space. 
(b)  No more than two (2) cremation burials with no casket/vault burial per grave space. 
Limitations are based upon space requirements for stone work and maintenance needs. All cremation burials and stone work shall be installed as directed by the cemetery superintendent or designee. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 9-299-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COLUMBARIUM NICHES 
 
Sec. 9-40. - Purchase limits for niches. 
No natural person shall be entitled to purchase more than two (2) double niches in the city columbarium unless there are unusual and extraordinary circumstances surrounding the particular situation making it necessary. Approval must be granted by city council. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-41. - Speculation in columbarium niches. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to buy or acquire any columbarium niche for the purpose of sale or exchange, or to sell or exchange the same for speculation or for profit or gain. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-42. - Certain columbarium niche sales prohibited. 
Sales of columbarium niches to any corporation and to business concerns, partnerships, and associations are hereby expressly forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-43. - Required clause in deed to columbarium niches. 
Every deed for a cemetery niche executed by the city, after the date of the passage of this section, shall contain a paragraph reading substantially as follows: 
To have and to hold the said lot for the uses and purposes, and subject to the limitations herein mentioned, unto the said ___________________, _____ heirs and assigns forever. Provided always, and these presents are on the express condition, that the said niche above described shall be used for the burial of cremains only, and in the event the said _________________, ______ heirs or assigns shall use or attempt to the use the same of any other purpose whatever, then this deed shall become inoperative, null and void, and all rights and privileges granted hereunder shall immediately cease and terminate; and provided, further, that this deed is hereby expressly made subject to and with full notice of the ordinances enacted by the city council pertaining to said columbarium, and all of the provisions, conditions and stipulations of said columbarium, and all of the provisions, conditions and stipulations of said rules and regulations, and of all the pertinent ordinances now in force, and of such rules and regulations and ordinances as may hereafter be adopted by the city council, are accepted by the grantee and are recognized as covenants running with the land, are expressly made a part hereof, and are binding upon the grantee and ____ heirs and assigns. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-44. - Purchase and sale of columbarium niches. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or transfer a columbarium niche in the city cemeteries except as provided herein or in Sec. 9.45 between members of the same family. 
When a purchaser desires to purchase a niche in the city columbarium, the purchase shall be initiated through the cemetery division. The purchaser shall provide all required information and make payment to the city based on the cemetery fee schedule established by the city council. The city clerk shall prepare a cemetery deed drawn on a form prepared by the city attorney that conveys the niche from the city to the purchaser. 
When an owner desires to sell a columbarium niche, the transaction shall be by execution of a deed from the owner reconveying the niche to the city. The owner shall initiate the reconveyance through the cemetery division. Upon verification of ownership and other required information by the cemetery division, the city legal staff shall prepare a cemetery deed drawn on a form prepared by the city attorney that conveys the niche from the grantor back to the city. The city shall repurchase the niche at the price paid by the owner. Should the niche plate have to be replaced, the city shall deduct costs for a replacement plate from its repurchase price. 
The cemetery division shall maintain a record of ownership of all columbarium niches. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-45. - Transfer of niches between family members. 
When the owner or owners of a niche in the city columbarium desire to transfer the niche to an immediate family member, related by blood or marriage, the cemetery division shall obtain a notarized statement from the owner acknowledging transfer of the niche to the designated family member. "Immediate family" shall mean parents, children, grandchildren, brothers or sisters, spouses and nephews or nieces. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9.46. - Opening and closing niches. 
All niches in the city columbarium shall be opened and resealed under the supervision of the cemetery superintendent and designated employees of the city at the price established by the city. No niche shall be opened without consent of the niche owner or transferee. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-47. - Placement of flowers. 
No flowers should be placed inside the columbarium without the consent of the cemetery superintendent or designee. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 9-48. - Attachments to niches facings. 
No attachments of any type shall be permitted to be fastened to niches. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-49. - Inurnment. 
Niches are to be used solely to store cremains. No other items are to be stored in niches. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-50. - Containers required. 
All cremains shall be inurned in a storage container that is of a sealed type and does not leak. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-51. - Price of niches. 
The price of niches sold by the city shall be established from time to time by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-52. - Fees for opening and closing. 
The fees to be charged by the city for opening and closing niches in the columbarium shall be established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-53. - Opening of niches. 
Niches shall be opened for the purpose of inurnment only. Opening for viewing purposes shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 97-28, 6-17-97)  
Sec. 9-54. - Engraving. 
Engraving of niche covers will be done by a private contractor approved by the city. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 10 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-110-15. - Reserved. 
Cross reference Section 1 of Ord. No. 87-10, enacted March 17, 1987, repealed §§ 10-110-3 of Art. I. Said repealed sections contained provisions relative to adoption of state law, civil defense unit, and unit director, and were derived from Code 1959, §§ 9-1, 9-3 .  
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED 
 
Secs. 10-1610-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STATE OF EMERGENCY 
 
Sec. 10-26. - State of emergency; restrictions authorized. 
(a)  A state of emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever during times of public crisis, disaster, rioting, catastrophe, or similar public emergency, for any reason, public safety authorities are unable to maintain public order or afford adequate protection for lives, safety or property, or whenever the occurrence of any such condition is imminent. 
(b)  In the event of an existing or threatened state of emergency endangering the lives, safety, health and welfare of the people within the City of Burlington or any part thereof, or threatening damage to or destruction of property, the mayor of Burlington is hereby authorized and empowered under G.S. Sections 14-288.12 and 166A-8 to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the existence of such a state of emergency, and, in order to more effectively protect the lives and property of people within the city, to place in effect any or all of the restrictions hereinafter authorized. 
(c)  In the line of succession of authority to proclaim a state of emergency, the mayor shall be the first line of authority; in his absence, the mayor pro tem shall be next in the line of authority; in the absence of both the mayor and mayor pro tem, then the next succeeding senior council member shall be next in the line of authority; and in the event of the absence of the mayor, mayor pro tem and the next succeeding senior council member then the next or second succeeding senior council member shall have the authority to proclaim a state of emergency; and finally, in the absence of the mayor, mayor pro tem, the next succeeding senior council member and the next or second succeeding senior council member, then the third succeeding senior council member shall have the authority to proclaim a state of emergency. For simplification throughout this article, the foregoing line of succession will be stated as follows: The mayor, mayor pro tem, or next succeeding senior member of the city council. 
(d)  The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council is hereby authorized and empowered to limit by the proclamation the application of all or any part of such restrictions to any area specifically designated or described within the city limits and to specific hours of the day or night; and to exempt from all or any part of such restriction, while acting in the line of and within the scope of their respective duties, law enforcement officers, firemen and other public employees, rescue squad members, doctors, nurses, employees of hospitals and other medical facilities; on-duty military personnel, whether state or federal; on-duty employees of public utilities, public transportation companies, and newspaper, magazine, radio broadcasting, and television broadcasting corporations operated for profit; and such other classes of persons as may be essential to the preservation of public order and immediately necessary to serve the safety, health, and welfare needs of the people within the city. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 1, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-27. - Proclamation imposing prohibitions and restrictions. 
(a)  The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council by proclamation may impose the prohibitions and restrictions specified in sections 10-28 through 10-33 of this chapter in the manner described in those sections. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council may impose as many of those specified prohibitions and restrictions as she or he finds are necessary, because of an emergency, to maintain an acceptable level of public order and services, and to protect lives, safety, and property. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council shall recite the findings made in the proclamation. 
(b)  The proclamation shall be in writing. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council shall take reasonable steps to give notice of the terms of the proclamation to those affected by it and shall post a copy of it in the town hall. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council shall send reports of the substance of the proclamation to the mass communications media which serves the affected area. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council shall retain a text of the proclamation and furnish upon request certified copies of it for use as evidence. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 2, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-28. - Evacuation. 
The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council may direct and compel the evacuation of all or part of the population of the City of Burlington, to prescribe routes, modes of transportation, and destination in connection with evacuation; and to control ingress and egress of a disaster area, the movement of persons within the area, and the occupancy of premises therein. Details of the evacuation may be set forth or amended in a subsequent proclamation which shall be well-publicized. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 3, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-29. - Curfew. 
(a)  The proclamation may impose a curfew prohibiting in certain areas and during certain periods the appearance in public of anyone who is not a member of an exempted class. The proclamation shall specify the geographical area or areas and the period during each twenty-four-hour day to which the curfew applies. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council may exempt from some or all of the curfew restrictions classes of people whose exemption the mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council finds necessary for the preservation of the public health, safety, and welfare. The proclamation shall state the exempted classes and the restrictions from which each is exempted. 
(b)  Unless otherwise specified in the proclamation, the curfew shall apply during the specified period each day until the mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council by proclamation removes the curfew. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 4, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-30. - Restrictions on possession, consumption, or transfer of alcoholic beverages. 
The proclamation may prohibit the possession or consumption of any alcoholic beverage; including beer, wine, and spirituous liquor other than on one's own premises, and may prohibit the transfer, transportation, sale or purchase of any alcoholic beverage within the area of the city described in the proclamation. The prohibition, if imposed, may apply to transfers of alcoholic beverages by employees of alcoholic beverage control stores as well as by anyone else within the geographical area described. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 5, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-31. - Restriction on possession, transportation, and transfer of dangerous weapons and substances. 
(a)  The proclamation may prohibit the transportation or possession off one's own premises, or the sale or purchase of any dangerous weapon or substance. The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council may exempt from some or all of the restrictions classes of people whose possession, transfer, or transportation of certain dangerous weapons or substances is necessary to the preservation of the public's health, safety, or welfare. The proclamation shall state the exempted classes and the restrictions from which each is exempted. 
(b)  "Dangerous weapon or substance" means: 
(1)  Any deadly weapon, ammunition, explosive, incendiary device, radioactive material or device as defined in G.S. 14-288.8(c)(5), gasoline, or other instrument or substance designed for a use that carries a threat of serious bodily injury or destruction of property. 
(2)  Any other instrument or substance that is capable of being used to inflict serious bodily injury or destruction of property, when the circumstances indicate that there is some probability that such instrument or substance will be so used. 
(3)  Any part or ingredient in any instrument or substance included above when the circumstances indicate a probability that such a part or ingredient will be so used. 
(c)  If imposed, the restrictions shall apply throughout the jurisdiction of the city or such part thereof as designated in the proclamation. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 6, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-32. - Restrictions on access to areas. 
(a)  The proclamation may prohibit obtaining access or attempting to obtain access to any area, designated in the manner described in this section, in violation of any order, clearly posted notice, or barricade indicating that access is denied or restricted. 
(b)  Areas to which access is denied or restricted shall be designated by the chief of police and his subordinates when directed in the proclamation to do so by the mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council. When acting under this authority, the chief of police and his subordinates may restrict or deny access to any area, street, highway or location within the city if that restriction or denial of access or use is reasonably necessary to promote efforts being made to overcome the emergency or to prevent further aggravation of the emergency. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 7, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-33. - Additional prohibitions and restrictions. 
The proclamation may prohibit or restrict: 
(a)  Movements of people in public places; 
(b)  The operation of offices, business establishments, and other places to or from which people may travel or at which they may congregate; and 
(c)  Other activities or conditions the control of which may be reasonably necessary to maintain order and protect lives or property during the state of emergency, within the area designated in the proclamation. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 8, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-34. - Removal of prohibitions and restrictions. 
The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council shall by proclamation terminate the entire declaration of emergency or remove the prohibitions and restrictions as the emergency no longer requires them, or when directed to do so by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 9, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-35. - Superseding and amendatory proclamations. 
The mayor, mayor pro tem or next succeeding senior council member of the city council in his/her discretion may invoke the restrictions authorized by this article in separate proclamations and may amend any proclamation by means of a superseding proclamation in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 10-27. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 10, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-36. - Termination of proclamation. 
Any proclamation issued under this article shall expire five (5) days after its last imposition unless sooner terminated in writing under the same procedures set forth in section 10-27 for proclamations. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 11, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-37. - In case of absence or disability of mayor. 
In case of the absence or disability of the mayor, the mayor pro tem, or such other person as may be designated by the city council, shall have and exercise all of the powers herein given the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 12, 11-18-86)  
Sec. 10-38. - Penalty for violation. 
Any person violating any prohibition or restriction imposed by a proclamation authorized by this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment not exceeding twenty (20) days, as provided by G.S. 14-4 and shall be further subject to the provisions of G.S. 160A-175. 
(Ord. No. 86-58, § 13, 11-18-86; Ord. No. 91-37, 10-1-91 8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 12 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference Ch. 3, Alarm Control. 
State Law reference Fire protection generally, G.S. Ch. 69; municipal fire protection, G.S. § 160A-291 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Supervision generally. 
The city manager shall have supervision of all matters pertaining to the fire department; and shall prescribe such rules and regulations as will, in the manager's judgment, sustain the discipline and improve the efficiency of the department. 
(Code 1959, § 11-1)  
Sec. 12-2. - Duties of fire chief. 
The chief of the fire department shall be the commanding officer of the department, under the supervision of the city manager, and shall be responsible to the city manager for its proper management. The property of the department shall be in his care, and for its safety and proper assignment he shall be directly responsible to the city manager. 
It shall be the duty of the chief to see that all rules, regulations and orders prescribed by the city manager are promptly and faithfully respected and obeyed, and whenever any violation of the same is reported to him or comes under his personal observation, he shall promptly investigate the same and report the matter to the city manager. 
(Code 1959, § 11-4; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 12-312-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 
 
Sec. 12-11. - Adoption and administration. 
(a)  The North Carolina Fire Prevention Code with all supplements and amendments thereto, ratified by the North Carolina Building Code Council under the provisions of G.S. 143-138, and with the specified effective date, shall be in effect as the Fire Prevention and Control Ordinance of the city. A copy of this Code shall be on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  The North Carolina State Administrative Code and Policies with all supplements and amendments thereto, ratified by the North Carolina Building Code Council under the provisions of G.S. 143-138, and with the specified effective date, is hereby adopted for the administration of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-12. - Enforcement; bureau of fire prevention. 
The fire chief shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire prevention code. The fire chief may designate such members of the fire department as inspectors as shall from time to time be necessary. To assist in the performance of the responsibilities and duties placed upon the fire chief, a bureau of fire prevention in the fire department of the city is hereby created. This bureau shall operate under the supervision of the fire chief. The fire chief of the fire department shall designate a fire official as chief of the bureau of fire prevention. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall be the administrator of the bureau of fire prevention. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall be responsible for the direct administration and enforcement of the fire prevention code as may be set forth by the fire chief. The chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall be appointed on the basis of examination or other method for determining his qualifications. The fire chief may also designate such number of technical inspectors as shall from time to time be authorized by the city council. Such technical inspectors shall be selected through an examination to determine their fitness for the position. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-13. - Bureau of fire prevention responsibilities 
(a)  It shall be duty of the officers of the bureau of fire prevention to enforce all laws and ordinances of the city covering the following: 
(1)  The prevention of fires; 
(2)  The storage and use of explosives and flammables; 
(3)  The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment; 
(4)  The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes; 
(5)  The means and adequacy of exit in case of fire, from factories, schools, hotels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters, amphitheaters, and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live, or congregate, from time to time, for any purpose; 
(6)  The investigation of the cause, origin, and circumstances of fires; 
(7)  The maintenance of fire cause and loss records. 
(b)  They shall have such other powers and perform such other duties as are set forth by ordinance or in the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code as adopted by the city as provided by Section 12-11 of this chapter. 
(c)  The bureau of fire prevention shall comply with all provisions of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code with regard to duties and responsibilities of local fire prevention bureaus. Such duties shall include but are not limited to periodic inspection and enforcement of laws affecting premises; investigation of causes and circumstances of fires within the city limits; notification of and cooperation with proper authorities; preservation of evidence; and compilation of records relating to property damage, personal injury, rescues and death resulting from fire. All such records shall be maintained and reported as required by the fire code and provided to the city manager. 
(d)  The fire chief or the chief of the bureau of fire prevention shall also recommend any amendments to the fire prevention code or ordinance which, in the chief's judgment, shall be desirable. Should such amendments be adopted by city council, they shall be forwarded to the North Carolina Building Code Council and shall only become effective upon adoption by the Building Code Council. 
(e)  The provisions of the fire prevention code shall apply equally to both public and private property, and it shall apply to all structures and their occupants, except as otherwise specified. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-14. - Districts in which storage of flammable liquids in outside above-ground storage tanks prohibited. 
(a)  The limits established in the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code applicable to storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks shall apply to the fire district and the restricted fire district as described in section 12-26, Fire District Map adopted by reference, of this Code. It is provided, however, that bulk storage may be permitted in the restricted fire limits as an incidental use when approved by the fire chief or bureau of fire prevention. 
(b)  Aboveground fuel storage tanks incidental to the use of the premises may be permitted by special permit issued by the fire chief or bureau of fire prevention. All applications for such permits must be submitted to the fire safety officer for his recommendation and must include provisions to adequately protect the surrounding property from damage by fire or tank leakage. In granting such permits, the bureau of fire prevention may require such safeguards as in its opinion are necessary for the safety and protection of the area. 
(Ord. No. 72-74, § 1, 10-17-72; Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-15. - Districts in which bulk plants for flammable liquids prohibited. 
The limits referred to in the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code in which bulk plants for flammable liquids are prohibited shall be as established by the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 12-10; Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-16. - Limits in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases restricted. 
The limits referred to in NFPA Pamphlet 58 Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code in which bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted shall be established by the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1959, § 12-11; Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-17. - Limits of districts in which storage of explosives and blasting agents prohibited. 
The limits for storage of explosives and blasting agents shall be as defined and prohibited in the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-18. - Routes for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents. 
The routes for vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents shall be as mandated in 49 CFR Parts 100185, Hazardous Materials Regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation and established by the city traffic engineer. 
(Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-19. - Routes for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals or other dangerous articles. 
The routes for vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals and other dangerous articles shall be as mandated in 49 CFR Parts 100-185, Hazardous Materials Regulations of the U.S. Department of Transportation and established by the city traffic engineer. 
(Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-20. - Fire lanes on private property, devoted to public use. 
The fire lanes on private property referred to in North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, Chapter Five shall be established by the city fire chief. 
(Ord. No. 83-3, 1-4-83; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-21. - Key boxes required. 
(a)  Installation. A key box(es) shall be installed on all new construction where a fire alarm system and/or a fire sprinkler system has been installed, on existing buildings where a fire alarm system and/or fire sprinkler system is newly installed, on access gates where fire department access may be delayed and on any other occupancy where the fire official deems necessary. 
(b)  Accessibility. The fire chief or his designee shall require a key box to be installed in an accessible location where immediate access is necessary to verify the existence of a fire or other emergency in buildings equipped with fire detection or fire suppression systems or equipment. 
(c)  Specifications for key boxes. The approved key box is the Knox Rapid Entry System Series. Lock code and key section shall be unconditionally restricted by the key vault manufacturer for use only by the city fire department. All fire department vehicles containing keys shall be recorded and inventoried annually. The city fire department shall be in complete control of the rapid key entry system authorization and operation. Entry systems shall utilize approval signatures from the authorized members of the city fire department for release of keys and all lock products from the factory. 
(d)  Location for key boxes. The key box shall be located on the exterior of a structure in a location approved by the fire chief or his designee. The key box shall be installed no less than four (4) feet and no more than six (6) feet above grade. 
(e)  Administration. All keys deemed necessary by the fire chief or his designee shall be locked within the key box. The bureau of fire prevention shall be responsible for the administration of the program, will provide all initiating documentation and maintain a current inventory control list. 
(f)  Compliance. Installation of key boxes in all new construction requiring a key box shall be completed in accordance with manufacturers installation requirements prior to final fire inspection approval for occupancy. All existing locations requiring key box installation shall have up to three (3) months to install such key boxes. Property owners that fail to comply shall be subject to a reinspection fee. 
(Ord. No. 06-35, § 1, 8-15-06)  
Sec. 12-22. - Service stations and unattended service stations. 
All service stations are required to comply with the requirements of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code, NFPA 30 and NFPA 30A. In addition, the following requirements apply: 
(1)  Canopy lighting must remain operational. 
(2)  All service stations shall comply with the City of Burlington Zoning Ordinance. 
(3)  Unattended service stations shall be used only for the sale and dispensing of motor vehicle fuels. The sale of liquefied petroleum and kerosene are prohibited while unattended. 
(4)  Existing service stations applying for unattended status shall submit plans that include the location of emergency shut-off devices, fire extinguishers and emergency telephone. 
(5)  All unattended service stations shall require a permit and inspection by fire and building officials before approval. 
(6)  Failure to meet and maintain the conditions for an unattended service station permit shall lead to the immediate revocation of the permit and loss of unattended status. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-23. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code herein adopted or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with an order by a court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every violation and noncompliance, respectively, be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as provided by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) as provided by G.S. 14-4. The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue; and all such persons shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time; and, when not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The application of the above penalty shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions, and violators shall be further subject to the provisions of G.S. 160A-175 Enforcement of Ordinances. 
(c)  It is provided further that pursuant to G.S. 143-139(b)(1) and G.S. 160A-175 any violations of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code shall subject the violator thereof to a civil penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00), with the following exceptions: 
(1)  The penalty for unlawful burning shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00); 
(2)  The penalty for obstructing an exit shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00); and 
(3)  The penalty for overcrowding as defined by the occupancy load in Chapter 10 of the North Carolina Fire Prevention Code shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  Any duly authorized local government official is authorized to issue this civil citation and the violator shall pay the penalty to the city tax collector's office within ten (10) days of receipt. The failure of such violator to pay the civil penalty within the specified time shall subject such violator to a civil action to collect all penalties and costs for such violation and any civil penalty that has not been paid which delinquent notice was sent shall carry an additional late payment penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for a fifty dollar ($50.00) civil penalty and fifty dollars ($50.00) for a one hundred dollar ($100.00) civil penalty. Continued violation or continuing violations shall subject the violator to separate, distinct and successive civil penalties. In addition to or in lieu of remedies authorized above, this section may be enforced by any one or more of the remedies authorized by the provisions of G.S. 14-4 or G.S. 160A-175. 
(Code 1959, § 12-17; Ord. No. 91-37, 10-1-91; Ord. No. 95-23, § 1, 5-16-95; Ord. No. 06-35, § 2, 8-15-06; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-24. - Transportation of articles pursuant to state and federal regulations. 
Nothing contained in this article or the fire prevention code adopted by this article shall be construed as applying to the transportation of any article shipped in conformity with the regulations prescribed by the Interstate Commerce Commission or the North Carolina Utilities Commission, nor as applied to the military or naval forces of the United states. 
(Code 1959, § 12-19)  
Sec. 12-25. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-26. - Fire district map adopted by reference. 
The primary fire district to be designated as Fire District No. 1 and the secondary fire districts to be designated as Fire Districts No. 2 shall be shown on a map to be maintained in the office of the Inspections Division of the City of Burlington, and the same is hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and all of said changes and amendments that may be hereafter made are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated as if fully set out at length herein. Said fire district map shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. Said districts are hereby established in accordance with North Carolina General Statutes Section 160A-435. 
(Ord. No. 81-78, § 1, 12-1-81; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 12-2712-34. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 12-35. - Fire apparatus leaving city; use for other purposes. 
Pursuant to G.S. 58-83-1, "Mutual Aid Between Departments," the city has authority to send firefighters and apparatus beyond the area served the city fire department. The consent of the fire chief or officer in charge shall be required for any fire engine, fire truck or other fire apparatus of the city to leave the city, and no fire apparatus shall be used for other than fire purposes without the consent of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1959, § 11-16; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 12-36. - Trespass at fire stations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter any fire station of the city, upon the front entrance of which there is posted a warning to keep off, or to go upon the lot or grounds upon which any such fire station is located and at a time when no officer or employee of the fire department of the city is present. 
(Code 1959, § 11-18)  
Sec. 12-37. - Discharging fireworks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firecracker, fireworks, explosive material, or other pyrotechnics as defined in G.S. 14-414 and all acts amendatory thereof within the corporate limits of the city except in conformity with procedures set forth in G.S. 14-413. The fire chief may authorize the public display of fireworks by certified individuals when such display shall be in such character and so located so as to confirm to conditions and limitation adopted by the city council. 
It is further provided that any such person desiring to display fireworks shall file with the city clerk a bond or certificate of liability insurance in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) indemnifying the public against damages sustained by reason of the display of any such fireworks, and, in addition, an umbrella policy in an amount approved by the city's risk management department. This bond or certificate of insurance shall be subject to the approval of the city attorney. This section shall be considered as a supplement to all other applicable fire prevention codes regulating the display of fireworks and the same shall be complied with as directed by the fire chief in accordance with the applicable provisions thereof. 
Upon compliance with all provisions of this section and the applicable fire prevention codes, a permit shall be issued by the fire chief prior to any display of fireworks. This section shall apply to all persons, whether or not such persons are exempt from any other provisions of the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 85-56, § 1, 7-16-85; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 12-3812-48. - Reserved.  
Chapter 14 - HOUSING  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Legislative findings of necessity to exercise police powers. 
The city council hereby finds and declares that there exist in the city, buildings used for human habitation which are unfit for human habitation due to dilapidation; defects increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; lack of ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; and other conditions rendering such housing unsafe, unsanitary, or dangerous, or detrimental to the health, safety or morals; or otherwise inimical to the welfare of the residents of the city; and that public necessity exists to exercise the police powers of the city to cause the repair and rehabilitation, closing or demolishing of such housing in the manner herein provided. (Code 1959, § 15A-2; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-2. - Substandard housing declared nuisances; abatement. 
All buildings or portions of buildings used for human habitation which are determined by the administrator of code enforcement to be substandard are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be repaired or rehabilitated to the standards of this chapter or demolished in accordance with the procedure set forth herein. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-3; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-3. - Purpose of chapter. 
The purpose of this chapter is to arrest, remedy and prevent the decay and deterioration of places of habitation and to eliminate blighted neighborhoods by providing minimum requirements for places of habitation for the protection of the life, health, welfare, safety and property of the general public and the owners and occupants of places of habitation. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-4)  
Sec. 14-4. - Applicability of chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter are applicable to all buildings used for human habitation within the city. All structures, when used or intended for use for human habitation within the city, shall be subject to the applicable provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-5; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-5. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. Terms, words, phrases and their derivatives used but not specifically defined in this chapter shall have the meaning specifically defined in the building code, and any terms, words, phrases and their derivatives used but not specifically defined in either this chapter or the building code shall have the meaning specifically defined in the zoning code. 
Administrator: The administrator of code enforcement, or however that position shall in the future be designated, whose assigned duties include the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
Apartment: Any building, or portion thereof, which is designed, built, rented, leased, let or hired out to be occupied, or which is occupied as the home or residence of three (3) or more families living independently of each other in dwelling units. 
Area: 
(1)  As applied to the dimensions of a building, shall mean the maximum horizontal prospective area of the building at grade. 
(2)  As applied to the dimensions of a room, shall mean the total square footage of floor area between finished walls. 
Basement: A story with fifty (50) per cent or more of its cubical contents below finished yard grade. 
Building: That which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner. The term "building" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or part thereof." 
Ceiling height: The clear vertical distance from the finished floor to the finished ceiling. 
Common areas: All areas which were conveyed to the homeowner's association in townhouse development when applicable under the provisions the Subdivision Ordinance. 
Demolish: The demolition and removal of the entire building leaving the property free and clear of any debris and without holes or pockets which may retain water. 
Dwelling: Any building or structure, or portion thereof, which is used, or designed or intended to be used, for human habitation including living, sleeping, cooking and eating, or any combination thereof, and shall include accessory buildings and appurtenances thereto. 
Dwelling unit: Any room or group of rooms located within a building and forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
Exit: A clear and unobstructed way of departure from the interior of a building or structure to the exterior at street or grade level. 
Extermination: The control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by eliminating their harborage places; by removing or making inaccessible materials that may serve as their food; by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping or by any other recognized and legal pest elimination methods approved by the inspector. 
Garbage: The animal and vegetable refuse resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food, including a minimum amount of liquid necessarily incidental thereto. 
Habitable room: A room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, pantries, foyers, communicating corridors, closets or storage spaces. 
Household: All persons who occupy a dwelling unit (a person living alone or any group of persons sharing a dwelling unit is a household). 
Housing: Any building or structure, or part thereof, used and occupied for human habitation or intended to be so used, including any outhouses and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith. 
Infestation: The presence, within or around a dwelling, of any harmful insects, rodents or other pests. 
Inspection division: The office and staff of the supervisor of building inspections of the city. 
Inspector: The supervisor of building inspections and any other employee of the city in the building inspection division whose assigned duties include the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. 
Occupant: Any person, over one (1) year of age, living, sleeping, cooking or eating in, or having actual possession of, a dwelling or rooming unit. 
Owner: A holder of any legal or equitable estate in the premises, whether alone or jointly with others, and whether in possession or not. 
Parties in interest: All individuals, associations, partnerships, corporations and others who have interest in a dwelling and any who are in possession or control thereof as agent of the owner, as executor, executrix, administrator, administratrix, trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner. Any such person thus representing the owner or owners shall be bound to comply with the provisions of this chapter and to the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto to the same extent as if he were owner. 
Pier: A masonry support of at least eight (8) inches by twelve (12) inches of solid masonry extending from the ground and footing to and supporting the building or portion thereof. Pier sizes and spacing shall conform to the specifications of the North Carolina Residential Building Code. 
Plumbing: The water supply system, the sanitary and storm drainage system, the vent system, the fixtures and traps, and shall include their respective connections, devices, appliances and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises. 
Public authority: Any housing authority or any officer who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the city, the county, or the state relating to health, fire, building regulations or other activities concerning dwellings or buildings in the city. 
Public space: That space within any multifamily housing which is open to common use by the occupants and others visiting the premises except in townhouse developments. 
Rooming house: A building in which five (5) or more rooms are let for rent. 
Rubbish: Combustible and noncombustible waste materials except garbage, including but not limited to ashes, wood, coal, coke and other combustible material, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, leaves, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery, dust and dirt. 
Sagging: The amount of deflection occurring over a span between two (2) supports. A deflection of 1/240 shall be deemed as a structural defect. 
Seriously damaged: The amount of damage occurring shall be sufficient to decrease the designed strength of the structural member. 
Story : That part of a building comprised between a floor and the floor or roof next above. 
Structure: That which is built or constructed, an edifice or building of any kind, or any piece of work artificially built up or composed of parts joined together in some definite manner. The term "structure" shall be construed as if followed by the words "or part thereof." 
Substandard building: Any building, including any dwelling unit, guest room or suit of rooms or the premises on which the same is located, or portion thereof, in which there exists any nuisance as defined in this chapter or any conditions, which endanger the life, limb, health, property, safety or welfare of the public or the occupants thereof shall be deemed and hereby is declared to be a substandard building. 
Tenant: Any person who alone or jointly or severally with others occupies a residential building under a lease or holds a legal tenancy in a building. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-6; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 14-614-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 14-17. - Administrator of code enforcement to enforce chapter. 
The administrator of code enforcement or however that position shall in the future be designated is hereby designated the public officer to exercise, by and through the administrator's duly appointed agents, the powers prescribed by this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-8; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-18. - Consulting agencies. 
The administrator shall have authority to request advice and assistance of the housing authority of the city, and the fire department, the police department, the county health department, the city planning department, and any other public authority he may deem appropriate, in order to determine those areas of the city in which substandard housing may be prevalent and shall designate and schedule such areas for comprehensive inspection under this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-9; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-19. - Powers and duties of inspectors. 
A duly designated inspector within the division of code enforcement may determine that buildings are substandard and unfit for human habitation if he finds, on the basis of the standards and requirements of fitness set forth in this chapter, that conditions exist in such buildings which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety or morals of the occupants of such buildings, the occupants of neighboring buildings or other residents of the city; such conditions may include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accident or other calamities; lack of adequate ventilation, light or sanitary facilities; dilapidation; disrepair; structural defects; and uncleanliness. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-10); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-20. - Administrative liability. 
Except as may otherwise be provided by statute or local law or ordinance, no officer, agent or employee of the municipality charged with the enforcement of the housing code shall be personally liable for any damages that may occur to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this Code. No person who institutes, or assists in the prosecution of, a criminal proceeding under this Code shall be liable to damages hereunder unless he acted with actual malice and without reasonable grounds for believing that the person accused or prosecuted was guilty of an unlawful act or commission. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-11)  
Secs. 14-2114-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MINIMUM HOUSING STANDARDS AND REQUIREMENTS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 14-41. - Generally. 
The provisions of this article shall constitute the minimum standards and requirements for housing and shall be pertinent in determining fitness for human habitation. 
(Code 1959, § 14A-14; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-42. - Property maintenanceBuildings and structures. 
(a)  Exterior wood surfaces, not inherently resistant to deterioration, shall be treated with a protective coating of paint or other suitable preservative with sufficient frequency to prevent deterioration. 
(a)  Floors, walls, ceilings and fixtures shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(h))  
Sec. 14-43. - SameOpen areas. 
The following conditions are considered nuisances on property regulated by this chapter and may also be enforced under Chapter 22 Nuisances. (8-21-18 recodification) 
(a)  Surface and subsurface water shall be appropriately drained to protect buildings and structures and to prevent development of stagnant ponds. 
(b)  Fences and other accessory buildings shall be maintained in safe and substantial condition or demolished. 
(c)  Yards and courts shall be kept clean and free of physical hazards, rubbish, trash, garbage, junked auto parts and the like. 
(d)  There shall be no heavy undergrowth or accumulation of plant growth which is noxious or detrimental to health. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(h); Ord. No. 95-24, § 1, 5-16-95; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-44. - SameInfestation. 
Grounds, buildings and structures shall be maintained free of infestation. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(h))  
Sec. 14-45. - SameGarbage and refuse. 
There shall be adequate sanitary facilities and methods provided and used for the storage, handling and disposal of garbage and refuse. These facilities and methods shall comply with Chapter 13, Solid Waste. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(h))  
Sec. 14-46. - Space and use. 
(a)  Any building, or portion thereof, used for human habitation shall not be less than three hundred fifty (350) square feet total floor space. 
(b)  A principal room shall not be less than one hundred fifty (150) square feet. 
(c)  A kitchen-dining room combination, if any, shall be not less than one hundred (100) square feet. 
(d)  A first bedroom, if any, shall be not less than one hundred (100) square feet. 
(e)  A second bedroom, if any, shall be not less than seventy (70) square feet. 
(f)  There shall be at least seventy (70) square feet in each habitable room. 
(g)  There shall be at least one hundred fifty (150) square feet of floor space in habitable rooms for the first occupant in each dwelling unit; at least one hundred (100) square feet for each of the next three (3) occupants; and at least fifty (50) square feet for each additional occupant over the number of four (4) (children three (3) years of age and under shall not counted). 
(h)  In every dwelling unit and in every rooming unit, every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one (1) occupant shall contain at least seventy (70) square feet of floor area, and every room occupied for sleeping purposes, by more than one (1) occupant shall contain at least fifty (50) square feet of floor area for each occupant twelve (12) years of age and over, and at least thirty-five (35) square feet of floor area for each occupant under twelve (12) years of age. 
(i)  Those habitable rooms which must be included to meet the foregoing minimum space requirements shall be at least seven (7) feet wide in any part with at least one-half of the floor area having a ceiling height of at least seven (7) feet, six (6) inches. That portion of any room where the ceiling height is less than four (4) feet shall not be considered as the required floor area. 
(j)  No basement shall be used as a habitable room or housing unit unless: 
(1)  The floor and walls are impervious to leakage of underground and surface run-off water and are insulated against dampness and condensation. 
(2)  The total window area in each room is equal to at least the window area sizes prescribed herein for habitable rooms. 
(3)  Such required window area is located entirely above the grade of the ground adjoining such window area unless provided with adequate window wells. 
(4)  The total of openable window area in each room is equal to at least the area prescribed herein for habitable rooms, except where there is supplied some other device affording adequate ventilation and approved by the inspector. 
(k)  Toilet and bathing facilities shall be enclosed. 
(l)  Access shall be provided to required toilet rooms without going outside building. Toilet rooms shall not open directly onto an open porch. 
(m)  No holes or excessive cracks shall be in walls or ceilings of rooms. 
(n)  Access shall be provided to all rooms within a dwelling unit without passing through a public space. Rooming houses are exempt from this requirement. 
(o)  Doors shall be provided at all doorways leading to bedrooms, toilet rooms and bathrooms and all rooms adjoining a public space. 
(p)  Doors providing access to any living unit shall be capable of being locked. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(c))  
Sec. 14-47. - Light and ventilation. 
(a)  Window glazed area in each habitable room shall not be less than ten (10) square feet or ten (10) per cent of the floor area whichever is greater. 
(b)  Openable window area in each habitable room shall be equal to at least one-half of the minimum allowable window area and facing directly to the outside, for ventilation, unless room is served by an approved ventilating system. 
(c)  All outside windows used for ventilation purposes shall be adequately screened. 
(d)  Screens shall not be permanently fixed to the window frame or sash. 
(e)  Windows shall be reasonably weathertight; there shall be no broken glass. 
(f)  Openable window area in each toilet room shall be at least one and one-half square feet, unless served by an approved ventilating system. 
(g)  Every public hall and inside stairway in every dwelling or multifamily dwelling shall be adequately lighted at all times with an illumination of at least three (3) foot candles per square foot in the darkest portion of the normally traveled stairs and passageways. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(b); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-48. - Exits. 
(a)  There shall be two (2) main exits, each at least thirty (30) inches wide and six (6) feet, eight (8) inches high, easily accessible to the occupants of each building. All exit doors shall be easily operable and remotely located. 
(b)  There shall be platforms, steps or handrails provided to serve exits and they shall be maintained in safe condition. 
(b)  There shall be a safe, continuous and unobstructed exit from interior of building to the exterior at street or grade level. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(c))  
Sec. 14-49. - Plumbing. 
(a)  All plumbing to be installed shall be installed in accordance with the North Carolina Plumbing Code with all supplements and amendments thereto, ratified and adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council under the provisions of G.S. 143-138, and with the specified effective date. 
(b)  All plumbing shall be connected to the city sanitary sewer system where available. 
(c)  All fixtures shall be operable. 
(d)  There shall be no broken water closet bowls. 
(e)  Water closet equipment shall not be loose or leaking. 
(f)  No leaks shall be in shower stall floors. 
(g)  There shall be adequate facilities for furnishing hot water to each tub or shower, lavatory and kitchen sink. 
(h)  There shall be installed a water supply inside the building for each dwelling unit. 
(i)  There shall be installed a water closet, tub or shower, lavatory and sink for each dwelling unit. Kitchen sinks shall be at least eighteen (18) inches by fifteen (15) inches by six (6) inches. 
(j)  Rooming houses, commercial, industrial and institutional buildings shall have the number of plumbing fixtures as required by the city plumbing code. 
(k)  There shall be separate toilet facilities for each dwelling unit. 
(l)  Toilet and bathing facilities shall be protected from the weather. 
(m)  All water piping shall be protected from freezing by proper installation in protected space. 
(n)  Soil and water lines shall be supported with no broken or leaking lines. 
(o)  Every water closet compartment floor surface and bathroom floor surface shall be so constructed and maintained as to be reasonably impervious to water and so as to permit such floor to be readily kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(d); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-50. - Heating. 
(a)  Every building and every dwelling unit shall be weatherproof and capable of being adequately heated, and the heating equipment in every dwelling or dwelling unit shall be maintained in good order and repair. 
(b)  Central heating, if provided, shall be properly installed and maintained in good and safe working condition and capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and water closet compartments in an occupied building to a temperature of at least sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit at a distance three (3) feet above floor level with an outside temperature at twenty (20) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(c)  All gas and oil heating equipment installed on the premises shall be listed by Underwriters' Laboratories or American Gas Association and installed in accordance with the provisions of the city heating code. 
(d)  Liquid fuel stored on the premises shall be stored in accordance with the provisions of the fire prevention code. 
(e)  There shall be no loose bricks in chimneys. 
(f)  There shall be no holes in flues. 
(g)  There shall be no hanging masonry chimneys. 
(h)  Thimbles shall be grouted in tightly. 
(i)  Thimbles shall not be broken or cracked. 
(j)  Thimbles shall be high enough for stovepipe to rise one-fourth inch per foot minimum. 
(k)  Hearths, where required, shall be at least sixteen (16) inches deep and six (6) inches beyond each side of fireplace opening and shall comply with standards in the North Carolina Building Code for the year when the building or dwelling unit was constructed. 
(l)  No combustible materials shall be within seven (7) inches of the top and seven (7) inches of either side of the fireplace opening. 
(m)  If fireplace opening is closed, it shall be a masonry closure. 
(n)  Stove shall be within six (6) feet of thimble serving it. 
(o)  No combustible materials shall be within twelve (12) inches of stovepipe. 
(p)  No stovepipe shall be through combustible walls. 
(q)  In apartment buildings, institutional buildings and rooming houses with central heat, the furnace room shall be enclosed with material having at least a one-hour fire protection rating. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(e); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-51. - Electricity. 
(a)  No receptacles, ceiling fixtures or other fixtures shall be hanging loose. 
(b)  All switches and fixtures shall be safely operable. 
(c)  The number of duplex convenience outlets per habitable room shall be two (2) for rooms one hundred (100) square feet or less and three (3) for rooms over one hundred (100) square feet. Such outlets shall be placed as remotely from each other as possible and practicable. All stationary appliances shall have electrical convenience outlets located within six (6) feet of the appliance. 
(d)  There shall be at least one (1) light in the bathroom. 
(e)  There shall be no unsafe wiring. 
(f)  There shall be no drop or extension cords in excess of six (6) feet in length. 
(g)  No circuits shall be overloaded. 
(h)  Fuses shall be sized correctly and not bridged out. 
(i)  All wiring to be installed shall be in accordance with the North Carolina Electrical Code with all supplements and amendments thereto, ratified and adopted by the North Carolina Building Code Council under the provisions of G.S. 143-138, and with the specified effective date. 
(j)  All wiring shall be maintained in a safe condition. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(f); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-52. - Automatic smoke and carbon monoxide detectors. 
(a)  In one- and two-family dwellings and in every dwelling unit within an apartment house, condominium and/or townhouse, an approved listed detector, sensing visible and invisible particles of combustion shall be provided and installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendation and listing. When actuated, the detector shall provide an audible alarm. 
(b)  At least one (1) listed detector shall be installed outside each sleeping area to warn occupants of the presence of any fire condition. Detectors shall have either a visible light to indicate operability or an audible trouble signal. Audible trouble signals shall be designed to operate at least every minute for seven (7) consecutive days. The alarm signaling device shall emit not less than eighty-five (85) decibels at ten (10) feet. Detectors shall be located on or near the ceiling and installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. Detectors shall be electrically operated (non-plug-in and the primary source of power for detectors installed in new structures shall be taken from the house electrical current. 
(c)  In new dwelling units and existing dwellings where interior alterations, repairs, fuel-fired appliance replacements, or additions requiring a permit occurs, or where one or more sleeping rooms are added or created, an approved carbon monoxide alarm installed outside of each separate sleeping area in the immediate vicinity of the bedroom(s) as directed by the alarm manufacturer. The required carbon monoxide alarms shall be audible in all bedrooms over background noise levels with all intervening doors closed. Single station carbon monoxide alarms shall be listed as complying with UL 2034 and shall be installed in accordance with this code and the manufacturer's installation instructions. 
(Ord. No. 84-10, § 1, 1-7-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 14-5314-57. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STRUCTURAL REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 14-58. - Foundation. 
(a)  Beneath the building, there shall be firm ground, reasonably dry ground, no soggy ground, no water standing, no water running under building. 
(b)  There shall be sound footings, adequate bearing. 
(c)  There shall be sound piers, no loose mortar or building materials. 
(d)  There shall be no piers in which plumb line from top center falls outside middle one-third of pier base. 
(e)  There shall be no isolated solid masonry piers exceeding in height ten times least dimension of pier. 
(f)  There shall be no wood stiff-knee piers. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g))  
Sec. 14-59. - Floors. 
(a)  There shall be no seriously rotted, or termite damaged joists and sills. 
(b)  There shall be no fire damaged charred wood. 
(c)  There shall be no broken, overloaded or sagging girders. 
(d)  There shall be no broken, overloaded or sagging sills. 
(e)  Sills shall be reasonably level. 
(f)  Sills shall be properly and sufficiently supported. 
(g)  There shall be no broken joists. 
(h)  Any floor joists which show signs of weakness or disrepair shall be properly replaced with lumber comparable to at least the same nominal dimension and grade as the original joist. 
(i)  Flooring shall be weathertight without holes or excessive cracks which permit air penetration into rooms. 
(j)  Flooring shall be reasonably smooth and not rotten, fire damaged or worn through. 
(k)  There shall be no loose flooring or floor covering. 
(l)  The floor shall be reasonably level. 
(m)  Any new flooring shall be installed to the standards of the 2012 North Carolina Building Code and subsequent amendments. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-60. - Walls, exterior. 
(a)  There shall be no wall in which a plumb line from the top center of stubs falls outside the base plate at any point along wall. 
(b)  There shall be no studs spaced excessively; maximums: Sixteen (16) inches on center where solid sheathing or siding is not used; twenty-four (24) inches on center where solid sheathing or siding is used. 
(c)  No studs shall be rotted or termite damaged. 
(d)  There shall be no broken or cracked structural members. 
(e)  All siding shall be weathertight, with no holes, excessive cracks or rotted boards which permit air to penetrate rooms. 
(f)  There shall be no loose siding. 
(g)  There shall be no serious deterioration because of lack of preventative maintenance consisting of painting, waterproofing and repair. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g))  
Sec. 14-61. - Walls, interior. 
(a)  Interior finish shall be free of holes and excessive cracks which permit air to penetrate rooms. 
(b)  There shall be no walls in which a plumb line from the top center of studs falls outside the base plate at any point along wall. 
(c)  There shall be no loose plaster, loose boards or other loose wall materials. 
(d)  There shall be no cardboard, newspaper or other highly combustible or improper wall finish. 
(e)  There shall be no studs excessively spaced, maximum: 
(1)  Sixteen (16) inches on center where three-eighth-inch or less sheetrock is used; 
(2)  Twenty-four (24) inches on center where solid wood, plaster, plywood finish, or one-half-inch sheetrock is used. 
(f)  No studs shall be rotted or termite damaged. 
(g)  There shall be no broken or cracked studs or other structural members. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14)  
Sec. 14-62. - Ceilings. 
(a)  There shall be no rotted, broken, sagging or fire damaged joists or improperly supported ends. 
(b)  Any ceiling joists which show signs of disrepair shall be properly replaced with lumber comparable to at least the same nominal dimension and grade as the original joist. 
(c)  There shall be no holes. 
(d)  There shall be no loose plaster, boards, sheetrock or other ceiling finish susceptible to falling. 
(e)  There shall be no cardboard, newspaper or other similar highly combustible finishes in dwelling units. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-63. - Roof. 
(a)  There shall be no rafters rotted, broken or having improperly supported ends. 
(b)  No rafters shall be seriously damaged by fire. 
(c)  Rafters shall be properly braced and tied four (4) feet on center maximum. 
(d)  Attic shall be ventilated. A net free area of at least 1/150 of the attic floor space is required. Obstructions caused by screens and louvers must be subtracted to obtain the net area. The net free area must be cut to 1/300 if fifty (50) per cent of the ventilation is in the upper portion of the attic. 
(e)  No rafter shall be closer than two (2) inches to a chimney unless protected as required by the North Carolina Residential Building Code. 
(f)  There shall be no rotted or loose sheathing. 
(g)  There shall be no loose roof covering, no holes, or no leaks causing damage to structure or rooms. 
(h)  There shall be a minimum of Class C roof covering. No wood shingles shall be exposed. 
(i)  There shall be proper flashing at walls or chimney. 
(j)  There shall be no roof with more than two (2) coverings. For this purpose, wood shingles shall not be considered a covering. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g))  
Sec. 14-64. - Porches. 
(a)  Floor, ceiling and roof shall be equal to requirements set forth above, except sills, joists and floors need not be level if providing drainage of floors; floors need not be weathertight; ceiling height may be seven (7) feet; and attic need not be vented. 
(b)  If post and railings are provided, they shall not be rotted or termite damaged. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14)  
Sec. 14-65. - Stairs and steps. 
(a)  Stairs and steps shall be free of holes, grooves and cracks large enough to constitute accident hazards.
