(b)  Stairwells and flights of stairs more than five (5) risers high shall have rails not less than two (2) feet, six (6) inches measured vertically from the nose of the treads to the top of the rail. 
(c)  Every rail shall be firmly fastened and maintained in good condition. 
(d)  No flight of stairs shall be settled more than one (1) inch out of its intended position or pulled away from supporting or adjacent structures. 
(e)  There shall be no rotting, sagging or deteriorating supports. 
(f)  Every stair riser shall be reasonably uniform in height, and treads shall be sound and securely fastened in position and strong enough to bear a concentrated load of at least four hundred (400) pounds without breaking through. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-14(g))  
Secs. 14-6614-76. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS, OCCUPANTS 
 
Sec. 14-77. - Responsibilities of occupant. 
Every occupant of a dwelling unit or an apartment within this city shall: 
(a)  Keep that part of a dwelling unit or an apartment which he occupies and controls in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  Keep all required plumbing and other fixtures in a clean and sanitary condition, and exercise reasonable care in the use and operation thereof. 
(c)  Be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests whenever such dwelling unit or apartment is the only one in the residential building infested and the owner has provided a reasonably insect-proof and adequate rodent-proof building. 
(d)  Dispose of all garbage and other refuse in an approved garbage receptacle; when approved garbage receptacles are not provided by the landlord, it shall be the responsibility of the occupant to provide adequate approved garbage receptacles. 
(e)  Not place on the premises any material which causes a fire hazard or otherwise endangers the health or safety of any occupants of such building; not place in storage on the premises any furniture, auto parts, junk, equipment or material which harbors insects, rodents or other pests. 
(f)  Not permit any dwelling unit or apartment let to him to be occupied so that any occupancy or use resulting therefrom violates any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Before vacating leased or rented property, such occupant shall, at his own expense, repair or have repaired all damage done to plumbing, gas and electrical fixtures; replace all broken glass and damaged screens; and shall return the keys to the owner or agent. 
(h)  Not permit any dwelling unit to be occupied unless running water is provided to the required plumbing fixtures. 
(i)  Not place on the premises for use any oil or gas fired portable or nonvented cook stove or heater. 
(j)  Not place on the premises for use any heating or cooking unit which constitutes a fire hazard. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-18)  
Sec. 14-78. - Responsibilities of owner. 
An owner remains liable for violations of duties imposed upon him by this chapter even though: 
(a)  An obligation is also imposed on the occupants. 
(b)  The owner has, by agreement, imposed on the occupant the duty of furnishing required equipment or of complying with this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-19)  
Sec. 14-79. - Enforcement of occupant's responsibilities. 
Upon discovering a violation of section 14-77 Responsibilities of occupant, the inspector shall have the power immediately to: 
(a)  Cause to be posted on the main entrance of any building a placard with words which, in effect, provide notice that the building has been condemned and that occupancy for human habitation is prohibited, and further setting forth the reasons therefor. 
(b)  Order the correction of any violations thereof. or otherwise order the building vacated within forty-eight (48) hours from date of notice thereof. 
(c)  Pursue any other remedial action as the inspector may deem reasonably necessary in order to effectuate the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-20)  
Secs. 14-8014-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 14-91. - Enforcement of article. 
(a)  The powers conferred upon the administrator of the division of code enforcement and the administrator's designees by the provisions of this article shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the administrator or designees by any other provisions of this chapter. Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. The measures and procedures herein provided for do not supersede, and this article does not repeal any other measures or procedures which are provided by ordinance or state law for the elimination, repair or correction of the conditions referred to in sections 14-1 and 14-2, but the measures and procedures herein provided for shall be in addition to the same. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the city manager to coordinate and set up proper departmental enforcement procedures to carry out the provisions of this article. Written summary reports with respect thereto shall be made to the city council annually. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-32; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-92. - Powers of administrator for enforcing chapter. 
The administrator shall have such powers as may be necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purpose and provisions of this article, including without limitation the following powers in addition to others herein granted: 
(a)  To investigate housing conditions in the city in order to determine which buildings therein are unfit for human habitation, and which buildings are dangerous, being guided in such examinations of buildings by the requirements set forth in this article; 
(b)  To administer oaths, affirmations, and to examine witnesses and receive evidence; 
(c)  To enter upon and within premises, dwellings and buildings for the purpose of making examinations and investigations; provided, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; 
(d)  To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter; 
(e)  To delegate any of his functions and powers under this chapter to such officers and agents as he may designate. 
Code 1959, § 15A-27; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-93. - Duty of administrator to examine residential buildings. 
It shall be the duty of the administrator to diligently examine the dwellings located in the city for the purpose of locating and taking action with respect to such dwellings as appear to be unfit for human habitation and dangerous. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-22; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Statutory authority, G.S. 160A-441.  
Sec. 14-94. - Criteria for determining building unfit for human habitation. 
(a)  The administrator or administrator's designees shall determine that a building is unfit for human habitation or a building is dangerous if he finds that any of the following conditions exist in such building: 
(1)  Interior wall or other vertical structural members which list, lean or buckle to such extent that a plumb line passing through the center of gravity falls outside the middle third of its base. 
(2)  Supporting member or members which show thirty-three (33) per cent or more of damage or deterioration, or nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering which show fifty (50) per cent or more of damage or deterioration. 
(3)  Floor or roofs which have improperly distributed loads, which are overloaded or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purposes used. 
(4)  Such damage by fire, wind or other causes as endangers the lives, safety or welfare of the occupants or other people in the city. 
(5)  Dilapidation, decay, insanitation or disrepair which is likely to cause sickness or disease, or to work injury to the health, safety or welfare of the occupants or other people in the city. 
(6)  Inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic. 
(7)  Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accident or other calamities. 
(8)  Such lack of adequate ventilation, light, heating or sanitary facilities as endanger the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the occupants or other residents of the city. 
(9)  Violation of any provisions of the building regulations or fire prevention laws or ordinances of the state or city. 
(b)  A building shall be construed by the administrator to be unfit for human habitation or a dangerous building, and the administrator shall so find if the same does not have the minimum facilities as required in this chapter. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-25; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Statutory authority G.S.160A-441 Minimum Housing, G.S. 160A-426(a), general authority for "unsafe buildings," residential and nonresidential.  
Sec. 14-95. - Posting notice of condemnation. 
Pursuant to authority under G.S. 160A-426(a), if the administrator finds that a building is unsafe according to any of the standards in section 14-94, the administrator or designee shall affix a notice that the building is unsafe on a conspicuous place on the exterior of the building or structure. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-96. - Issuance of complaint and notice of hearing 
(a)  Filing of lis pendens. If the dwelling has been condemned, the administrator may file a notice of lis pendens in the office of the clerk of superior court where the property is located. A copy of this notice of lis pendens shall be served upon the owners and parties of interest in the building or dwelling at the time of filing. If the administrator does not file a complaint and notice as provided for herein within sixty (60) days, the administrator shall cancel the notice of lis pendens. The notice of lis pendens shall remain in full force and effect until cancelled. The clerk of superior court shall cancel the notice of lis pendens upon receipt of notice from the city. 
(b)  Issuance of complaint and notice. The administrator or designee shall issue a complaint and notice of hearing whenever a petition is filed with the administrator by a public authority or by at least five (5) residents of the city charging that the subject building is unfit for human habitation, or whenever it appears to the administrator (on the administrator's own motion) that the any building is unfit for human habitation or is dangerous. The complaint and notice of hearing shall be served as provided in section 14-101 upon the owner of and parties in interest in such building stating the charges in that respect. 
(c)  Contents of notice. The complaint shall contain a notice that a hearing will be held before the director of inspections as hearing officer at a place therein fixed within the city, not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty (30) days after the serving of such complaint. The notice shall also state that owners and parties in interest shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint and to appear in person, or otherwise, and give testimony at the place and time fixed in the complaint. Notice of such hearing shall also be given to at least one (1) of the persons signing any petition relating to such building. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-26; Ord. No. 95-62, § 1, 1-2-96; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Statutory authority, G.S. 160A-443(2).  
Sec. 14-97. - Hearing and issuance of order. 
(a)  Hearing At the hearing before the director of inspections, any person desiring to do so may attend and give evidence relevant to the matter being heard. The rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity shall not control in hearings before the director of inspections. 
(b)  Findings of fact and issuance of order. If, after notice and hearing as provided above, the director of inspections determines that the building under consideration is unfit for human habitation in accordance with the standards set forth in section 14-94, the director shall state in writing his finding of fact in support of such determination. The director shall issue an order that repair shall be completed, or the building demolished within a period of time designated by the director as provided below and cause the order to be served on the owner as set forth in section 14-101. 
(1)  If it is determined that the repair of the dwelling to render it fit for human habitation can be made at a cost not exceeding fifty (50) percent of the then current value of the dwelling, the director's order shall require that the owner either complete repair or demolish and remove the dwelling within a designated period not less than sixty nor more than ninety (90) days; or 
(2)  If it is determined that the repair of the dwelling to render it fit for human habitation cannot be made at a cost not exceeding fifty (50) percent of the then current value of the dwelling, the ordinance shall require the owner to demolish and remove the dwelling within a designated period no longer than ninety (90) days. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-23(a); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-98. - Appeals from decisions of director of inspections. 
Pursuant to G.S. 160A-446(c), the owner may appeal the director of inspection's order by filing a notice of appeal within ten (10) days of the rendering of the order with the director and with the Housing Commission. The appeal shall specify the grounds on which the appeal is based. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-99. - Hearing before housing commission on appeal. 
Pursuant to G.S. 160A-446 the housing commissions shall fix a time to hear an appeal within thirty (30) days of notice of appeal shall give due notice to the parties as provided in section 14-101; and shall render its decision within a reasonable time. Any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
The commission may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the decision or order appealed from, and may make any decision and order that in its opinion ought to be made in the matter, and to that end it shall have all the powers of the public officer, but the concurring vote of four members of the commission shall be necessary to reverse or modify any decision or order of the director of inspections. 
Every decision of the commission shall be subject to review by proceedings in the nature of certiorari to Superior Court instituted within fifteen (15) days of the decision of the commission, but not otherwise. An appeal stays all proceedings until a decision is rendered. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-100. - Failure of compliancePlacard. 
If the owner of a building fails to comply with the order to repair or demolish, the administrator shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of any such building a placard with the following words: 
"This building is unfit for human habitation; the use or occupancy of this building for human habitation is prohibited and unlawful." 
(Code 1959, § 15A-23(c); 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Statutory authority, G.S. 160A-443(4).  
Sec. 14-101. - Report to manager; council order of demolition. 
(a)  Administrator's report to manager and notice to owner. If, following notice and hearing, the housing commission orders demolition of the property, the administrator of code enforcement shall file a written report, including the housing commission's order, with the city manager who shall place the report on the agenda for action by the city council at its next regular meeting or at a subsequent meeting to which the council may continue the matter. The administrator shall provide notice to the owner and parties in interest as provided in Sec. 14-101. The notice shall specify the date of the meeting of the city council for which the matter will be docketed for action. 
(b)  Demolition ordinance. Upon review the housing commission's order and the report of the administrator of code enforcement, the council may adopt an ordinance of demolition and authorize funding to effect the ordinance. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-102. - Service of complaints and methods of notice under this chapter. 
All service of complaints, notices or orders issued pursuant to this chapter shall be served upon persons either personally or by registered or certified mail; but, if the whereabouts of any person is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the administrator of his designee or in the exercise of reasonable diligence, and the administrator shall make an affidavit to that effect, then the serving of such complaint, notice or order upon such person may be made by publishing the same once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper published in the city, service being deemed complete upon the date of the last publication. A copy of any notice, complaint or order served by publication shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises affected by the notice, complaint or order on or before the date of the last publication. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-103. - SamePenalty. 
If any order issued and served in accordance with this chapter is not complied with within the time specified therein, the building with respect to which the order has been issued is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and it shall be unlawful for any person that had knowledge of the issuance of such order to occupy or permit the occupancy of any portion of such building for any purpose under a penalty as provided in section 1-4 of this Code. Each day is a separate offense. A placard placed on the building shall be the same as a written order delivered to owner or agent. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dwelling or dwelling unit to fail, neglect or refuse to repair, alter or improve the same or to vacate and close and remove or demolish the same, upon order of the inspector or the housing commission duly made and served as herein provided, within the time specified in such order, and each day that any such failure, neglect or refusal to comply with such order continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-28)  
Sec. 14-104. - Reduction of penalty. 
The judgment for any penalty provided for in this chapter may be reduced or wholly or partly remitted by the presiding judge as he may deem just in any case tried before him. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-30)  
Sec. 14-105. - Use of buildings posted with notices, etc. 
(a)  No person, without the written consent of administrator shall remove, or permit the removal, of any complaint, notice or order posted in accordance with the provisions of sections 14-100. 
(b)  When the administrator finds that a building is unfit for human habitation within the meaning of this chapter and has notified the owner to such effect and the time limit set by the administrator for the correction of defects and vacating same has expired, no person shall receive rentals, offer for rent or occupy such building for any purpose. 
(c)  No person shall damage, mutilate or remove, nor shall any person suffer, permit or cause to be damaged, mutilated or removed from or in a dwelling unit any placard referred to in section 14-100. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any building upon whom a notice, complaint or order has been served to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose thereof until the provisions of the notice, complaint or order have been complied with, or until such owner shall first furnish to the transferee, lessee or mortgagee prior to such transfer, lease or mortgage a true copy of any notice, complaint or order issued by the inspector and at the same time give written notice to the inspector of the intent of transfer, lease or mortgage and to whom the transfer, lease or mortgage is proposed. A transferee, lessee or mortgagee who had received actual or constructive notice of the existence of a notice, complaint or order shall be bound by such notice, complaint or order as of the date of such transfer, lease or mortgage without service of further notice upon him. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-29; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-106. - Recovery of city's expense. 
The costs of demolition and removal shall be a lien against the real property upon which the cost was incurred as provided by G.S. 160A-443(6) 
The city shall sell and distribute the proceeds of the sale of usable materials of the dwelling and any personal property, fixtures, or appurtenances found in or attached to the building as provided by G.S. 160A-433(6) 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-107. - Validity of procedure. 
Failure on the part of any owner or party in interest to receive or have served upon him any complaint, notice or order herein provided for shall not affect or invalidate the proceedings with respect to any other owner or party in interest or any other person. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-23(f))  
Sec. 14-108. - Determination of value. 
The administrator is hereby authorized to fix the reasonable value of any building for the purpose of this article and such value shall be binding, unless the owner protests such value in writing to the inspector within ten (10) days after receipt of an order. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-23(g); 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 14-109. - Immediate action in emergencies. 
(a)  In emergency cases where it reasonably appears there is immediate danger to the life or safety of any person or to the safety of other property, unless a dwelling unit unfit for human habitation or a dangerous building as herein defined is immediately repaired or demolished, the director of inspections shall cause the immediate demolition of the building and the cost of such destruction shall be recovered and collected as is provided in Section 14-106 
(b)  The employees of the city fire department, the city police department and the county health department shall make a report in writing to the administrator of all buildings or structures which are, may be or are suspected of being unfit for human habitation or dangerous within the terms of this chapter, such report to be delivered to the administrator within seventy-two (72) hours of the discovery of such building by such employees of the city fire department, the city police department and the county health department. 
(Code 1959, § 15A-31; 8-21-18 recodification) 
State Law reference Abatement of public health nuisance, G.S. 160A-193.  
Chapter 16 - JUNKED, ABANDONED AND HAZARDOUS MOTOR VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
Abandoned motor vehicle: A vehicle that: 
(1)  Has been left upon a street or highway in violation of a law or ordinance prohibiting parking; or 
(2)  Is left on property owned or operated by the city for longer than twenty-four (24) hours; or 
(3)  Is left on private property without the consent of the owner, occupant or lessee thereof for longer than two (2) hours; or 
(4)  Is left on any public street for longer than seven days. 
Code enforcement officer: A duly sworn official charged with the enforcement of provisions of the City of Burlington Code of Ordinances. 
Hazardous motor vehicle: A vehicle declared to be a health or safety hazard by city code enforcement staff or the city police department. 
Junked motor vehicle: A vehicle that does not display a current license plate and: 
(1)  Is partially dismantled or wrecked; or 
(2)  Cannot be self-propelled or moved in the manner in which it originally was intended to move; or 
(3)  Is more than five (5) years old and appears to be worth less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-2. - Immunity. 
No person shall be barred from bringing an answer or held to answer in any civil or criminal action to the owner or other person legally entitled to possession of an abandoned, lost or stolen motor vehicle for disposing of the vehicle as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 16-3. - Administration. 
(a)  The city police department and city code enforcement staff shall be responsible for the administration and enforcement of this chapter. The city police department shall be responsible for administering the removal of vehicles determined to be abandoned or hazardous on public property, including streets and highways within the city limits. City code enforcement staff shall be responsible for administering the removal of abandoned, junked and hazardous vehicles located on private property in the city. 
(b)  The city may contract with private towing operators to remove, store and dispose of abandoned, junked and hazardous vehicles in compliance with all state and local laws. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to limit the legal authority and powers of the city police and fire department officers in enforcing other laws or in otherwise carrying out their duties. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-4. - Abandoned vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to cause or allow such vehicle to be abandoned as the term is defined herein. 
(b)  Upon investigation, city police department or city code enforcement staff may determine that a vehicle is abandoned and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-5. - Hazardous vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located, to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after it has been declared a hazardous vehicle. 
(b)  Upon investigation, city police department or city code enforcement staff may determine and declare that a vehicle is hazardous and order the vehicle removed. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-6. - Junked motor vehicle unlawful; removal authorized. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the registered owner or person entitled to the possession of a junked motor vehicle, or the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which a junked motor vehicle is located, to leave or allow the vehicle to remain on the property after the vehicle has been ordered removed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, person entitled to the possession of a junked motor vehicle, or for the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which a junked motor vehicle is located, to fail to comply with the location requirements or the concealment requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  Subject to the provisions of subsection (d) below, upon investigation, the code enforcement officer may order the removal of a junked motor vehicle as defined in this chapter after finding in writing that the aesthetic benefits of removing the vehicle outweigh the burdens imposed on the private property owner. Such finding shall be based on a balancing of the monetary loss of the apparent owner against the corresponding gain to the public by promoting or enhancing community, neighborhood or area appearance. The following among other relevant factors shall be considered: 
(1)  Protection of property values. 
(2)  Promotion of tourism and other economic development opportunities. 
(3)  Indirect protection of public health and safety. 
(4)  Preservation of the character and integrity of the community. 
(d)  In determining whether a vehicle constitutes a "junked motor vehicle," city police department and city code enforcement staff, in applying the specific criteria in the definition of a "junked motor vehicle," shall take into consideration, but not be limited to, whether the vehicle has a valid inspection decal as evidence of the stationary character of the vehicle; whether the tires, wheels and other essential parts of the vehicle are present for the operation of the vehicle; has flat tires; has removed parts; and that the condition of the exterior or any other specific evidence that would support a finding that the vehicle violates this section. If such a determination is made, city police department or city code enforcement staff shall state that basis in writing. 
(e)  The city may require any individual requesting removal of a junked motor vehicle from private property under their ownership or control, to indemnify and hold harmless the city against any loss, expenses or liability incurred because of the removal, storage or sale thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-7. - Permitted enclosure. 
Junked motor vehicle(s) subject to this chapter may be kept in a garage or building structure that provides a complete enclosure so that the junked motor vehicle(s) cannot be seen from a public street or abutting property. A "garage or building structure" means either a lawful non-conforming use or garage or building structure erected pursuant to the lawful issuance of a building permit and that has been constructed in accordance with all zoning and building code regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-8. - Pre-towing notice required. 
(a)  Except as set forth in subsection (c) below, a junked, abandoned or hazardous vehicle that has been authorized for removal by the code enforcement officer shall be towed only after notice has been given to the registered owner or to the person entitled to possession of the vehicle. In the case of a junked or hazardous vehicle, if the names and mailing addresses of the registered owner or person entitled to possession of the vehicle or the owner, lessee or occupant of the real property upon which the vehicle is located, can be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, the notice shall be sent by first class mail. If such information cannot be so ascertained or if the vehicle to be removed is abandoned, notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. 
(b)  The notice required by subsection (a) above shall state why the vehicle is subject to removal and that the vehicle will be removed within fourteen days after the postmarked date or date of affixation of the notice unless removed prior to that time. 
(c)  The requirement that notice be given prior to the removal of an abandoned, junked or hazardous vehicle may, as determined by the code enforcement officer or respective police personnel, be omitted in those circumstances where there is a special need for prompt action to eliminate traffic obstructions or to otherwise maintain and protect the public safety and welfare. By way of illustration and not of limitation, such circumstances include vehicles blocking or obstructing ingress or egress to businesses or residences, vehicles parked in such a location or manner as to pose a traffic hazard and vehicles causing damage to public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-9. - Removal of vehicles; post-towing notice. 
(a)  The city may have vehicles removed under this chapter by private towing operators. Any abandoned, junked or hazardous vehicle that has been ordered removed may be removed to a storage area by the tow-truck operator or towing business contracting to perform such services for the city. 
(b)  Private towing operators removing vehicles pursuant to this chapter shall comply with post-towing notice procedures and all provisions of Chapter 20, Article 7A of the North Carolina General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-10. - Probable cause hearing prior to disposition. 
(a)  After removal of an abandoned, junked or hazardous vehicle the owner or any other person entitled to possession may file a request with the Alamance or Guilford County magistrate for a hearing to determine if probable cause existed for removing the vehicle. The magistrate will set the hearing within seventy-two (72) hours of the receipt of the request, and the hearing will be conducted in accordance with G.S. 20-219.11 as amended. 
(b)  If the magistrate determines that the vehicle was towed in error, the city shall: 
(1)  Notify the person in possession of the vehicle to release it, and when the vehicle is in the possession of a private towing operator, pay all charges if the hearing is held before the vehicle is reclaimed; or 
(2)  Reimburse the owner for all charges made by the private towing operator and for storage of the vehicle if the hearing is held after the vehicle is reclaimed. 
(3)  Any aggrieved party may appeal the magistrate's decision to district court. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-11. - Right to redeem. 
At any stage in the proceedings, even before a probable cause hearing, the owner may obtain possession of the removed vehicle by paying all towing and storage fees accrued to date or by posting bond for double the amount of such fees to the towing operator or business having custody of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-12. - Disposal of removed vehicles. 
Any abandoned, junked or hazardous motor vehicle that is not claimed by the owner or other party entitled to possession may be disposed of by the tow-truck operator or towing business having custody of the vehicle. Disposition of such a vehicle shall be carried out in accordance with Article 1 of Chapter 44A of the North Carolina General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-13. - Conditions on removal of vehicles from private property. 
(a)  The city shall not remove a vehicle from private property if the owner, occupant or lessee could have the vehicle removed under applicable state law procedures. 
(b)  Unless determined to be a hazardous or junked motor vehicle by the code enforcement officer, no vehicle shall be ordered removed by the city without prior written request from the owner, occupant or lessee. 
(c)  The city may require any person requesting the removal of a junked, abandoned or hazardous vehicle from private property to indemnify the city against any loss, expense or liability incurred because of the removal, storage or sale of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Sec. 16-14. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter shall apply to any vehicle: 
(1)  That is located in a bona fide "automobile graveyard" or "junkyard" as defined in N.C.G.S. 136.143, in accordance with the "Junkyard Control Act." 
(2)  A vehicle that is in an enclosed building. 
(3)  A vehicle that is on the premises of a business enterprise being operated in a lawful place and manner if the vehicle is necessary to the operation of the enterprise. 
(4)  A vehicle that is used regularly for personal use. 
(5)  A vehicle that is in an appropriate storage place or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner by the City or private towing operator contracting with the City for removal of vehicles. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "lawful place and manner" shall include, but not be limited to, strict compliance with the City of Burlington Zoning Ordinance. A vehicle is "necessary to the operation of the enterprise" shall mean, but not be limited to, the clear, active use or involvement of the vehicle in the operation of the business enterprise. Mere storage or idle standing of a vehicle does not constitute "a vehicle necessary to the operation of the business." 
(Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 6-7-11)  
Chapter 17 - LAKES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL; APPLICABLE TO ALL CITY LAKES 
 
Sec. 17-1. - Definitions. 
City lake, lakes or city owned water supply lakes shall mean Stoney Creek Lake, Lake Cammack, Lake Mackintosh and any other lake under the control of the city. 
Personal watercraft shall mean a small vessel that uses an outboard or propeller-driven motor, or an inboard motor powering a water jet pump, as its primary source of motive power and which is designed to be operated by a person sitting, standing, or kneeling on, or being towed behind the vessel, rather than in the conventional manner of sitting or standing inside the vessel as defined or subsequently defined in G.S. 75A-13.3. 
(Ord. No. 79-34, § 1, 6-19-79; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-2. - Impairing substance. 
The use of an impairing substance is prohibited on any city owned water supply lakes. Persons under the influence of an impairing substance shall be denied the use of any city owned water supply lakes and adjoining city property. 
(Code 1959, § 26-40; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-3. - Suspension of recreational activities. 
The city manager, water resources director or recreation and parks director may suspend recreational activities on any water supply lake in times of low water levels due to drought, construction or maintenance of the dams, or due to water quality or vegetative concerns. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-4. - Baptisms and special events. 
Individuals or organizations desiring to use a city water supply lake for a baptism or other special event shall apply to the water resources director. Upon provision of required information, the water resources director shall forward the request to the city manager to be placed on the upcoming city council agenda. Upon approval by the city council, the manager will forward the request along with a statement of the council's action to the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality, Public Water Supply Section. Approval by the city council and the Public Water Supply Section is required for such an event to be conducted. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-5. - Fireworks. 
Fireworks are prohibited on city water supply lakes and adjoining city owned property under the management of the water resources department. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-617-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY LAKE DIRECTORS AND RULES ENFORCED. 
 
Sec. 17-16. - Duties. 
Lake directors shall be responsible for management and operation of recreation facilities and activities at city owned water supply lakes. It shall be the duty of the city lake directors and their assistants to enforce all rules and regulations adopted by the council and to collect and properly account for all fees prescribed in this chapter. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-17. - Enforcement. 
The director at each lake shall have the power and authority to deny admission to any city owned water supply lake and adjoining city owned property to any person known to have violated the rules and regulations, this chapter, or other ordinances governing such city owned water supply lakes pending final resolution, or to any person having an impairing substance his/her possession, or who shows evidence of being under the influence of an impairing substance. City lake directors shall also have the power and authority to remove from city owned water supply lakes any boat operator who violates any of the regulations governing city owned water supply lakes for health and safety. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-18. - Boats with vegetative, organic matter prohibited 
The director at each lake shall have the power and authority to prohibit boats with vegetative matter or encrusted with barnacles or other salt or fresh water organic matter from entering city owned water supply lakes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-19. - Posting copies of rules and regulations. 
The directors at each lake shall post copies of the rules and regulations of the council concerning city owned water supply lakes in the director's office and other conspicuous places about the lake premises and shall direct every person to read the same before boating or fishing in city owned water supply lakes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-2017-32. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATERCRAFT REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL LAKES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY. 
 
Sec. 17-33. - Boat access to lakes. 
No boats shall enter or leave city owned water supply lakes except from the docks or launching ramps provided by the city. Lake directors and their staffs are authorized to approve boats placed on lakes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-34. - Equipment on boats. 
Each boat on a city owned water supply lake shall be equipped to comply with federal and state regulations pertaining to operation of watercraft. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-35. - Use and operation of watercraft/speed limited. 
Boats within one hundred (100) feet of the shore and one hundred (100) feet of the docks, piers, and ramps, or other designated areas, shall not exceed five (5) mph. 
(Code 1959, § 26-38; Ord. No. 76-53, 7-6-76; Ord. No. 79-34, § 1, 6-19-79; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-36. - Refueling of boats. 
No boats shall be refueled in the water or within one hundred (100) feet of the water's edge at any of the city owned water supply lakes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-37. - Designated restricted use areas. 
The city may designate portions of all city owned water supply lakes as restricted with regard to the use, the type of boating (no gasoline engines) allowed, or for other purposes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-38. - Wakes. 
Boats shall be operated at all times in such a manner as to not create a wake which would endanger the lives or property of others. Lake directors shall have the authority to remove from any city owned water supply lake any boat operator who shall fail to comply with this section. Lake directors are hereby authorized to designate the launching and docking areas of any city owned water supply lake as "no wake" areas and within such areas, when properly posted pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 75A of the North Carolina General Statutes, it shall be unlawful to operate a boat so as to create a wake. 
(Code 1959, § 26-38; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-39. - Hours restricted. 
Private boats will be allowed on any city owned water supply lakes only during specific hours determined by the city and posted at the entrance to such city owned water supply lakes. 
(Code 1959, § 26-38; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-40. - Operation generally. 
Boats shall at all times be operated in such a manner as to not endanger the lives or property of others. 
(Code 1959, § 26-38)  
Sec. 17-41. - Refuse cans. 
All boats shall be equipped with refuse cans to be used only for sanitary purposes.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 17-42. - Amphibious aircraft or balloons. 
No landings or take-off of amphibious aircraft or balloons shall be permitted on any city owned water supply lakes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-43. - Persons not eligible. 
No entry shall be permitted under this chapter to any person who has knowingly violated the provisions of this chapter or the rules or regulations promulgated under this chapter until such violation has been resolved in a manner that will provide assurances that the city owned water supply lakes are protected. 
(Code 1959, §§ 26-4, 26-60; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-44. - Admission. 
Individuals desiring to fish or operate watercraft shall obtain the required permit and pay the required fee upon entry at the checkpoint to any city water supply lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-45. - Fees. 
Fees for use of city owned water supply lakes and rental of equipment shall be charged to individuals using the city owned water supply lakes. These fees shall be reviewed annually by the city council. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-46. - Nontransferable. 
Passes or receipts required by the provisions of this division shall not be transferable to any other person or boat. 
(Code 1959, § 26-39; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-47. - Duration. 
Any pass or receipt issued under the provisions of this division shall be void after the date indicated therein. 
(Code 1959, §§ 26-2, 26-58; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-48. - Revocability. 
Every pass or receipt required by this division shall be issued subject to revocation or cancellation upon violation by the holder thereof of any of the provisions of this chapter or rules or regulations promulgated under the authority of this chapter. 
(Code 1959, §§ 26-3, 26-59; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-4917-59. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FISHING REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO ALL LAKES 
 
Sec. 17-60. - Fishing from banks. 
No fishing will be allowed from the banks of any city owned water supply lake except in designated areas. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-61. - Adoption of NC Wildlife Resources Commission regulations. 
The regulations of the NC Wildlife Resources Commission relating to the kinds and sizes of fish and the times and seasons of taking fish in noncommercial waters are hereby adopted by reference as the fishing regulations for all city owned water supply lakes. 
(Code 1959, §§ 26-7, 26-69; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-62. - Checkpoint stop required prior to fishing. 
All persons desiring to fish, including persons with private boats, must check in at the fishing checkpoint and provide a valid fishing license. 
(Code 1959, § 26-68; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-6317-69. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - REGULATION OF ACTIVITIES IN ALL WATERSHEDS 
 
Sec. 17-70. - Sanitary requirements generally. 
The North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality, Division of Energy, Mineral and Land Resources, Water Supply Watershed Protection Program; the Commission for Public Health; and North Carolina Administrative Code Title 15A Subchapter 18C shall govern the operation of public water supplies, the keeping of livestock, operation of recreational areas, recreational activities, maintenance of residences and places of business, disposal of sewage, establishment of cemeteries or burying grounds on the city owned water supply lakes or tributaries thereto. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-71. - Development, cultivation or pasturing near bank. 
Enforcement of regulations governing cultivation, pasturing and agricultural uses of property within fifty (50) feet of the normal pool level of city owned water supply lakes shall be enforced according to the Jordan Lake Water Supply Nutrient Strategy Protection of Existing Riparian Buffers as currently written or subsequently revised (S.L. 2013-395). Maintenance of sedimentation ponds at Lake Cammack shall be allowed. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-72. - Location of highway or railroad. 
No public highway or railroad shall be established within one hundred (100) feet of the margin of a city owned water supply lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-73. - Trash and other contamination of lakes 
No person shall commit on the city owned water supply lakes any act that will affect the purity of the water in the lake city owned water supply lakes. No trash, garbage, empty cans, bottles or other similar containers, paper, litter or similar refuse shall be deposited in the city owned water supply lakes, on the shore thereof or on the adjacent lands owned by the city around such lake city owned water supply lakes, except in designated containers. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-74. - Riparian buffer area. 
A fifty (50) foot wide riparian buffer shall be maintained and enforced around all city owned water supply lakes measured from the normal pool line outward or to the elevation owned by the City whichever is greater as provided in 15A NCAC 02B .0267 Jordan Lake Water Supply Nutrient Strategy Protection of Existing Riparian Buffers, as currently written or subsequently revised (S.L. 2013-395). 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-7517-84. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - STONEY CREEK LAKE 
 
Sec. 17-85. - Closure due to water level, weather conditions or emergencies. 
The city reserves the right to close Stoney Creek Lake for special events, conditions related to weather or water level for as long as may be necessary, and in the event of any emergency. Homeland Security status will also be considered justification for closing the reservoir. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-86. - Restrictions on type of boat. 
Boats on Stoney Creek Lake are restricted to electric motors and non-motorized craft. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-87. - Approach of boats to the dam. 
No boats shall approach closer than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the dam and spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-88. - Recreational use of lake and marina. 
Activities which will be allowed on Stoney Creek Lake, marina and in the park area include: fishing, bank fishing, picnicking and sailing. Only boats with electric motors, sailboats, row boats, canoes, kayaks, or paddleboats will be allowed on Stoney Creek Lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-89. - Swimming, wading, waterskiing, and jet skiing not permitted. 
Swimming, wading, waterskiing, and jet skiing shall not be permitted in Stoney Creek Lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-90. - Waterskiing and tubing prohibited. 
No waterskiing and/or tubing will be allowed on Stoney Creek Lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-91. - Boats contacting lake banks prohibited. 
Boats shall not be permitted to land or contact the Stoney Creek Lake bank except at the docks, ramps, or landings provided by the city for such purposes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-92. - Fishing. 
Fishing will be permitted in Stoney Creek Reservoir except within 150 feet of the dam spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-93. - No fishing from bridge. 
No fishing is allowed on any bridge or controlled access highway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-94. - Picnicking. 
Picnicking on property adjoining Stoney Creek Lake shall be confined to areas designated for that purpose by the city. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-9517-114. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - LAKE CAMMACK 
 
Sec. 17-115. - Closure due to water level or weather conditions 
The city reserves the right to close Lake Camack for special events, conditions related to weather or water level for as long as may be necessary, and in the event of any emergency. Homeland Security status will also be considered justification for closing the reservoir. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-116. - Speed limits. 
(a)  The maximum speeds of boats operating in Lake Cammack shall be forty (40) mph and outboard motors exceeding one hundred fifty (150) horsepower shall be prohibited when necessary to enforce the forty (40) mph speed limit. 
(b)  On Lake Cammack a speed limit of five (5) mph shall be observed by all craft operating above the bridges and buoy on Stoney and Tom's Creeks. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-117. - Recreational use of Lake Cammack. 
(a)  Activities which will be allowed on Lake Cammack in designated areas and in the marina and park include boating, fishing, sailing, skiing, jet skiing and tubing, paddleboarding, bank fishing and picnicking. 
(b)  Jet skis will be allowed in designated areas of the Lake. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-118. - Swimming not permitted. 
Swimming, except that which is incidental to waterskiing, shall not be permitted on Lake Cammack. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-119. - Waterskiing and/or tubing. 
Lake Cammack is the only city owned water supply lake in which waterskiing and/or tubing is approved. Waterskiing and/or tubing will be permitted from the bridge over Tom's Creek to a point one hundred fifty (150) feet in front of the dam and from a point one thousand (1,000) feet north of the Stoney Creek bridge on the Altamahaw Road between Union Ridge Church and the Stoney Creek Church Road to a point one hundred fifty (150) feet in front of the dam. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-120. - Skier's flotation device. 
Each water-skier shall wear a United States Coast Guard approved personal flotation device at all times. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-121. - Fishing. 
Fishing will be permitted anywhere on Lake Cammack except within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the dam spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-122. - No fishing from bridge. 
No fishing is allowed on any bridge or other controlled access highway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-123. - Boats contacting lake banks prohibited. 
Boats shall not be permitted to land or contact the Lake Cammack bank except at the docks, ramps, or landings provided by the city for such purposes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-124. - Picnicking. 
Picnicking on property adjoining Lake Cammack shall be confined to areas designated for that purpose by the city. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-125. - Approach of boats to the dam. 
No boats shall approach closer than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the dam and spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-12617-134. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - LAKE MACKINTOSH 
 
Sec. 17-135. - Closure due to water level or weather conditions 
The city reserves the right to close Lake Mackintosh for special events, conditions related to weather or water level for as long as may be necessary, and in the event of any emergency. Homeland Security status will also be considered justification for closing the reservoir. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-136. - Speed. 
The maximum speeds of boats operating in Lake Mackintosh shall be forty (40) mph and outboard motors exceeding one hundred fifty (150) horsepower shall be prohibited when necessary to enforce the forty (40) mph speed limit. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-137. - Approach of boats to the dam. 
No boats shall approach closer than 500 feet from the dam and spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-138. - Recreational use of Lake Mackintosh and marina. 
Recreation activities which shall be allowed in designated areas on Lake Mackintosh and in the marina(s) and park(s) include: boating, fishing, sailing, paddleboats, canoes, kayaking, paddleboarding, and bank fishing and picnicking in areas specified for those uses. 
(1)  Only boats with electric engines, sail boats, paddleboats, row boats, canoes and kayaks shall be allowed east of the Huffman Mill Road bridge. Motor boats launched from the city marina east of the Huffman Mill Bridge shall immediately proceed at no wake speed to operating areas west of said bridge. 
(2)  Boats with gasoline engines shall be allowed west of Huffman Mill Road bridge excluding designated areas in the vicinity of Guilford Mackintosh Park and Marina and must operate at no wake speed from launching at the marina to Huffman Mill Road bridge. 
(3)  Paddleboats shall be restricted to cove areas designated by recreation and parks department staff. 
(4)  No waterskiing, tubing or jet skiing shall be allowed. 
(5)  No gasoline engine boat launch shall be allowed at the Guilford Mackintosh Marina. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-139. - Activities prohibited. 
Swimming, wading, waterskiing and/or tubing, and jet skiing are not allowed on Lake Mackintosh. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-140. - Boats contacting lake banks prohibited. 
Boats shall not be permitted to land or contact the Lake Mackintosh bank except at the docks, ramps, or landings provided by the city for such purposes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-141. - Picnicking. 
Picnicking on property adjoining Lake Mackintosh shall be confined to areas designated for that purpose by the city. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-142. - Fishing. 
Fishing will be permitted anywhere on Lake Mackintosh except within five hundred (500) feet of the dam spillway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-143. - No fishing from bridge. 
No fishing is allowed on any bridge or other controlled access highway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-144. - Boats contacting Lake Mackintosh banks prohibited. 
Boats shall not be permitted to land or contact the Lake Mackintosh bank except at the docks, ramps, or landings provided by the city for such purposes. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-145. - Limited number of boats on Lake Mackintosh. 
The total number of gasoline powered watercraft allowed on Lake Mackintosh at the same time shall not exceed seventy-five (75) boats. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 17-14617-154. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - PENALTIES 
 
Sec. 17-155. - Criminal penalties. 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with N.C.G.S. Section 14.4. The maximum fine for each offense shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-156. - Civil penalties for threats to water quality, public health. 
(a)  Civil penalties. Civil penalties may be assessed for violations identified in this chapter that threaten water quality and/or public health. No activity, situation, structure or land use shall be allowed within watershed area which poses a threat to water quality and public health, safety and welfare. Such conditions may arise from inadequate on-site sewage systems which use ground absorption; inadequate sedimentation and erosion control measures; the improper storage or disposal of junk, trash or other refuse within a buffer area; the absence or improper implementation of a spill containment plan for toxic and hazardous materials; the improper management of stormwater runoff, or any other situation found to pose a threat to water quality. 
(b)  Amount of penalty. The city manager shall notify in writing any person(s) assessed for violations of this section. The amount of a civil penalty shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day for a severe violation, five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for a moderate violation, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for a minor violation. Determination of the penalty amount shall be based on: 
(1)  The degree of violation of effluent standard(s) or water quality standard(s); or 
(2)  The degree of effect on receiving waters, public health, and fish or wildlife. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-157. - Additional remedies. 
If any subdivision, development, or occupant and/or land use is found to be in violation of this chapter, the city manager may, in the name of the City of Burlington, in addition to all other remedies available either at law or in equity, institute an action or proceedings to restrain or correct the violation; an action to prevent occupancy of the building, structure, or land; or an action to prevent any illegal act, conduct, business, or use in or about the premises. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-158. - Notice and action by city manager. 
If the water resources director finds that any of the provisions of this chapter are being violated, the city manager shall notify in writing the person responsible for such violations, indicating the nature of the violations and ordering the action necessary to correct it. The manager shall order discontinuance of the illegal use of land, buildings or structures; removal of illegal buildings or structures, or of additions, alterations or structural changes thereto; discontinuance of any illegal work being done; or shall take any action authorized by this section to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions. If a ruling of the city manager is questioned, the aggrieved party or parties may appeal such ruling to the city council. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 17-159. - Severability. 
Should any section or provision of this chapter be declared invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration shall not affect the validity of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof that is not specifically declared to be invalid or unconstitutional. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 22 - NUISANCES  
ARTICLE I. - NUISANCES ON LAND 
 
Sec. 22-1. - Noxious conditions on lots deemed unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land in the city to permit to exist on any such lot or parcel of land any condition which may be declared to be noxious, detrimental to health or to constitute a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-18, 3-18-75; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 22-2. - Enumeration. 
The existence of any of the following conditions on any lot or parcel of land in the city is hereby declared to be noxious, detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of its citizens and the peace and dignity of the city, and to constitute a nuisance and to be violative of the provisions of this chapter: 
(1)  Uncontrolled growth of weeds or other vegetation to a height of twelve (12) inches, or any rank vegetable growth that exhales unpleasant and noxious odors, or that may conceal filthy deposits, or harbor insects causing or threatening to cause a hazard detrimental to the public health or safety, whether the same be upon occupied or vacant premises. 
(2)  Any accumulation of animal or vegetable matter that is offensive by virtue of strong odors or vapors or by the presence therein of rats, mice, snakes or vermin of any kind. 
(3)  An open place of concentration of combustible items such as mattresses, boxes, paper, automobile parts, tires and tubes, garbage, trash, refuse, brush, old clothes, rags, or any other combustible materials or objects of a like nature. 
(4)  An open place of collection of garbage, food waste, animal waste, or any other rotten or putrescible matter of any kind. 
(5)  Hides, dried or green, provided the same may be kept when thoroughly cured and odorless. 
(6)  Any furniture, appliances, or metal products of any kind or nature openly kept that have jagged edges of metal or glass or areas of confinement. 
(7)  Any condition that blocks, hinders, or obstructs in any way the natural flow of water in swales, surface waters, ditches, or drains to the extent that standing water is created on the premises. 
(8)  Any other condition of a property that is considered dangerous, offensive or obtrusive to neighboring property. 
For the purpose of enforcement of this section, an open place is defined as an area of property or portion thereof that is open, including building openings of residential dwelling units that are open to the exterior, such as porches and any other exterior portions of properties ordinarily exposed to public view. 
(Ord. No. 05-15, § 1, 4-5-05; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 22-3. - Notice of violation. 
When any public nuisance as enumerated in this chapter is found to exist on any property within the city, the code enforcement division shall notify the owner or occupant that conditions exist that constitute a public nuisance, and unless the condition is abated within ten (10) days from the mailing of the notice which shall be sent by registered mail, return receipt requested, the conditions constituting a nuisance will be abated, and the costs of the abatement shall constitute a lien against the premises in accordance with other provisions of this chapter. If any such lot is owned by more than one (1) person, the notice may be mailed to any person having any estate or interest in the lot, and such service shall be deemed sufficient compliance with this section. If any such lot is owned by a corporation, the notice may be mailed to local officer or agent of the corporation. If said notice is not accepted or received by the owner as provided herein, the posting of "Notice of Violation" on said property shall constitute notice. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-19, 3-18-75; Ord. No. 04-29, § 2, 6-3-2004; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 22-4. - Abatement by city. 
Upon the failure of the owner or person in possession of any premises upon which a nuisance exists to abate the same within the time allowed, it shall be the duty of the inspection department to abate such nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-19, 3-18-75)  
Sec. 22-5. - Effect of defect in notice. 
Any defect in the method of giving the notice of violation, or in the form thereof, or the giving of such notice to an improper person, shall not prevent the city, in any case where the work of abatement of any nuisance from any lot is actually done by the city, from collecting the cost thereof from the owner, nor shall it affect the validity of the lien on the lot for such cost. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-19, 3-18-75)  
Sec. 22-6. - Abatement without notice. 
If any nuisance is in such a dangerous condition as to admit of no delay in its abatement, the inspection department may, without notice, proceed to abate the same and the costs thereof shall be charged against the lot owner as is provided by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 75-21 § 13-20, 3-18-75)  
Sec. 22-7. - Payment. 
Upon completion of the abatement of any nuisance by this city under the provisions of this chapter, the code enforcement division shall deliver to the city tax collector a statement including the costs of labor, hauling and other necessary items of expense for such abatement. The city tax collector shall thereupon mail to the owner of the lot a bill covering the costs. As provided in N.C.G.S. 160A-193, the amount of the bill shall become a lien upon said property and if not paid within thirty (30) days shall be collected in the same manner as provided for the collection of delinquent taxes. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-21, 3-18-75; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 22-8. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violations of this chapter may be subject to abatement summarily by appropriate injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the provisions of G.S. 160A-175. 
(b)  The abatement of any nuisance in accordance with the procedure prescribed by this chapter shall not prevent the city from proceeding in a criminal action against any person violating the provisions of this chapter. Violators of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable, upon conviction by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than twenty (20) days. 
(Ord. No. 75-21, § 13-22, 3-18-75; Ord. No. 91-37, 10-1-91; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 22-922-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SMOKING AND POLLUTION CONTROL 
 
Sec. 22-30. - Purpose. 
To protect the public health, safety and welfare of its citizens the city council hereby adopts the following ordinance to regulate smoking in public places. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93)  
Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall be construed as defined in this section: 
Bar means an area comprising fifteen (15) feet or less from the perimeter of a permanent counter which is primarily devoted to serving alcoholic beverages and within which the service of food is only incidental to the consumption of such beverages. Although a restaurant may contain a bar, the term "bar" shall not include the restaurant/dining area. 
Burlington Parks System/City Parks System. Bodies of water, land and facilities owned, managed, leased, or occupied by Burlington Recreation and Parks. This includes but is not limited to: grounds, city parks, playgrounds, natural areas, golf course, trails and greenways, streams, municipal lakes or other bodies of water, parking lots and sidewalks bordering the park system and bus stop shelters on the City of Burlington Parks System grounds. 
Business means any sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business formed for profit- or nonprofit-making purposes, as well as professional corporations and other entities where professional services are delivered. 
E-cigarette. Any electric oral device that employs a mechanical heating element, battery or electronic circuit regardless of shape or size and that can be used to heat a liquid nicotine solution or any other substance, and the use or inhalation of which simulates smoking. The term shall include any such device, whether manufactured, distributed, marketed or sold as an e-cigarette, e-cigar, e-pipe, or under any other product name or description. 
Greenways. A strip of undeveloped land near an urban area, set aside for recreational use or environmental protection. 
Grounds. An unenclosed area owned, managed, leased, or occupied by the City of Burlington. 
Nonsmoking area means an area in which smoking is prohibited. 
Public area/place means any enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted. A private residence is not a public place. 
Restaurant means any coffee shop, cafeteria, sandwich stand, private and public school cafeteria, and any other eating establishment which gives or offers food for sale to the public, guests, or employees, except that the term "restaurant" shall not include a cocktail lounge or tavern if said cocktail lounge or tavern is a "bar" as defined in this section. 
Retail store means any sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation or other business entity where goods or services are sold. Grocery stores are considered to be retail stores. 
Service line means any indoor line at which one (1) or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not such service involves the exchange of money. 
Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, or other lighted combustible tobacco product in any manner or in any form. 
Tobacco/Tobacco product. Any product containing or derived from tobacco that is intended for human consumption, whether chewed, smoked, absorbed, dissolved, inhaled, or ingested by any other means, including but not limited to cigarettes; e-cigarettes; cigars; hookah; little cigars; snuff; and chewing tobacco. A tobacco product excludes any product that has been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product, and a tobacco dependent product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely for such an approved purpose. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 19-02)  
Sec. 22-32. - Smoking and use of tobacco products prohibited in specified public places. 
Smoking and use of tobacco products shall be prohibited in the following places: 
(1)  Service lines; 
(2)  Elevators; 
(3)  Public restrooms and hallways; 
(4)  Polling places; 
(5)  Buses and taxicabs; 
(6)  Public areas or galleries, libraries and museums when open to the public; 
(7)  Seating areas of any building not open to the sky which is primarily used for exhibiting any motion picture, stage drama, lecture, musical recital or other similar performance, except when smoking is part of a stage production; 
(8)  Seating areas and public areas of indoor sports arenas, convention halls, recreational establishments, and service establishments, which have seating and/or waiting areas; 
(9)  Every room, chamber, place of meeting or public assembly, public areas or waiting areas under the control of the city or any other political subdivision of the state, to the extent such place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city. 
(10)  Except as limited pursuant to North Carolina General Statutes Section 130A-498(b1), smoking shall be prohibited in enclosed areas to which the public is invited or allowed when such enclosed areas are located within a building or structure under one ownership which houses multiple tenants or occupancies, and such enclosed area or business is located immediately adjacent to a restaurant located within the same structure. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 2012-25, 11-20-12; Ord. No. 2013-12, 7-16-13; Ord. No. 19-02)  
Sec. 22-33. - Smoking and use of tobacco products, including e-cigarettes, prohibited in facilities and grounds of the Burlington Parks System. 
Smoking and the use of tobacco products, including e-cigarettes, shall be prohibited in all Burlington Parks Systems facilities and grounds, which include but are not limited to: playgrounds; youth athletic fields including spectator areas; swimming pools including dressing or restroom facilities; tennis courts including spectator areas; city park amusement ride area; Fairchild Park BMX track including spectator areas; concert areas in City Park, North Park, Willowbrook Park, and the Depot area; greenways and trails; special facilities such as the golf course and municipal lakes; parking lots; sidewalks bordering park grounds; and ballfields. 
(Ord. No. 19-02)  
Sec. 22-34. - SameIn bars and small restaurants. 
All bars and restaurants with bars and restaurants without bars which have a seating capacity of less than fifty (50) shall post one of the following signs at every entrance notifying patrons of their smoking policy. Signs shall read: "No Smoking," and/or be a No Smoking Symbol, and/or "Non-Smoking Section Available," or "We Do Not Provide A Non-Smoking Section." 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93)  
Sec. 22-35. - SameIn retail stores. 
Smoking shall be prohibited in the public areas (including service lines) of retail stores designed and arranged to accommodate more than two hundred (200) persons, or in which twenty-five (25) persons are regularly employed. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93)  
Sec. 22-36. - Posting of signs required. 
"No Smoking", or other signs relating to an establishment's smoking policy, whichever are appropriate, with letters of not less than one (1) inch in height, and/or the international "No Smoking" symbol shall be clearly, sufficiently and conspicuously posted in every building or other place where smoking is regulated by this article. The international "No Smoking" symbol consist of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red or white or other conspicuous color circle with a same color bar across it. 
Signs shall be posted in the facilities and grounds of the Burlington Parks System identified in section 22-33 above that state that smoking including e-cigarettes is prohibited. Such signs shall include the "No Smoking" and "No Smokeless" and "No E-cigarette" symbol, and lettering shall be of size and legibility as described above. 
Signs shall be posted by the owner, operator, manager or other person having control of such building or other place. Said signs shall indicate where smoking is prohibited and permitted. 
Facilities which provide areas where smoking is permitted in designated areas shall post signs with that information at every public entrance to the facility. 
Except as to the requirements of size, posting and content the signs shall not be regulated by this article. No person shall remove or deface any sign required to be posted by or under the authority of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 19-02)  
Sec. 22-37. - Administration. 
The police department under the direction of the city manager is responsible for administering this article and is authorized and directed to establish regulations for the administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93)  
Sec. 22-38. - Enforcement and penalties, smoking. 
Any person who shall violate this article shall be subject to payment of a civil penalty of fifty dollars ($50.00). Any person, or his agent, having control or the owner of any premises or place who knowingly permits a violation of this article without requesting the violator to comply shall be subject to payment of the civil penalty provided for herein. Any person, after having been asked to comply with this article but fails or refuses to comply shall be subject to the civil penalty provided for herein. Any duly authorized local government official is authorized to issue this civil citation and the violator shall pay the penalty to the city tax collector's office within ten (10) days of receipt. The failure of such violator to pay the civil penalty within the specified time shall subject such violator to a civil action to collect all penalties and costs for such violation and any civil penalty that has not been paid which delinquent notice was sent shall carry an additional late payment penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 95-21, § 1, 5-16-95.)  
Sec. 22-39. - Conflict of law. 
If any portion of this article or the enforcement thereof shall be preempted by any state or federal authority, such preemptions shall not operate to invalidate the rest of this article; and the same shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 93-5, § 1, 3-2-93)  
Secs. 22-4022-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - GRAFFITI: CONTROL AND REMOVAL 
 
Sec. 22-51. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Graffiti means any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted, or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property by any graffiti implement, to the extent that the graffiti was not authorized in advance by the owner or occupant of the property, or, despite advance authorization, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance by the city council. An unauthorized inscription, word, figure, mark, design or other inscribed material that is written, marked, etched, scratched, drawn, or painted on a surface. 
Graffiti implement means an aerosol paint container, a broad-tipped marker or paint stick capable of scarring or leaving a visible mark on any natural or man-made surface. 
Minor shall mean a person who has not yet reached eighteen (18) years of age. 
Persons means any individual, partnership, cooperative association, private corporation, personal representative, receiver, trustee, assignee, or any other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 2013-28, 12-3-13)  
Sec. 22-52. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Defacement. It shall be unlawful for any person to apply graffiti to any natural or man-made surface on any city-owned property or, without the permission of the owner or occupant, on any privately-owned property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-28, 12-3-13)  
Sec. 22-53. - Penalty, graffiti. 
(a)  Fines and imprisonment. Any person violating this article shall be subject to the penalties contained in section 22-8 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2013-28, 12-3-13)  
Sec. 22-54. - Graffiti as nuisance. 
(a)  The existence of graffiti on public or private property in violation of this chapter is expressly declared to be a public nuisance and, therefore, is subject to the removal and abatement provisions specified in Article I, of this chapter. 
(b)  It is the duty of both the owner of the property to which the graffiti has been applied and any person who may be in possession or who has the right to possess such property to at all times keep the property clear of graffiti. 
(Ord. No. 2013-28, 12-3-13)  
Sec. 22-55. - Removal of graffiti by perpetrator. 
Any person applying graffiti on public or private property shall have the duty to remove the graffiti within twenty-four (24) hours after notice by the city or private owner of the property involved. Such removal shall be done in a manner prescribed by the city manager or any additional city department head, as designated by the manager. Any person applying graffiti shall be responsible for the removal or for the payment of the removal. Failure of any person to remove graffiti or pay for the removal shall constitute an additional violation of this chapter. Where graffiti is applied by an unemancipated minor, the parents or legal guardian shall also be responsible for such removal or for the payment for the removal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-28, 12-3-13; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 22-56. - Removal of graffiti by property owner or city.
