(a)  Adopted. The Alamance County Recycling Ordinance, adopted by reference on October 15, 1991, is ratified as being applicable within the corporate limits of the City of Burlington. 
(b)  Enforcement. The provisions of the Alamance County Recycling Ordinance shall be enforced by the director of public works or his or her designee as provided by section 33-21 of this chapter to the extent said enforcement shall not be inconsistent with County Code Section V (penalties). 
(Ord. No. 05-13, §§ 1, 2, 2-15-05)  
Secs. 33-433-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COLLECTION SERVICE 
 
Sec. 33-21. - Rules and regulations authorized. 
The city manager may promulgate such rules and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter as the manager deems advisable to safeguard the health and welfare of the citizens of the city in the disposal of garbage, ashes and other refuse. The collection, removal and disposition of all solid waste from within the city shall be under the jurisdiction and enforcement of the director of public works and his authorized agents, except otherwise provided by the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 33-22. - Ownership of materials. 
Approved wet and dry garbage, recyclable materials, yard waste, bulk trash, and large appliances which are properly placed by an owner or occupant of a property at curbside for collection, are deemed to be abandoned by such person(s) and become the property of and be deemed transferred to the city or its authorized agent. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05)  
Sec. 33-23. - Unauthorized collection prohibited. 
No person, other than those under the direction of the sanitation superintendent, shall haul away or remove any garbage or other refuse set out for collection as in this article provided, except by written consent to the sanitation superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05)  
Sec. 33-24. - Littering. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to put, place, deposit, or throw any trash, litter, house sweepings, paper, paper cups, garbage, shavings or other rubbish upon any sidewalk or in any public street, public alley or other public place in the city, except in receptacles as the city council shall prescribe or provide. No person shall deposit in or sweep into any street, sidewalk, lane or alley or in any catch basin of the city, any paper, trash, litter, plastic containers or wraps, rubbish, broken glass, aluminum/tin cans, bottles, fruit or vegetable peelings, grass clippings, dead animals or any other refuse, ashes or waste. Such materials shall be accumulated as herein before specified and placed in their respective or proper receptacles. Nor shall any householder or storekeeper, by himself or agent, cause to be swept from any house, yard, store or elsewhere any dirt or refuse in or upon the sidewalk or public streets of the city. 
The placing or leaving of the articles or matter forbidden by this section shall, for each day that such articles or matter are placed or left, constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Truck loads causing litter. No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place, an excessive amount of mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
State Law reference Littering, G.S. § 14-399; Size of vehicles and loads, G.S. § 20-116. 
(c)  Litter on occupied private property. No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether owned by such person or not; except, that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(d)  Duty of business owners, occupants. 
(1)  Generally. The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the city shall exercise reasonable diligence at all times to keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, and other used or waste materials thrown or left on said premises by its customers, and to take reasonable measures to prevent the same from drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(2)  Receptacles. Receptacles of sufficient size and number shall be placed on the premises accessible to the customers of such business where the articles of waste referred to above may be disposed of. 
(3)  Signs. Each and every business establishment shall place upon its premises in a conspicuous place in close proximity to the receptacles referred to above, signs which shall, in essence, convey to its customers a request that they use such receptacles for the disposal of waste material. 
(4)  Duty of customer. It is a violation of this chapter for any customer going upon the premises of another to in any manner dispose of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers, recyclables, and other used or waste materials except in receptacles provided for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05)  
Sec. 33-25. - Refuse to be promptly removed. 
No refuse that has become decayed or that shall otherwise be a menace to health or cleanliness shall be allowed to remain in any dwelling house, hotel, boarding house, cafe, restaurant, lunch stand, fruit stand, meat market, store or other building or on any premises or in any other structure for longer than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05)  
Sec. 33-26. - Refuse not collected by the city. 
(a)  Waste from the cleaning and dressing of any fish, flesh or fowl conducted by a commercial operation, such as fish markets, meat processing plants or other businesses of this nature will not be collected by the city. 
(b)  No construction and demolition debris or refuse from building operations will be collected by city forces, except for quantities not exceeding two (2) 32-gallon containers and not to exceed fifty (50) pounds each per project shall be collected if work is done by the homeowner or occupant. Removal of construction and demolition debris shall be the responsibility of the property owner. In addition, any material exceeding six (6) feet in length or otherwise improperly prepared shall not be collected. Vegetative debris generated at residences by commercial tree and/or landscape contractors shall not be collected by the city. 
(c)  Human excreta will not be collected by city forces. 
(d)  Household animal waste shall be disposed of in household garbage. 
(e)  Infectious waste or hazardous waste will not be collected by city forces. 
(f)  Tires, lead acid batteries, paints, waste oil and oil filters, lubricants and other petroleum distillates shall not be collected by city forces. 
(g)  Oxygen tanks and other medical equipment; propane tanks; large oil tanks used for household purposes; parts of campers, boats, camper shells, trailers; automotive parts; including but not limited to motors, doors, fenders, tires, car seats or batteries from a residentially used premises, shall not be collected by the city forces. 
(h)  Oyster shells from private citizens will not be collected by city forces. 
(i)  Wooden pallets will not be collected by city forces. 
(j)  Material in non-clear plastic bags that are placed for collection outside of the refuse container will not be collected by city forces. 
(k)  Discarded consumer electronics will not be collected. This includes but is not limited to televisions (cathode ray tube, projection and flat panel), computer monitors (cathode ray tube or flat panel), computers, computer peripherals, fax machines, VCR and DVD players and stereos. 
(l)  Used fluorescent lamps containing mercury and mercury containing thermostats will not be collected. This includes straight, circular and compact fluorescent lights. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 10-38, § 2, 12-21-10; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 33-27. - Reserved.  
Sec. 33-28. - Refuse from outside corporate limits. 
No refuse collected outside the corporate limits of the city shall be disposed of anywhere within the corporate limits of the city, or on any disposal area outside the corporate limits operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005)  
Sec. 33-29. - Collection routes and schedules. 
The sanitation superintendent shall establish collection routes and schedules and may alter these routes and schedules from time to time. No owner or occupant of any premise shall prohibit or prevent weekly solid waste collection. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005)  
Sec. 33-30. - Service for persons who are physically disabled. 
Special collection services for the physically disabled shall be available. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005)  
Sec. 33-31. - Curbside collection service. 
City-serviced curbside collection services will be provided under the following conditions: 
(1)  Curbside collections scheduling. City-served curbside collection services will be provided once a week on a day designated for collection by the sanitation superintendent. Solid waste shall not be placed at the curbside more than twenty-four (24) hours preceding the scheduled collection day. Recyclables will be collected every two (2) weeks on a day designated by the city's authorized collector. 
(2)  Approved containers. All households and single business units shall use only city approved containers for all solid waste removal by the city. The following provisions shall be complied with: 
a.  Automated collection system. An automated system is in use for the collection of wet and dry garbage. The city-approved automated containers shall have a capacity of no more than one hundred (100) gallons. The city shall provide one (1) 100-gallon container for wet and dry garbage and one (1) for recyclables. In multi-family developments and in special situations where a 100-gallon container is determined by the public works director or his designee to be difficult to use or not feasible for use by the customer, a 65-gallon container will be provided upon request by the customer. In the event there is not sufficient storage between collections, the resident may request from the city one (1) additional garbage and/or recyclables container for a fee. (Refer to solid waste fee schedule.) The following provisions shall pertain to said containers: 
1.  Identification. Where solid waste rollout containers have been provided, the collection containers shall be numbered by the sanitation division so as to indicate the dwelling unit using the particular container. 
2.  Ownership of rollout containers. The city shall retain ownership of rollout containers provided for solid waste collection. Said container shall not be removed from the original assigned premises. Containers which require replacement as a result of user abuse and/or negligence will result in the user being charged a replacement fee as set forth in the solid waste fee schedule. It is a violation of this chapter to willfully break or cause damage to any city owned automated container and any violation shall be subject to civil or criminal penalties as provided in section 33-71. 
3.  Lost, stolen, or damaged containers. Any rollout container provided by the city which becomes lost or stolen through no fault of the user, shall be replaced by the city at no cost. Any rollout container damaged by the placing of hot ashes or other toxic chemicals therein by the user shall be charged a replacement fee. 
4.  Unserviceable containers. Any rollout container provided to the user at the city's expense that becomes unserviceable due to normal usage shall be replaced at the city's expense. 
Businesses generating in excess of two hundred (200) gallons per week of wet or dry garbage shall provide a stationary refuse and/or a recyclable container for service by a private hauler. 
(3)  Placement of containers. 
a.  In order to collect solid waste, the owner or occupant of each business or household shall place all solid waste in approved containers and place such solid waste containers between the curb or traveled portion of the street and the property line closest to the curb of the premises from which the same is placed. Solid waste shall not be placed at the curbside more than twenty-four (24) hours preceding the collection day but must be placed no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day fixed for collection. Solid waste will be collected and removed on the day designated by the sanitation superintendent. Public notice shall be given for any change of collection day. City collection personnel shall not provide service if denied reasonable access by parked vehicles, equipment, fixed objects, low hanging wires or other obstructions. 
b.  The following rules shall apply for the removal of solid waste: 
1.  No wooden boxes, barrels, or any other wooden receptacle, or any other receptacles except approved containers shall be used for collection of wet or dry garbage. Solid waste collectors shall be required to remove all such wooden boxes and other receptacles, if so used. 
2.  For the purpose of collection, placement of containers will be at ground level. 
(4)  Removal of containers following collection. 
a.  All containers or receptacles placed on any street to be emptied, shall after the contents thereof are emptied and collected, be removed from such street by 7:00 p.m. and stored on the host premises. The storage place shall be as near to the house (or business) as reasonably possible. 
b.  No solid waste container or any form of movable carrier shall be placed, kept or left on any street for any purpose whatsoever on Saturday or before dusk on Sunday. 
c.  Any solid waste container or any form of movable carrier placed or found in violation of this section will be deemed a public health hazard and reported to the county environmental health division and be subject to their regulations. 
(5)  Spilled materials. Spilled materials or overflow not caused by city collection crews shall be cleaned up immediately after such spillage or overflow by the property owner or occupant. Spilled solid waste materials caused by city collection crews shall be cleaned up immediately by said collection crew. 
(6)  Yard waste collection service. 
a.  Yard waste collection shall be provided only to residential units and/or small businesses served by the automated collection system. Yard waste collection shall be provided once a week on the same day as curbside collection service designated by the sanitation superintendent. 
b.  Yard waste shall be separated from all other refuse prior to collection. Collection forces shall collect yard waste that is customarily and reasonably associated with the residential units(s) served, so long as it is properly prepared or containerized and in compliance with the following regulations: 
1.  Grass clippings, small shrubbery clippings, leaves, and other small lawn debris shall be collected at the curbside provided that they are placed in clear plastic bags or approved containers for collection. Such bags shall be clear or transparent, in good condition and of such size and weight that when full, do not weigh more than fifty (50) pounds each and are such that one (1) individual can easily pick up each bag, one (1) at a time, for disposal. Plastic bags shall be secured at the top when placed at the curbside for collection. 
2.  Other approved containers used for yard waste shall have tight-fitting lids, equipped with strong handles, and shall not exceed thirty-two (32) gallons in size or fifty (50) pounds in weight when filled. All yard waste containers shall be furnished by the owner or occupant and be made of metal, cardboard boxes or plastic. 
3.  Tree limbs, cuttings, shrubbery and similar materials will be collected as yard waste by sanitation personnel when cut in four-foot lengths, not to exceed fifty (50) pounds in weight, not to exceed six (6) inches in diameter and placed by the curb. 
4.  Large quantities of tree trimmings or similar materials must be cut in lengths not to exceed six (6) feet and placed in piles at the curb. Such materials will be collected by a special truck upon notice by the property owner or sanitation personnel. 
5.  No vegetative debris will be collected if generated by commercial tree contractors or landscaping contractors. (August 21, 2018 recodification) 
6.  No stumps, logs, dirt, rocks, tires on wheels or concrete will be hauled by the sanitation division. 
7.  No building materials or refuse from commercial building operations or landscape work will be hauled by city forces. 
(7)  Large appliance (white goods) collection. Large appliances (white goods) shall be collected only from residential units and/or small businesses served by the automated collection system. Collection is subject to the following conditions: 
a.  Notification must be made to the sanitation division at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the scheduled collection day. 
b.  Appliances shall be placed to the curb by 7:00 a.m. on the collection day, from the unit from which the appliance was removed. 
c.  Appliances shall be emptied of their contents. 
d.  Refrigerator and freezer doors must be removed or secured to prevent entry by small children. 
e.  City collection personnel shall not provide service if denied reasonable access by parked vehicles, equipment, fixed objects, low hanging wires or other obstructions. 
f.  Appliances shall not be collected from any residential unit or small business engaged in the repair or resale of appliances. 
(8)  Bulk trash. 
a.  Bulk trash collection shall be provided only to residential units served by the city. Bulk trash collection shall be provided as designated by the sanitation superintendent or his designee under the following conditions: 
1.  Bulk trash shall be placed to the curb by 7:00 a.m. on the collection day to insure pickup. 
2.  Bulk trash must be separated from all other refuse prior to collection. 
3.  Bulk trash that is too large to be placed in the collection vehicle will not be collected by city forces. 
4.  All glass in windows, doors, mirrors and other items with large expanses of glass must have the glass taped with an "X" mark so it will not shatter in the collection process. 
5.  Gasoline must be removed from all lawn equipment prior to collection. 
6.  Carpet and padding shall be collected provided the carpeting is rolled and tied in sections no longer than five (5) feet. 
7.  Oxygen tanks and other medical equipment; propane tanks; large oil tanks used for household purposes; parts of campers, boats, camper shells, trailers; automotive parts, including but not limited to motors, doors, fenders, tires, car seats or batteries from a residential premises shall not be collected by the city forces. 
8.  Overflow volumes of wet and dry garbage will not be collected as bulk trash. 
b.  The sanitation superintendent or his designee shall have the authority to require items to be prepared for ease of collection and to insure the safety of the employees performing the collection task. Any item not prepared properly may be refused for collection at the sanitation superintendent or his designee's discretion. 
(9)  Private streets agreement. Where curbside collection services are provided upon private streets, the property owner or property owner's association shall enter into an agreement with the City of Burlington whereby the property owner or property owner's association shall indemnify and hold harmless the City of Burlington or any of its agents from any damage to private streets or related infrastructure resulting from any and all waste collection activities. The agreement may also specify certain street-type improvements (i.e. turnarounds) be required in order for the city to be able to provide sanitation services. The agreement may also require that the private streets be maintained to a standard that allows reasonable passage of all sanitation vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; Ord. No. 2011-7, §§ 1, 2, 5-3-11; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 33-32. - Stationary container collection services (dumpsters). 
(a)  Conditions for commercial collection for multifamily residential units (attached and unattached). 
(1)  The developers and/or owners of a multifamily residential unit or a group of multi-family residential units, where it is determined by the director of public works or his designee that curbside collection services are not feasible shall maintain stationary refuse containers. 
(2)  Applicability to new customers. All of the provisions of this section shall apply to all new construction, alterations or conversions of multifamily residential units and/or groups of the same for which any building permit shall be issued where the multifamily residential unit or group or complex of same has been determined by the director of public works or his designee to not be able to receive curbside collection services. No building permit shall be issued for construction, alteration or conversion of a building or group or complex of buildings falling within the application of this section until a plan approved in writing by the director of public works or his designee showing adequate provision for containerization of refuse as required by this section shall be furnished by the owner or developer; and no such multi-family residential unit or group or complex of same to which this section applies shall be constructed, altered or converted without providing for the use and maintenance of stationary refuse containers. 
(3)  Owners and developers of mobile home parks where it is determined by the director of public works or his designee that curbside collection services are not feasible must provide stationary containers as prescribed above. 
(4)  Developers and/or owners of multi-family units and/or complexes, who have been instructed to provide stationary containers may appeal such requirements to the city manager for review and determination by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the public works directors determination, setting forth in said notice of appeal any special conditions or hardships which he feels may be relevant. If not resolved, an appeal may be taken to the city council. The decision of the city council shall be conclusive; provided, however, either party may petition the council for a rehearing based on changed conditions. 
(b)  Conditions for stationary container collection for nonresidential use. 
(1)  Attached business unit. Where an attached business unit or a group of attached business units in the same complex comprise more than four (4) businesses stationary refuse containers shall be provided by the owner or owners at such complex. 
(2)  Business unit. Where refuse accumulates at any business unit, place or location in quantities of more than two (2) 100-gallon automated refuse containers (two hundred (200) gallons) between collections, the owner or owners in charge shall be required to provide a stationary refuse container. 
a.  The city sanitation superintendent is authorized to require certain high volume refuse generators to provide and utilize containerized disposal systems commonly known as "dumpsters" which shall be serviced solely by the high volume refuse generator and not by the city. "High volume refuse generator" as used in this section shall mean and refer to those commercial, business, institutional or multi-family residential development who in the opinion of the superintendent could more effectively and efficiently be served by the containerized disposal system. 
b.  Should the sanitation superintendent make such a determination, he shall notify the user in writing, stating therein the number, size and location of containers to be used. All such containers shall be approved as to design and operation by the superintendent prior to use. Thereafter, the user shall within thirty (30) days conform to the requirements specified in the notice or refuse collection may be terminated by the city. 
c.  Property owners or other interested parties who have been notified to provide containers may appeal such requirement to the city manager for review and determination by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the superintendent's notice, setting forth in said notice of appeal any special conditions or hardships which he feels may be relevant. If not resolved an appeal may be taken to the city council. The decision of the city council shall be conclusive; provided, however, either party may petition the council for a rehearing based on changed conditions. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; Ord. No. 2011-07, § 3, 5-3-11)  
Sec. 33-33. - Collection in central business district. 
(a)  Collection times. The sanitation division will collect garbage and business trash between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday of each week. 
(b)  Approved containers. The same container approved for residential solid waste collection will be provided to the central business district. In unique circumstances, as determined by the Public Works Director or designee, alternate means of collection may be permissible. 
(c)  Container location. All owners, proprietors or managers of retail stores, hotels, restaurants, or office buildings, or occupants of houses within the central business district, may have garbage and business trash collected by the city by putting such refuse in approved containers referred to in subsection (b) of this section. Automated containers shall be placed in areas and maintained as prescribed by this subsection. Where possible, business owners are required to remove cans from the sidewalk and return them to storage area at their business or another area designated by the city. Business owners are responsible for keeping the downtown area clear of solid waste containers to enhance the visual appearance of the central business district. 
(d)  Violations. It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to place or allow to remain garbage or recyclables on the street, or sidewalks in containers other than as provided in this section, or at any time other than the hours designated in this section, or for any person to place or allow to remain empty receptacles or bags on the street or sidewalks. A violation of the above provisions may subject the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) in accordance with section 33-71. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 33-34. - General collection regulations. 
(a)  Collections from manufacturing plants, mills, garages, etc. No collections will be made from manufacturing plants, mills, factories, wholesale stores, bottling works, printing establishments, garages, poultry houses, nurseries or any by-product establishments. 
(b)  Collection schedules. Residential and commercial collection scheduling will be such as to provide adequate and uniform service and will be established by the sanitation superintendent or designee. 
(c)  Solid waste fees. Solid waste fees shall be charged to each solid waste user in such amount as shall be determined by the city council from time to time. The solid waste fees billing cycle shall correspond to the city's water and sewer billing cycle. Residential customers shall be billed bimonthly. Commercial customers shall be billed monthly. Any customer not currently receiving a water or sewer bill shall be billed for the solid waste fees. (It shall be the policy of the City of Burlington to afford solid waste service to all users on as nearly an equitable basis as possible and to charge a fair and reasonable fee to those service users who require extra and disproportionately large amounts of solid waste removal service.) 
(d)  Application of solid waste fee and water and sewer charges. All payments for solid waste fees and water and sewer charges whether full or partial payments shall be applied to the customer's accounts as follows: First, to any solid waste fees charges including any arrears charges; second, to any water and sewer charges including arrears charges. In the event of partial payments, the utility charges will be considered outstanding and the disconnection for non-payment will be enforced. 
(e)  Responsibility for use of service. All premises entitled to the city solid waste collection service shall be assumed to be using such service, and the occupants of the premises shall be charged for this service so long as the premises remain serviced by the city solid waste collection service. If there is no tenant or other service customer of record, the owner shall be considered the occupant and shall be responsible for all use of and payment for the service. A solid waste fee shall be imposed on each unit of a multi-unit dwelling. 
(f)  Dispute procedure. The supervisor of billing and collection, or his designee, shall have the authority to adjust any limb, junk or recycling charge after the sanitation superintendent has reviewed the circumstances of such charge and has determined that the charge was in error. Any adjustment shall be made with the approval of the sanitation superintendent. 
(g)  Rental property. Rental property is the responsibility of the owner/landlord. When a tenant places household debris, bulk and non bulk, at the curb for collection, the property owner is responsible for any fees resulting from collection of bulk items and any clean up of the city's rights-of-way that is associated with trash at the property and on the right-of-way. 
When tenants move in and the garbage container or recycle container are not at the property, it is the responsibility of the landlord to replace the container(s) through the city. A replacement fee may be warranted. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 33-3533-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - FEES 
 
Sec. 33-51. - Type of fees. 
(a)  Solid waste fees. There are established monthly charges for the availability for collection of wet and dry garbage and recyclables in any city approved and authorized container/receptacle. 
(b)  Bulk trash service. For special services in the removal of bulk trash and limbs from residential units, the cost of such service shall be determined by the actual cubic yards of trash removed. (Refer to solid waste fee schedule.) 
(c)  Additional automated refuse container for residential units. A maximum of one (1) additional automated refuse and/or recyclables container for residential use may be purchased. The cost shall be current in accordance with the City of Burlington fee schedule as approved by the city council. An additional automated container will result in an additional solid waste fee for garbage and/or recyclables in accordance with section 33-31(a). 
(e)  Damaged containers. Automated containers that are damaged by no fault of the city such as misuse, accident, neglect, or any other means which renders the container unfit for service, will require a replacement cart. Residents will be assessed a replacement cart fee (Refer to solid waste fee schedule). 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 33-5233-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - VIOLATIONS 
 
Sec. 33-71. - Violationscivil penalties/misdemeanor citations. 
A violation of any provisions of this chapter shall subject the offender to a civil penalty in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). Violators shall pay the penalty to the city tax collector's office within ten (10) days of receipt. The failure of such violator to pay the civil penalty within the specified time shall subject such violator to a civil action to collect all penalties and costs for said violation, and any civil penalty that has not been paid in which a delinquent notice was sent shall carry an additional late payment of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Continued violation or continuing violations shall subject the violator to separate, distinct and successive civil penalties and each day's continuing violation shall be a separate and distinct offense. 
Additionally, any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor and punished as provided by G.S. § 14-4, and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned as provided by law and shall be subject to all of the provisions or penalties and remedies of G.S. § 160A-175. The provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the director of public works or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 05-12, § 1, 2-15-2005; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Chapter 34 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note Building, Ch. 7; Solid Waste Ch. 33; Lakes, Ch. 17; Planning and Zoning, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference Public enterprises, G.S. § 160A-311 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 34-1. - Paving generally; charges. 
The paving or repaving of streets or sidewalks and the installation of paving, curb, gutter and sidewalks in the city and the assessments therefor shall be done in accordance with the provisions of the city charter and the applicable provisions of the North Carolina General Statutes and the charges for the same shall be as established from time to time by the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 27-2; Ord. No. 76-32, 4-20-76; Ord. No. 78-21(a), § 1, 5-16-78; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 34-2. - Driving vehicles on street or sidewalk under construction or repair. 
No person shall drive or cause to be driven any automobile or other vehicle upon any street or sidewalk when the same is barricaded and under process of construction or repair, or in any other manner cause any damage to any such street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1959, § 27-3)  
Sec. 32-3. - Removal of barricades. 
No person except an authorized agent of the city, or any person authorized by permit, shall remove or cause to be removed any barricade placed by authority of the city upon any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1959, § 27-4; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-4. - Sidewalk entrances to basements. 
Every property owner owning property whereon basement floors are entered from the sidewalk shall erect a substantial iron fence around the opening to the stairway and provide such entrance with an iron gate which will automatically close. Each and every person maintaining a sidewalk entrance otherwise than as herein provided shall be guilty of a violation of this section and each day such entrance shall be maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 27-6)  
Sec. 34-5. - Obstructing gutters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to put or place or cause to be put or placed any trash or garbage in any gutter or driveway in the city, or to obstruct the same in any manner. 
(Code 1959, § 27-10)  
Sec. 34-6. - Protecting public streets from dirt and debris. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any building, construction, landscaping, demolition, grading, clearing, repair, installation, or any construction or improvement job site to be established or maintained without provisions for vehicular ingress and egress suitable and sufficient to prevent dirt, mud, and debris from wasting or dropping upon streets. 
(b)  In the event that dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris shall be deposited upon any street or sidewalk as a result of a construction project in progress, the person or the contractors in charge of the project shall be required to remove said debris. Responsibility for providing the aforementioned protection shall rest upon the contractor in whose name the applicable city building permit is issued. Responsibility for protection at projects involving two (2) or more separate contractors shall rest with the holder of the general construction permit. 
(c)  In the event corrective action is not taken immediately by the person or contractor so violating this section, the city may revoke the building permit and cause all work at the site to cease. 
(d)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be published as provided in General Statute section 14-4. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)  As an additional remedy, violation of this section which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents in the area is deemed, and is declared to be, a public nuisance and may be subject to abatement summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 74-38, § 1, 7-16-74)  
Sec. 34-7. - Hauling coal, dirt, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul coal, dirt, sand, gravel, crushed stone, or waste matter of any kind, whether included in this enumeration or not, along and over any street in the city, except in vehicles having bodies so constructed and arranged as to prevent the same from wasting or dropping upon the streets. 
(Ord. No. 74-38, § 1, 7-16-74)  
Sec. 34-8. - Keeping sidewalk clean; removing snow. 
The tenant or occupant or, if there be no tenant, the owner, agent or custodian of any building or lot of land bordering on any street in the city on which there is a sidewalk abutting, shall keep such sidewalk in front of and adjoining such property clean. After any fall of snow or sleet, such tenant, occupant, owner, agent or custodian shall, within two (2) hours after the snow or sleet shall have ceased to fall, remove or cause such snow or sleet to be removed from the sidewalk of their respective premises. In case the fall of snow or sleet shall have ceased during the night, it shall be removed by 10:00 of the following morning. 
(Code 1959, § 27-12)  
Sec. 34-9. - Barbed wire fences. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain on any premises along any streets or alleys of the city any barbed wire or barbed wire fence, and each day any such fence or barbed wire shall be suffered to remain in or along the line of any such street or alley shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 27-13)  
Sec. 34-10. - Trees, etc.trimming or removal. 
The superintendent of streets shall notify all persons having: 
(a)  Trees in front of lots to have them properly trimmed when deemed necessary. 
(b)  Dead or dying trees or parts thereon on any lot or land adjacent to any public street or public place which may fall onto the public street, right-of-way or place to have them removed. 
If the owner or occupant refuses or delays compliance for more than five (5) days after receiving such notice, the city shall proceed to have such trees trimmed or removed at the expense of the owner or occupant. 
(Code 1959, § 27-14; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-11. - Projecting growths over streets. 
Trees, vines, bushes, shrubbery or flowers standing in or upon any public street, street right-of-way or public place or on any lot or land adjacent to any public street or public place and having branches, limbs, trunks or other parts projecting into the public street right-of-way or place shall, under the supervision of the superintendent of streets, be kept trimmed by the owner or occupant of the property on or in front of which such vines, trees, bushes, shrubbery or flowers are growing so as not to interfere with the free and safe passage along the public right-of-way by pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 27-15; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-12. - Planting in public places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to plant or set out any tree, vine, shrub, bush or flowers or cause or authorize any person to plant or set out any tree, vine, shrub, bush or flowers in or upon any public place without first obtaining permission from the community appearance advisory commission or its designated committee and without complying in all respects with all conditions set out in connection with any such permission granted by the commission. 
(Code 1959, § 27-16; 8-21-18 recodification) 
Cross reference Vegetation, Ch. 38.  
Sec. 34-13. - Reserved.  
Sec. 34-14. - Removal of grass on sidewalk; hedges to be trimmed. 
The tenant or occupant or, if there be no tenant or occupant, the owner, agent or custodian of any building or lot of land bordering on any street in the city where there is a sidewalk, either paved or unpaved, abutting thereon shall keep all grass and weeds removed from such sidewalk and shall keep all hedges bordering thereon properly trimmed. 
Any person failing to comply with the provisions of this section after three (3) days' notice by the street superintendent shall be guilty of violating this section and every day such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 27-17; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-15. - Writing or painting on sidewalks or streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, mark, or place upon the paving, curbs, or surfaces of any streets or sidewalks of the city any words, pictures, markings, graffiti, or advertisements of any kind, or for any person to cause the same to be done, except as provided below. 
(b)  This prohibition shall not apply to official markings applied by the city or other authorized public agencies. 
(c)  The city manager may, for reasons of public safety, convenience, and/or welfare, permit other persons, firms, corporations, or organizations to place markings on city streets or sidewalks. Such authorizations shall be accompanied by appropriate conditions of indemnification and safety and any other conditions deemed appropriate to the proper use of these public facilities. 
(Code 1959, § 27-19; Ord. No. 85-58, § 1, 8-8-85)  
Sec. 34-16. - Riding or driving animals on sidewalks or grassplot. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive any horse or other animal on any sidewalk within the city or on any grassplot between any sidewalk and property line. 
(Code 1959, § 27-21) 
Cross reference Animals and fowl, Ch. 5.  
Sec. 34-17. - Reserved.  
Sec. 34-18. - Excavating on lot contiguous to street 
It shall be unlawful to excavate adjacent to the public right-of-way such that the lateral support of the street or sidewalk is diminished or the public is endangered. Any person who fails to provide necessary lateral support for such excavation or endangers the public after three (3) days' notice by the city manager or manager's designee shall be guilty of violating this section, and every day such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 34-1934-28. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOVING BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 34-29. - Permit required for moving a building. 
No building or part of any building more than two hundred (200) square feet shall be moved through or across any sidewalk, street, alley or highway within the city limits until a permit for such moving shall have been obtained from the chief inspector. Excluded from the above requirement are mobile homes and licensed modular units. 
(Code 1959, § 27-25; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84)  
Sec. 34-30. - Permit for moving a building application. 
Any person desiring to move a building shall first file a written application with the inspections division setting forth the following information: 
(a)  Type and kind of building to be moved. 
(b)  The extreme dimensions of the length, height and width of the building as loaded on the vehicle. 
(c)  Its present location and proposed new location by lot, block, subdivision and street numbers. 
(d)  The approximate time such building will be upon the streets, and the contemplated route that will be taken from present to new location. 
(e)  Permit must be applied for seven (7) calendar days prior to date of moving. 
(f)  If the applicant determines that he will not be able to meet the time set forth in his application, he must notify the chief inspector three (3) days prior to the date of commencement, otherwise failure to meet the appointed time will result in a withdrawal of the permit and forfeit of all permit fees. 
(g)  The chief inspector may not grant extensions to the permit unless uncontrollable elements such as acts of God or delays caused by one (1) or more permit approving utility agencies prevent the moving to occur at the scheduled time. 
(h)  The original cost of the building. 
(i)  Photograph of the structure viewed as it will travel down the street. 
(Code 1959, § 27-26; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84;; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-31. - Permit for moving a buildingFee. 
For the moving of any building, the permit fee shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 27-30; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 34-32. - Permit for moving a buildingDenial. 
(a)  If, in the opinion of the chief inspector, the moving of any building will cause serious injury to persons or property or serious injury to the streets or other public improvements, or the building to be moved has deteriorated more than fifty (50) per cent of its original value by fire or other element, or the moving of the building will violate any of the requirements of this Code or of the zoning regulations of the city, the permit required by this article shall not be issued and the building shall not be moved over the streets of the city. 
(b)  If, in the opinion of the chief inspector, the valuation of the building or structure appears to be underestimated on the application, the permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimated costs to meet the approval of the chief building inspector. 
(Code 1959, §§ 27-27, 27-28; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84)  
Sec. 34-33. - Insurance required. 
No permit to move any building shall be issued until the applicant has filed with the chief inspector a certified copy showing that he has in force general liability insurance covering bodily injury and property damage combined single limit of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each occurrence, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) aggregate. 
(Code 1959, § 27-29; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-34. - Bond. 
The chief building inspector, as a condition precedent to the issuance of a permit required by this article shall require a bond to be executed by the person desiring the removal permit, with corporate or such other comparable security as approved by the chief building inspector of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). Such bond shall be made payable to the city. It shall indemnify the city against any damage caused by the moving of such building to streets, curbs, sidewalks, shade trees, highways and any other property or costs which may be affected by the moving of a building. Such surety bond shall also be conditioned upon and liable for strict compliance with the terms of such permit, as to route to be taken and limit of time in which to effect such removal and to pay the city as liquidated damages an amount not exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to be prescribed by the chief building inspector for each and every day's delay in completing such removal. 
The applicant shall reimburse the city for all damages and liabilities incurred as well as all personnel costs at the hourly rate for each city employee multiplied by the number of hours each employee is assigned to the moving. 
(Code 1959, § 27-31; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-35. - Notice of issuance of moving permit to departments and affected utilities. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of a moving permit required by this article, the chief inspector shall cause notice to be given to the superintendent of fire alarm, fire chief, public works director, sign supervisor and light superintendent. The chief building inspector shall set forth in all notices the route that will be taken, time started and approximate time of completion. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide the chief inspector with written approval from the telephone company, natural gas company, electric company, cablevision company, and any other utility companies or property owners directly affected by the moving of the structure. 
(Code 1959, § 27-32; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84)  
Sec. 34-36. - Public safety requirements while moving a building. 
Every building which, in the process of being moved, occupies any portion of public property after sundown, shall have sufficient lights continuously burning between sunset and sunrise for the protection of the public. There shall be a minimum of five (5) amber lights placed on each street side of such building; such amber lights shall be attached to the building in such a fashion as to indicate extreme width, height and size. There shall be placed, in addition to the amber lights on such building, Type II barricades (per the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices published by the United States Department of Transportation) adjacent to the structure and at the nearest intersections. 
(a)  It will be the responsibility of the applicant to pay for services of the city personnel to escort the house on city property. The city will provide the vehicles for this purpose. The number of personnel required will be based on traffic volumes, significant street widths, or any unusual conditions which might warrant additional safety measures. In the event that any city personnel are required to work overtime in order to accomplish the job, the applicant will pay for the additional cost based on one and one-half (1½) times the employee's hourly rate. Any fractional part of an hour will be counted as one (1) complete hour of pay time. 
(Code 1959, § 27-33; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-37. - Time limit for occupying streets while building is being moved. 
Any building moved pursuant to the permit granted under this article shall not be allowed to remain in or on the streets of the city for more than twelve (12) hours. Any extensions would be for emergencies and only then at the discretion of the chief building inspector. 
(Code 1959, § 27-34; Ord. No. 84-85, § 1, 5-1-84)  
Sec. 34-38. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate a provision of this article, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall move any building in violation of a detailed statement or drawing submitted and approved thereunder may be fined up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day civil penalty. Each day shall constitute a separate violation of this article. 
(b)  Additionally, any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided by North Carolina General Statutes, section 14-4, and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than twenty (20) days and shall be further subject to the provisions of G.S. 160A-175. 
(Code 1959, § 27-35; Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 5-1-84; Ord. No. 91-37, 10-1-91; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 34-3934-49. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OBSTRUCTING A STREET OR SIDEWALK 
 
Sec. 34-50. - Permit required when a street will be blocked or obstructed. 
No person shall obstruct or block any street or sidewalk in the city without a written permit. Blocking a street in the central business district, or however that district may hereafter be classified, for a special event that occupies a street requires approval by the city council. Blocking a street in any other district or for any other purpose requires written permission from the city manager. 
The permittee may be required to execute an indemnification holding the city harmless from any and all liability and damages arising out of the permitted use, obstruction, or blocking of any street, street right-of-way, or other public easements or facilities. 
The permittee may be required to purchase liability insurance, in an amount determined by the city manager or his representative to be suitable to the nature of the permit, and to include the city as an additional named insured. 
The city manager or his representative may impose reasonable conditions in the approval of permits under this section. 
(Code 1959, § 27-36; Ord. No. 85-73, § 3, 10-15-85; 8-21-18 recodification) 
Cross reference Recreation and parks, Ch. 31; Special Event Permits, § 31-44.  
Sec. 34-51. - Removal of street obstructions by chief of police. 
All unauthorized encroachments or obstructions upon any street, public alley or highway in the city, where provision for removal is not otherwise prescribed, shall be removed by the chief of police or under his or her instructions, and, if attended with any expense, shall be defrayed by the person so encroaching upon or obstructing any such street or public place. 
(Code 1959, § 27-37)  
Sec. 34-52. - Signs and awnings over sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build, erect, construct, place or maintain any awning or advertising sign projecting over any sidewalk to exceed the width of any sidewalk adjoining the building to which same is attached. Awnings or advertising signs projecting over any sidewalk shall be suspended from the buildings to which they are attached and shall be at least eight (8) feet above the sidewalk at the lowest point. If any such obstruction is allowed to remain, after ten (10) days' notice by the chief inspector to remove the same, each day thereafter shall constitute a separate offense and any person failing or refusing to obey the order directing the removal of such obstruction shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1959, § 27-38; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-53. - Porch, fence, steps, etc., over or on sidewalk or street. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to build, erect, construct, place or maintain any porch, steps, fence, wall or other obstruction whatsoever in, on or over any of the streets, sidewalks or public alleys of the city, except as otherwise permitted and as provided in section 34-4 of this Code, the zoning code, and the NC building code as applied to the use of public property. Further, it shall be unlawful to build, erect, construct, place or maintain any of the above structures in, on or over any of the streets, sidewalks or public alleys within National Register Historic Districts or locally designated historic districts established pursuant to chapter 160-A of the North Carolina General Statutes. Each day any such obstruction is allowed to remain after ten (10) days' notice by the city manager to remove the same or maintain a sidewalk entrance as herein provided shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1959, § 27-39; Ord. No. 94-6, § 1, 3-1-94; Ord. No. 94-59, § 2, 12-6-94)  
Sec. 34-54. - Congregating on streets or sidewalks. 
The assembling or collecting together of persons on any street, sidewalk or passageway or any other public place in the city, so as to obstruct the free and uninterrupted passage of persons along the same, is forbidden. All persons in any such group shall disperse at the request of any police officer, any person who shall willfully obstruct or hinder any person from passing along any street, sidewalk, passageway or public place, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1959, § 27-41)  
Secs. 34-5534-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CONSTRUCTION WHERE BUILDING OR DEMOLITION ENCROACHES ON PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 34-91. - Permit required for construction that encroaches on public right-of-way. 
The chief inspector shall issue a building permit for construction or any other work which encroaches on any street, alley, sidewalk, public way or public place. It shall be unlawful to engage in such work without the required permit. The chief inspector may refuse the permit for good and sufficient cause, but the applicant therefor shall have the right to appeal from such refusal to the council. 
(Code No. 90-19, § 2, 4-3-90; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-92. - Information required for permit for encroachment on public right-of-way. 
Every permit for construction in, or work upon, the streets, alleys, sidewalks or public places of the city shall specify the location, character and extent of the proposed construction or work, the name of the person to whom the same is granted, and the name of the person by whom the construction is to be made or the work to be done. The permit shall also specify that the same shall become void if the construction or work authorized therein shall not be begun and completed within a time to be specified therein and shall require that written notice be given the chief inspector when the construction or work is begun and when completed. Such permit shall further provide that the same shall be subject to being revoked at any time without notice by the chief inspector. It shall be unlawful for any person to neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of such permit, or to engage in any construction, do any work or continue the construction or work after the expiration or revocation of the permit.  
Sec. 34-93. - Bond and liability insurance required. 
Before a building permit is issued for construction that encroaches on the public right-of-way, the applicant shall post a bond and provide a general liability insurance certificate naming the city as an additional insured. The amount of the bond shall be five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), and the general liability insurance covering bodily injury and property damage shall have a combined single limit of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence and three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) aggregate. For good cause shown upon written request with supporting documentation, the chief inspector with the concurrence of the city manager may modify or reduce in whole, or in part the amounts of general liability and/or bond requirement. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-94. - Supervision and control of chief inspector. 
(a)  Upon approval of the bond and general liability insurance coverage, the chief inspector shall designate a construction zone, which may include the temporary removal of public parking areas and use of sidewalk or pedestrian walkway areas. 
(b)  All construction and work in the streets sidewalks, alleys or public places of the city shall be under the supervision and control of the chief inspector, whose duty it shall be to inspect the same from time to time during the progress thereof. Upon the completion thereof, the chief inspector shall make a final inspection and shall see to it that the street, sidewalk or public place is restored to a condition as good in all respects as before the construction or work was made or done, and that all debris, material, tools and equipment are removed therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 90-19, § 2, 4-3-90; Ord. No. 92-40, § 1, 10-6-92; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-95. - Permit holder's duty to restore streets/pedestrian areas. 
When any part of any street, sidewalk, alley or public place of the city shall be designated as a construction zone as herein provided, the person doing the same shall immediately upon completion of such purpose, and as speedily as practicable during the accomplishment thereof, shall replace the surface of the street, sidewalk, alley or public place and restore the same to a condition as good in all respects as before the construction was commenced, all of which shall be done according to the directions and to the final approval of the chief inspector. 
(Ord. No. 90-19, § 2, 4-3-90)  
Sec. 34-96. - Permit holder's duty to warn public. 
The person obtaining a permit under this article shall put out necessary approved flares, warning signals, signs, barriers or other appropriate markings as determined by the chief inspector to warn person using the streets in the vicinity of the working area. 
(Ord. No. 90-19, § 2, 4-3-90)  
Secs. 34-9734-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DRIVEWAYS 
 
Sec. 34-100. - Driveway construction permit. 
The city engineer is authorized to issue permits for driveway cuts and construction connecting to a public street or right-of-way where an existing curb and gutter is cut or where a public sidewalk is impacted. Before any person shall cut or construct a driveway to a public street or on a public right-of-way, such person shall apply to and secure a permit from the city engineer and shall pay the appropriate fee. The city engineer may deny a driveway construction permit for good and sufficient cause in which case the applicant can appeal to the city council. 
(Code 1959, § 27-49; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-101. - Insurance and bond for driveway permit. 
Any person applying for a driveway construction permit shall, at the time of making application for such permit, file with the city engineer a general liability insurance certificate of a minimum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) naming the city as an additional insured. The applicant shall also post a bond, signed by the owner of the property to be served by such driveway, in an amount not less than one thousand dollars ($1000.00). Such bond shall be payable to the city and conditioned upon faithful compliance with the provisions of this article. Alternatively, the applicant may deposit in cash a sum equal to twice the amount of the bond provided for. 
(Code 1959, § 27-50; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-102. - Driveway specifications. 
Every person constructing a driveway under the provisions of this article shall construct the same in accordance and compliance with specifications, rules and regulations promulgated therefor by the city engineer and on file in the office of the city engineering division. 
(Code 1959, § 27-51; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 34-103. - Charge for installation of pipe in driveway. 
The charge to be made to each property owner for the installation of driveway pipe shall be the actual cost of the pipe installed. Pipe will be installed to a length of twenty (20), twenty-four (24), twenty-eight (28) feet. Only pipe of fifteen-inch diameter will be installed under this policy. 
(Code 1959, § 27-52; Ord. No. 87-25, § 1, 6-2-87)  
Sec. 34-104. - Replacement of substandard driveway pipe or culvert; title to pipe. 
Whenever the city shall find it necessary, in connection with the installation of water or sewer mains in city streets, to remove a driveway pipe or culvert which is of substandard or inferior quality, the city shall install a new pipe or culvert of approved quality and the cost of such pipe or culvert shall be borne by the abutting property owner; provided, that the city shall not be required to make such installation until the property owner has paid to the city engineer the cost as provided by Section 34-101, and provided further, that the title of any such pipe or culvert shall remain in the city. (Code 1959, § 27-52.1; 8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-105. - Removal by city upon change of usage when driveway no longer required. 
The city may reset the curb and relay the sidewalk to the correct grade in circumstances where property has changed to a use not requiring a driveway. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-106. - Removal by owner upon renovation or repair of building when driveway no longer required. 
Any person desiring to alter, repair or renovate any building, the use of which at such time requires a driveway, or the use of which has required a driveway within ninety (90) days immediately preceding the application for a permit to make such alteration, repair or renovation, shall, in the event such repair, alteration or renovation eliminates the necessity for such driveway, remove such driveway by replacing and resetting the curb and gutter at the correct grade, at the expense of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1959, § 27-54)  
Sec. 34-107. - Installation of driveway culverts on public right-of-way. 
All driveway culverts on public right-of-way shall be installed by the city unless otherwise authorized by the city engineer. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Secs. 34-10834-114. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - ADDRESSING AND ROAD NAMING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 34-115. - Definitions. 
Private road: Any road which is not maintained by a government entity or agency through the use of public funds. 
Public road: Any road which is maintained by a governmental entity or agency through the use of public funds. 
Radio/communications services: Includes any radio communications, transmissions, dispatching or future. Enhanced 911 communications that may involve police, emergency, fire, or rescue operations, but are not limited to these aforesaid operations. 
Street address: An identifier unique for each addressable structure within the city. The minimum adequate street address shall be defined as the assigned structure number and the officially adopted road name. Where required by this chapter, the street address shall also include the assigned unit designator. 
Structure: Any building, whether residential, commercial, industrial, or institutional in nature and use. 
Structure number: The numerical portion of the street address, as assigned by the GIS administrator or his or her designee, in accordance with the official road name and structure numbering map of the city. 
Unit designator: The portion of the street address used to distinguish individual units within the same structure. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-116. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to provide for the orderly assignment of city addresses; to fulfill the city's responsibilities between the city, county and the E-911 computer aided dispatch system, to protect the safety and welfare of the general public by facilitating the location of individual dwellings and businesses by emergency response personnel. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-117. - Territorial jurisdiction. 
The road naming and addressing policies set forth in this article shall be applicable within the territorial and extra territorial limits of the city as defined on the official zoning map. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-118. - Official road name and structure numbering map. 
(a)  The official road name and structure numbering map shall be known as the "addressing map". The map shall be effective upon adoption by the city council. All city addresses assigned shall be assigned in accordance with this map. 
(b)  The addressing map shall be kept on file in the GIS division. This map may be maintained and updated in the city's GIS (Geographic Information System). 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-119. - Administrator and responsibilities. 
(a)  The GIS administrator, or his or her designee, is given authority to administer and assign city addresses, and to enforce the provisions of this article. Questions arising from the enforcement of this article shall be interpreted by the GIS administrator or his or her designee. 
(b)  Interpretation of this article shall be accomplished by the GIS administrator or his or her designee. 
(c)  The GIS administrator shall report to the planning and zoning commission and/or city council at their regularly scheduled meetings as needed to keep the members of the boards informed of any pertinent addressing related matters and to provide them with a summary of any such matters. 
(d)  Annually, the GIS administrator shall submit the addressing map to the city council for ratification of road names approved under this article and added to the map. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
DIVISION 2. - NUMBERING SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 34-120. - Uniform numbering 
system. 
All roads that are officially designated on the addressing map whether public or private shall have a uniform and consecutive numbering system along the roadway centerline. Numbers shall be assigned along the entirety of all named roads. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-121. - Origin point of numbering system. 
The origin point, or vertex, of the numbering system shall be located at the intersection of Church Street, and Webb Avenue in Burlington, NC. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-122. - North/south and east/west axis. 
The city shall be divided by two axes. The north-south axis shall be Webb Avenue. The east-west axis shall be Church Street. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-123. - Name, numbering, signs where required. 
(a)  All roads, both public and private, shall be named, numbered, and have road name signs installed according to the standards of section 34-147 if two (2) or more addressable structures, including mobile homes, are located on and accessed by them. 
(b)  If development on a private road exceeds two or more addressable structures including mobile homes, the road shall be named and numbered and structures readdressed according to the requirements herein. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-124. - Numbering method. 
A pair of numbers, each being either a three-, four-, or five-digit natural number, called a structure number, shall be assigned at intervals of 5.28 feet along a roadway centerline. Odd natural numbers shall be assigned to the right side of the road by ascending numbers moving away from the axes or origin point. Even natural numbers shall be assigned to the left side of the road in a like manner. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-125. - Numbers on dead end roads. 
All dead end roads and cul-de-sacs shall begin with ascending numbers at the open end, that being the end connecting to another road. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-126. - Numbers on roads connecting to both axes. 
Roads which connect to both axes shall begin ascending numbers on the end stemming from the north-south axis. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-127. - Numbers begin with 100. 
The first potentially assignable structure number on a given road shall be the number 100. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-128. - Method of assigning a number. 
Each structure shall be assigned a structure number based on the number of the appropriate segment of roadway centerline. The structure number shall be determined by the line perpendicular to the road centerline, which intersects with the front door of the structure. The number of the centerline segment at the point of perpendicular intersection shall be the number of the structure. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-129. - Numbers on corner lots. 
Structures on corner lots shall be assigned a structure number either from the road that intersects the addressable driveway to that structure, or from the road in which the main access or entrance to the structure is oriented. The number will be assigned using the method in section 34-129. above and will be assigned in the manner as determined by the GIS administrator or his or her designee. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-130. - Numbers for duplex and multi-family dwellings. 
One (1) structure number shall be assigned to each structure whose units share a common roof. Each unit within the structure shall be assigned a unit designator. Allowed unit designators include apartment numbers for apartments, and numbers for commercial buildings. The unit designator shall be a number, and shall not include alphabetic characters, except for underground units as stated in section 34-131 of this chapter. This section specifically applies to multi-family dwellings. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-131. - Assignment of unit designators. 
(a)  Residential unit designators shall be as follows: ground-level floor numbers, #101, #102, #103; second floor numbers, #201, #202, #203 and the like; all floor levels are to follow this scheme. Underground floor designators shall follow the same scheme with the exception of having a "U" for a prefix, for example #U101, # U102, and the like. 
(b)  Unit designators shall be assigned in a logical manner, with increasing unit numbers corresponding to increasing road centerline numbering wherever possible. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-132. - Numbers for mobile homes. 
Manufactured housing or mobile homes shall be assigned individual street addresses according to the requirements herein, whether they are located on individual lots or in developments or parks. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-133. - Road name address. 
The road name for an address shall be the name of the road from which the structure is numbered. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-134. - Assignment of structure numbers. 
The GIS Administrator is authorized to assign and reassign structure numbers in accordance with the provisions of this article. The Administrator shall mail notice of a proposed structure number or number change to each landowner whose structure number will be assigned or changed and to the physical address. The notice shall be mailed by first class mail to the landowners according to the county tax abstracts using the last owner's address as shown on the county tax listing, and to the physical address. 
Following such notice, affected parties may appeal an assignment in writing to the GIS Administrator and thereafter may submit a written appeal to the city council stating the reason for the objection and asking to be heard. 
In the absence of appeal, structure numbers take effect as of the date specified in the notice to landowners. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-135. - Time constraints for posting structure number. 
Within ninety (90) days after written notification of the assignment of, or change of, a structure number, the owner of the structure shall post the assigned structure number in compliance with the requirements herein. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-136. - Number specifications. 
(a)  All structure numbers shall be constructed of a durable material. The color shall contrast with the color scheme of the structure, and if mounted on glass, shall contrast with the background and be clearly visible. 
(b)  The minimum number size for residential structures shall be four inches in height. Reference: Section 505.1 of the North Carolina Fire Code. The minimum size for all other structure numbers shall be six inches in height. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-137. - Posting locations of structure numbers. 
(a)  For single-family residential or duplex structures, the structure number shall be posted and maintained within a three-foot perimeter of the front entrance of the structure, in a location visible and readable from the road. For all other structures, the structure number shall be posted on a building face most readily visible from the road from which the number is assigned. Unit designators shall be posted at each unit within a three-foot perimeter of the front entrance of the unit. 
(b)  In the event that a structure or its posted number is not visible from the road from which its number is assigned, the assigned structure number shall also be posted on property adjacent to the road. This number shall be located at the primary driveway access point. 
(c)  In all cases, the structure number shall be clearly displayed in such a way that the structure number can easily be identified from the street or road during both day or night. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-138. - Maintenance of structure numbers. 
Following the posting of the assigned number as required herein, the owner shall maintain the structure number at all times in compliance with the requirements of this subchapter. Structure numbers and unit designators, as viewed from the road, shall not be obstructed from view. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
DIVISION 3. - ROAD NAMING 
 
Sec. 34-139. - Road names; authority of GIS administrator. 
(a)  The GIS administrator shall have administrative authority to name unnamed public and private roads with two (2) or more addressable structures. Using current county tax records, the administrator shall give notice to all landowners having frontage along the road and to occupants at the physical address of the action taken. Such names shall be ratified by action of the city council upon submission of the addressing map by the administrator. 
(b)  All new road names in subdivision plats require the approval of the GIS administrator in the course of review by the technical review committee. Such road names are approved by the city council when it approves the plat. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-140. - Road naming criteria. 
The GIS administrator shall maintain a database of existing road names, such that duplicate or "deceptively similar" road names are neither approved nor assigned. 
New road names that relate to the history, location or scale of a project area shall be given consideration. 
New road names that are offensive or insulting to the state's people, history and heritage shall not be used. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-141. - Existing road names. 
The GIS administrator shall whenever possible, consistent with the provisions of this chapter, retain road names already established. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-142. - Ratification of names 
Road names approved under this article shall be added to the addressing map which shall be submitted by the GIS administrator to the city council for ratification at the end of each calendar year. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-143. - Road name suffixes. 
The following road name suffixes are allowed: Avenue (AVE), Boulevard (BLVD), Circle (CIR), Court (CT), Drive (DR), Highway (HWY), Lane (LN), Loop (LP), Parkway (PKWY), Place (PL), Road (RD), Street (ST), Trail (TRL), and Way. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-144. - Same name for road segments. 
Each road shall bear the same name and uniform numbering along the entirety of the road. Segments of roads shall not be allowed to have different or separate names. The GIS administrator shall determine what constitutes a road or way. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-145. - Different names for offset intersections and split routes. 
Split routes, also known as "dog-legs" of offset intersections, shall be treated as separate roads with different names and numbering to preserve the integrity and continuity of the numbering system. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-146. - Different names for impasses. 
Impasses or sections of a road that are impassable shall be assigned different names and numbering to each portion of the road on either side of the impasse to preserve the integrity and continuity of the numbering system. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-147. - Installation and maintenance of road name signs 
All public road name signs required by this chapter shall be installed and maintained by the public works department. All private road name signs required by this chapter shall be installed and maintained by property owner(s). 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 34-148. - Sign standards. 
Road name signs shall meet the following standards: 
(a)  All road name signs should be at least nine (9) inches in vertical dimension, or higher.
