b.  Significant risk of contamination (booster pumps, foam, antifreeze solution, etc.) RP 
(19)  Hospitals, medical buildings, sanitariums, morgues; mortuaries, autopsy facilities, nursing and convalescent homes, medical clinics, and veterinary hospitals: RP 
(20)  Industrial facilities: 
a.  Low risk of contamination: DCVA 
b.  Significant risk of contamination: RP 
(21)  Laundries: 
a.  Low risk of contamination: DCVA 
b.  Significant risk of contamination (i.e. Commercial Laundries, Dry Cleaners): RP 
(22)  Lawn irrigation systems: RP 
(23)  Metal manufacturing, cleaning, processing and fabricating plants: RP 
(24)  Mobile home parks: DCVA or RP 
(25)  Motion picture studios: RP 
(26)  Oil and gas productions, storage or transmission properties: RP 
(27)  Paper and paper products plants: RP 
(28)  Pest control (exterminating ~ fumigating): RP 
(29)  Plating plants and facilities: RP 
(30)  Power plants: RP 
(31)  Radioactive materials or substances plants or facilities handling: RP 
(32)  Restaurants: 
a.  Low risk of contamination: DCVA 
b.  Significant risk of contamination: RP 
(33)  Restricted, classified, or other closed facilities: RP 
(34)  Rubber plants (natural or synthetic): RP 
(35)  Sand and gravel plants: RP 
(36)  Sanitary and storm drain systems: RP 
(37)  Schools and colleges: RP 
(38)  Sewage treatment plants: RP 
(39)  Swimming pools: RP 
(40)  Waterfront and port facilities and industries: RP 
(41)  Water treatment facilities: RP 
All backflow prevention assemblies/devices shall meet the testing and installation requirements set by the city's cross connection control office for their specified use prior to installation. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 40-206. - Installation of assemblies. 
(1)  All backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in accordance with the city's cross connection control office requirements regarding minimum clearances of twelve (12) inches above ground, twenty-four (24) inches on all sides and a maximum height of between thirty (30) to sixty (60) inches. They shall be installed in an area easily accessible for testing and repair(s), and serviceable from the floor level. 
(2)  All new construction plans and specifications, when required by the North Carolina Building Code and the NCDEQ/DWR, shall be made available to the city's cross connection control office for review and approval, and to determine the degree of hazard. New installation of testable backflow prevention assemblies shall require protection against weather and vandalism; this may include a concrete foundation for covers to be installed with anchors at the owner's expense. 
(3)  Ownership, installation, testing, and maintenance of the assembly shall be the responsibility of the customer. 
(4)  All double check valve assemblies must be installed above ground so that no portion of the assembly can become submerged in any substance under any circumstances. Double check valve assemblies may be installed in a vertical position with prior approval from the city's cross connection control office provided the flow of water is in an upward direction. 
(5)  When it is not possible to interrupt water service, provisions shall be made for a "parallel installation" of backflow prevention assemblies; the parallel assembly shall be the same type as on the main line. The city will not accept an unprotected bypass around a backflow preventer when the assembly is in need of testing, repair, or replacement. 
(6)  Reduced pressure principle assemblies must be installed in a horizontal position and in a location in which no portion of the assembly can become submerged in any substance under any circumstances (pit, vault, and/or below grade installations are prohibited unless engineered with a sufficient gravity drain). 
(7)  The installation of a backflow prevention assembly that is not approved must be replaced with an approved backflow prevention assembly. 
(8)  The installer is responsible to make sure a backflow prevention assembly is working properly upon installation and is required to furnish the following information to the city's cross connection control office within fifteen (15) days after a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RP), double-check valve assembly (DCVA), pressure vacuum breaker (PVB), double check-detector assembly (DCDA), or reduced pressure principle assembly (RPDA) is installed: 
(a)  Service address where assembly is located. 
(b)  Owner (and address, if different from service address). 
(c)  Description of assembly's location (specific, i.e. Northeast corner of front entrance) and site drawing. 
(d)  Date of installation. 
(e)  Installer (include name, plumbing company represented, plumber's license number, and plumbing permit number). 
(f)  Type of assembly, size of assembly. 
(g)  Manufacturer, model number, serial number. 
(h)  Test results/report. 
(9)  The consumer shall, upon notification, install the appropriate containment assembly within sixty (60) days or less as determined by the Director based on the perceived risk to the approved water system. 
All facilities which pose a health hazard to the potable water system must have a containment assembly in the form of a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly installed within sixty (60) days or immediately, it if is determined that there is an imminent threat to the water distribution system. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 40-207. - Testing, inspection, and repair of assemblies. 
(1)  The frequency of inspection and re-inspection shall be set by the director and shall be made by personnel of the city's cross connection control office. Inspections shall be made of properties served by the public water supply where cross-connections with the public water supply are deemed possible. The interval between inspections will be commensurate with the degree of hazard that will be determined by the cross connection control office. 
(2)  Testing shall be made by a certified backflow prevention assembly tester. A record of all testing and repairs is to be retained by the customer. Copies of the records, after the completion of any testing and/or repair work, must be provided to the city as scheduled by the city's cross connection control office. In no case shall the time exceed thirty (30) days from receipt of notification by the cross connection control office. 
(3)  Any time that repairs are deemed necessary, whether through annual inspections or required testing or by routine inspections by the owner or the city, these repairs must be completed within fourteen (14) days. 
(4)  All certified backflow prevention assembly testers must obtain and employ backflow prevention assembly test equipment, which has been evaluated and/or approved by the city's cross connection control office. All test equipment shall be registered with the city. All test equipment shall be checked for accuracy annually (at a minimum), calibrated, if necessary, and certified to the city as to such accuracy/calibration, employing a calibration method acceptable to the city's cross connection control office. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any customer or certified tester to submit any record to the city that is false or incomplete. It shall be unlawful for any customer or certified tester to fail to submit to the city any record that is required by this article. Such violations may result in any of the enforcement actions outlined in section 40-134 of this article. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 40-208. - Cross-connection prohibited. 
(1)  No person shall connect or cause to be connected any supply of water not approved by the State of North Carolina to the water system supplied by the city, unless allowed by the director. Any such connections allowed by the director must be in conformance with Title 10, Chapter 10, Subchapter 10-D, Subparagraph .1006 (North Carolina Administrative Code, rules governing water supplies). 
(2)  In the event of a suspected contamination of a potable water system, the consumer shall notify the city cross connection control office immediately in order that appropriate measures may be taken to overcome and eliminate the contamination or pollution. 
(3)  Failure of the customer to cooperate in the installation, maintenance, testing or inspection of backflow prevention assemblies will be grounds for enforcement actions as outlined in section 40-134 of this article. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 40-209. - Procedures. 
If in the opinion of the director an imminent threat to health exists due to a cross-connection, water severance will result until the cross connection has been corrected by implementation of approved backflow assembly or elimination of the cross connection. 
A violation of any provisions of this article shall subject the offender to the penalties as set forth in section 40-162 of this chapter. Pursuant to N.C.G.S. 143-215.6A these penalties are not less than fifty ($50.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per violation. Each day on which a violation shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(1)  The owner, manager, supervisor, or person in charge of any installation found non-compliant with the provisions of this Article shall be notified in writing by the director addressing the necessary corrective action(s). The time for compliance is outlined in section(s) 40-131 and 40-132 of this chapter. 
(2)  The owner, manager, supervisor, or person in charge of any installation which remains in non-compliance after the time prescribed in section(s) 40-131 and 40-132 shall be considered in violation of this chapter and may be assessed a civil penalty by the cross connection control office of the utilities department. The citation or notice of assessment shall specify the nature of the violation and the provision(s) of this article violated. This notice shall further notify the offender that the penalty as set forth in section 40-162 of this Code is to be paid to the City of Burlington c/o Cross Connection Control Office within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice. 
(3)  If, in the judgment of the city, any owner, manager, supervisor, or person in charge of any installation found to be in non-compliance with the provision of this article, neglects their responsibility to correct any violation, it shall result in discontinuance of water service until compliance is achieved. 
(4)  Failure of a customer or certified tester to submit any record required by this article, or the submission of falsified reports/records may result in a civil penalty as provided in section 40-162 of this Code. If an approved certified backflow prevention assembly tester submits falsified records to the city's cross connection control office, the city shall take the necessary actions to revoke their approval to test backflow prevention assemblies within the potable water system for a time period no less than one (1) year. The tester will then be required to complete an approved certification course to acquire a new certification. Falsification of records/reports after becoming recertified shall result in the permanent revocation of backflow testing certification, in addition to a civil penalty (as stated herein). 
(5)  The director shall administer the enforcement of this program. 
(8-21-18 recodification)  
Sec. 40-210. - Appeals. 
Requests for extension of time shall be made in writing to the director. All other appeals shall be made in accordance with the following procedures: 
(a)  Any disputed technical interpretation pertaining to the NC State Plumbing Code shall be resolved by the Office of the State Fire Marshall. 
(b)  Adjudicatory hearings: A customer assessed a civil penalty under this section shall have the right to an adjudicatory hearing before a hearing officer designated by the director upon making written demand identifying the specific issue(s) to be contended. This written demand must be made within ten (10) days following notice of final decision to assess a civil penalty. Unless such demand is made within the specified time frame, the decision on the civil penalty assessment shall be final and binding. 
(c)  Appeal hearings: Any decision of the city hearing officer made as a result of an adjudicatory hearing held under paragraph (a) above of this subsection may be appealed to the city council upon filing a written demand within ten (10) days of receipt of notice of the decision. Hearings held under this section shall be conducted in accordance with the city council hearing procedures. Failure to make written demand within the time specified herein shall bar further quasi-judicial appeals. The city council shall make a decision on the appeal within ninety (90) days of the date the appeal was filed and shall transmit a written copy of its decision to the appellant by certified mail. 
(d)  Official record: When a final decision is issued under subsection (b) above, the city council shall prepare an official record of the case that includes: 
(1)  All notices, motions, and other like pleading; 
(2)  A copy of all documentary evidence introduced; 
(3)  A certified transcript of all testimony taken, if testimony is transcribed. If testimony is not transcribed, then a narrative summary of any testimony taken. 
(4)  A copy of the final decision of the city council. 
(e)  Any customer against whom a final decision of the Burlington City Council is entered, pursuant to the hearing procedure under subsection (b) above, may appeal the order or decision by filing a written petition for judicial review within thirty (30) days after receipt of notice by certified mail of the order or decision with the Superior Court of Alamance County, along with a copy to the City of Burlington. 
Within thirty (30) days after receipt of the copy of the petition of judicial review, the city council shall transmit to the reviewing court the original or a certified copy of the official record, as outlined in subsection (c) above. 
(8-21-18 recodification)
